The brushwork flows with such ease—like the parable of Master Lu, it bears the efficacy of Wei and Xian’s counsel. To thaw the frozen furnace door is indeed a fine intent. One must set one’s heart truly upon this deliverance.

**Record of the Register of Destinies.**

*(This is the Central Lord’s response to the Long Historian’s reply to Lady Youying, further praising his words.)*

The heart has already arrived—there is no need to journey to the mountains. Those who empty their minds to face the Real, who offer single-minded sincerity to float upon the Dao—though they may wish not to be taught, how could it be so? Gazing toward the mountains and marshes is but an afterthought. Yet those utterly devoid of longing truly leave one disheartened. Now, let it cease.

**On the first day of the twelfth month, at night, the Register of Destinies addressed Lord Xu.**

*(Upon examination, this seems to respond to the matter of his arrival in the capital and inability to come. The affairs are intertwined and difficult to untangle.)*

**On the twenty-seventh day of the first month:**
Will you not even briefly visit the site where you intend to build your dwelling? The Perfected One of Tortoise Mountain should arrive on that day. If he does not truly come to the retreat, there need be no semblance of it. Do you merely wish for him to see me?

**On the fourteenth day of the first month, the Preserver of Life declared.**

*(This declaration closely resembles the previously questioned matter, hence its convoluted obscurity. From this first month onward, all pertains to events in the bingyin year.)*

---

**The following five passages were written by Yang:**

Reining in the light, I ascend the dawn’s empyrean,
Wandering and feasting in the Azure Vastness Palace.
Colored clouds entwine the cinnabar haze,
Divine mists scatter through the eight voids.
The Perfected on high chant in the jade chamber,
Lofty immortals sing in the gemstone hall.
Nine phoenixes intone the vermilion flute,
Hollow pipes harmonize with feathered bells.
Neck to neck within the Golden Court,
We bind our bonds as friends in the unseen.
Together we sip the jade nectar’s flow—
Yet already the blackened flame clings to the child.
How can one crouch in the path’s midst?
Ills and transgressions swell with each passing day.

**On the night of the ninth day of the second month, Cloud Forest composed.**

At dawn I roam the Palace of Great Simplicity,
Governing the gaze upon the Jade River.
At dusk I feast in the Resplendent Lofty Abode,
At morn I pluck the round radiance’s bloom.
I pluck the jade zither at the Northern Cold Terrace,
Seven spirits gleam in the purple haze.
Solemnly the lofty immortals rise,
Scattered like dust amid the worldly snare.
Lingering within the clamor and mist,
Transgressions and burdens ought not be many.

**On the sixteenth day of the second month, Lady Youying composed.**

The Dark Clarity’s distant gaze,
The setting light emerges from the eastern stillness.
Would that I might find a friend beyond the dust,
Living in rare seclusion, far from the world’s din.
I chant this again and again.

---

**The following three passages were written by Yang:**

The numinous ones conceal themselves on the Mystic Peak,
True spirits veil their cloud-borne radiance.
The dark chant is not without its time,
The wondrous response awaits its moment.
Who would say the void is silent?
The supreme resonance endures forever.
Hand in hand we ascend the Feathered Palace,
Feasting together in the Vast Cold’s halls.
I ask: who are these companions?
Only the jade youths remain.
The soaring clouds, the void’s steed—
They rise with pinions aloft in the empty sky.
Such men—how could they not long bow to the south,
Forever renouncing the thousand chariots?

**Purple Tenuity’s poem.**

Upon chanting this:
I harness the wind, I gallop the clouds,
At dawn I ascend the Great Stillness’s mound.
The crimson ford shakes the linked peaks,
Clear waves surge through the deep currents.
I pace the void, observing the nine wefts.

The Eight *Gang* [Principles]—*Yunji Qiqian*, Scroll 98, records that Cloud-Forest Right Radiance Lady {orally transmitted} to Yang the Perfected One, who composed this poem for Director Xu. All have already roamed:
For a brief respite, they feast amid the Three Gold Splendors,
Coming to observe the companions of steadfast resolve.
Diligent or idle, they do not linger.
Thus, a hundred sorrows accumulate.

On the night of the thirtieth day of the second month, Right Radiance composed:
Cold robes ford the Green River,
And so they meet Lord Fusang.
A grand assembly at the Great Forest’s ruins,
Resting and feasting in the Dark Flower Palace.
If one’s faith in the Dao is truly pure and sincere,
Why not dwell upon the Eastern Peak?

Purple Tenuity Lady chants this:
Crossing waves, traversing the azure vast,
Suddenly they arrive at Golden Mountain.
Gazing all around, they wander the whole day—
Rare are we, the cloud-borne ones.

Right Radiance intones this:
Guiding the light, they reach the Dawn Ford,
Riding the whirlwind to ascend the Supreme Clarity.
Cloud Terraces rise in towering majesty,
{Gates flourish} enclosing the jade-walled city.
Morning winds stir the cinnabar mists,
Crimson vapors scatter across the golden courts.
Green blossoms gleam on the dark peaks,
Purple haze arises beneath the cliffs.
Auspicious clouds coil around the cinnabar furnace,
Refined jade scatters as eightfold jasper.
Reclining, they gaze upon the Vast Cold Palace,
Where ten thousand *chun* trees restore youth.
Dragon {banners} unfurl with numinous lightning,
Tiger standards summon the crimson hosts.
Lofty perfected ones circle the Nine Luminaries,
Their penetrating vision equal to the hidden and manifest.
Who can tread the secluded path,
And seek my boundless years?

Purple Tenuity Lady composes:
Purple towers are built atop the void,
Dark halls surge with the rushing gale.
Jade and pearl adorn the numinous gardens,
Blossoms bloom, entwining with jasper.
They gallop the ford of the azure vast,
Eight winds stir the cloud-borne melodies.
Parting the feathered fans of the northern shade,
Grasping the staff, they sound the golden flutes.
Phoenix pipes harmonize with a thousand bells,
Western youths sing at dawn’s audience.
The heart opens beyond the void’s outer bounds,
The spirit’s lapel—how vast and bright!
Turning {to dance} upon the Great Void’s ridge,
The Six Qi govern the profound and obscure.
How could my path be found?

Right Elegance Lady composes:
Mists veil the Purple Tenuity’s halls,
Lofty terraces disperse the radiant gale.
Luan birds sing amid the flowered canopy,
Phoenix hooks guide the dragon’s {chariot-summons}.
Eight wolves bear crimson banners,
White tigers blow horned flutes.
Clouds surge, depicting the numinous palace,
Coming to this dust-choked clamor.
Loosening the reins where the fair one slumbers,
Together they summon one another.
Seeking the lineage takes but a moment,
Ten thousand years—yet a single dawn.
The cedar’s span meets its decline,
How could kalpas past be deemed distant?
The true gaze upon one another,
Lest the heart’s course {wither}.
The empty blade swings to the void’s end,
Coarse stagnation saddens the Five Spirits.

Right Purple Tenuity composes:
At dawn, the eastern morning’s radiance unfolds,
Soaring across the azure abyss.
Mountain waves shake the green shores,
Eight winds fan the dark mist.
Glancing back, the shifting chambers change,
Longing stirs the true and moves the heart.
Three gold coins may wander the plate,
The eastern peak suits eternal refinement.
Amid the tumult of the crossroads,
Who can tread the living ford?
{Whirling winds} sweep the Eight Rosy Peaks,
Lingering beneath the flying morning canopy.
Purple soars through the Great Void,
Glorious gaze beyond the Nine Heavens’ bounds.
Jade flutes stir the luminous clouds,
Spirit-mist severs the deep haze.
Lofty immortals feast with the Grand Realized,
Pure songs stretch without limit.
Coming and going through mountain and peak’s courts,
Why should there be delay in waiting?

On the fourteenth day of the fourth month,
Purple Tenuity Lady composes:
Dark waves shake the azure billows,
Vast fords drum ten thousand currents.
Driving the luminous gaze through the Six Voids,
Thoughts turn to roaming with the fair one.
Exquisite songs find no response from me,
To whom may the pure tones be cast?
Amid clouds, jade wheels gallop—
Why hasten through the dust’s throng?

Right Elegance Lady chants this song at the same evening:
Pines and cypresses grow on the dark peak,
Thriving as the cold forest’s towering trees.
{Luxuriant} blossoms flourish amid stern ice,
Unwilling to fear the white snow.
In troubled times, the deep and layered ravines.

chunks.original_text: 巡生道常洁。 飞此逸辔轮。 投彼遐人辙。 公侯可去来。 何为不能绝。 右右英作。 神玉曜灵津。 七元焕神扉。 灵迁方寸里。 一跃登太微。 妙音乘和唱。 高会亦有机。 齐此天人眄。 协彼晨景飞。 总辔六合外。 宁有倾与危。 四月二十三日夜。 紫微夫人作。 玄感妙象外。 和声自相招。 灵云郁紫晨。 兰风扇绿｛车召｝。 上真宴琼台。 ｛进貌｝为地仙标。 所期贵远迈。 故能秀颖翘。 玩彼八素翰。 道成初不辽。 人事胡可豫。 使尔形气销。 四月二十七日夜。 南岳夫人作。 右十二篇有杨书。 又杂掾写。 清净愿东山。 荫景栖灵穴。 ｛心音｝｛心音｝闲庭虚。 翳荟青林密。 圆曜映南轩。 朱凤扇幽室。 拱袂闲房内。 相期启妙术。 寥朗远想玄。 萧条神心逸。 闰月三日夜。 右英作。 示许长史。 （案晋历。 丙寅年闰四月也） 右有杨书。 又掾写。 纵心空同津。 总辔策朱。 佳人来何迟。 道德何时成。 （吟此道） 有心许斧子。 言当采五芝。 芝草不必得。 汝亦不能来。 汝来当可得。 芝草与汝食。 （此两得及来。 并戏作吴音） 右英吟此。 右二篇有杨书。 八涂会无宗。 乘运观嚣罗。 化浮尘中际。 解衿有道家。 骋烟忽未倾。 携真造灵阿。 虚景盘琼轩。 玄钧作凤歌。 适路无轨滞。 神音｛人舞｝云波。 齐德秀玉京。 何用世间多。
chunks.translated_text:
Wandering life keeps the Dao ever pure,
This soaring carriage leaves swift tracks behind.
Tracing the distant one’s wheel-ruts,
Even lords and marquises may come and go—
Why then cannot the bonds be severed?

Right Elegance Lady composes.

Divine jade gleams at the numinous ford,
The Seven Origins illumine the spirit’s gate.
The numen shifts within the square inch of the heart,
A single leap ascends to the Grand Tenuity.
Exquisite tones ride harmonious song,
The lofty assembly too has its mechanism.
Gaze in unison with heaven and humankind,
In concert with the morning’s radiant flight.
Reining beyond the Six Directions,
How could there be peril or collapse?

On the night of the twenty-third day of the fourth month,
Purple Tenuity Lady composes:
Dark resonance lies beyond wondrous images,
Harmonious voices summon one another.
Numinous clouds thicken the purple dawn,
Orchid winds stir the green chariot’s call.
The Highest Perfected feast in the jasper terrace,
Their bearing marks them as earthbound immortals.
What they await is noble and far-reaching,
Thus they flourish with surpassing distinction.
Delighting in those Eight Pristine Brushes,
The Dao’s completion was never distant.
How can worldly affairs be foreseen?
They would but dissolve your form and qi.

On the night of the twenty-seventh day of the fourth month,
Southern Marchmount Lady composes.

Twelve pieces bear Yang’s calligraphy,
with additional transcriptions by various scribes.

Pure and still, I vow for Eastern Mountain,
Shaded by radiance, I dwell in the numinous grotto.
The heart’s echoes resound in the tranquil courtyard,
Canopies of verdant forests grow dense.
Circular brilliance illumines the southern casement,
Crimson phoenixes fan the secluded chamber.
Sleeves clasped within the quiet room,
We pledge to initiate wondrous arts.
Vast and bright, distant thoughts turn to the mysterious,
Desolate and serene, the spirit’s heart roams free.

On the night of the third day of the intercalary month,
Right Elegance Lady composes,
addressed to Director Xu.
(Note: In the Jin calendar, the intercalary month of the bingyin year was the fourth month.)

These bear Yang’s calligraphy,
with additional transcriptions by scribes.

Releasing the heart to the empty confluence of waters,
Reining the crimson steeds—
Why does the fair one come so late?
When will the Dao and virtue be achieved?

(Chanting this Dao verse:)
If you truly intend to follow the Master’s axe,
Then you should gather the five zhi herbs.
Even if the zhi herbs cannot be found,
You still cannot come.
If you come, then you may obtain them—
The zhi herbs shall be yours to eat.

(These lines of “obtain” and “come” are playful, rendered in Wu dialect.)

Right Elegance Lady chants this.

Two pieces bear Yang’s calligraphy.

The Eight Paths converge without a single origin,
Riding fate, I observe the clamor of the world.
Transformed amid the floating dust,
Loosening my robe, I join the Daoist family.
Swift as mist, yet uncollapsed,
I carry the true to the numinous heights.
Empty radiance coils through the jasper pavilion,
The dark harmony composes the phoenix’s song.
The road is smooth, without hindrance,
Numinous tones dance upon cloud-waves.
Virtues aligned, they flourish in Jade Capital—
What need is there for the world’s excess?

Exquisite songs find no response from me,
To whom may the pure tones be cast?
Amid clouds, jade wheels gallop—

Right Elegance Lady chants this song at the same evening:
Pines and cypresses grow on the dark peak,
Thriving as the cold forest’s towering trees.
{Luxuriant} blossoms flourish amid stern ice,
Unwilling to fear the white snow.
In troubled times, the deep and layered ravines.

chunks.original_text: 授书毕。 又吟。 良久而复授令书此诗。 似不与书上相连也。 坦夷观天真。 去累纵众情。 体寂废机驷。 崇有则摄生。 焉得齐物子。 委运任所经。 右中候夫人作。 薄宴尘飙领。 代谢缘还归。 奚识灵劫期。 顾眄令人悲。 紫微夫人作。 右三篇有掾书。 林振须类感。 云蔚待龙吟。 玄数自相求。 触节皆有音。 飞出西华。 总辔忽来寻。 八遐非无娱。 同咏理自钦。 悼此四罗内。 百忧常在心。 俱游北寒台。 神风开尔襟。 六月二十三日夜。 南极夫人作。 登发东华。 扇｛火火火欠｝｛人舞｝太玄。 飞辔腾九万。 八落亦已均。 ｛暂足｝眄山水际。 窈窕灵岳间。 同风自齐气。 道合理亦亲。 龙芝永遐龄。 内观摄天真。
chunks.translated_text:
The transmission of the text complete,
She chants again.
After a long while, she once more bestows this poem,
Seeming unconnected to what was written above.

Serene, I observe the celestial truth,
Shedding burdens, I release all passions.
The body stills, the mechanism of the four steeds abandoned,
Exalting being, I thus preserve life.
Where might I find the Master of Equanimity,
To entrust fate and follow wherever it leads?

Composed by the Lady of the Central Watchtower.

A fleeting feast beneath the dust-laden winds,
Vicissitudes trace their return.
How could one know the span of the kalpa’s turning?
A glance back stirs sorrow in the heart.

Composed by the Lady of the Purple Tenuity.

These three pieces bear Yuan’s calligraphy.

The forest stirs with kindred resonance,
Clouds gather, awaiting the dragon’s song.
Mysterious numbers seek one another,
Every touch of rhythm bears its own sound.
Flying forth from Western Florescence,
Reins gathered, they suddenly come in search.
Though the Eight Distances hold no lack of joy,
In shared chanting, the principle itself commands reverence.
Mourning those within the Four Nets,
A hundred sorrows ever dwell in the heart.
Together we roam the Northern Frigid Terrace,
A divine wind unfastens your robe.

Composed by the Lady of the Southern Culmen on the night of the twenty-third day of the sixth month.

Ascending to Eastern Florescence,
Fanning the dance of the Great Mystery,
Flying reins soar ninety thousand,
The Eight Falls now made equal.
A moment’s gaze upon the rivers and mountains,
In the depths of the numinous peaks.
Of one wind, our qi naturally aligns,
In Dao’s harmony, the principle draws near.
Dragon zhi herbs grant boundless longevity,
Inward vision gathers the celestial truth.

chunks.original_text: 东〔〈岑〉［＜艹今＞俞本作「＜艹今＞」、是也］〕（谓应作岑字）可长净。 何为物所缠。 六月二十三日夜。 中候夫人作。 右二篇有杨书。 又掾写。 五月十二日。 中君喻书。 （此九字题卷外。 从此后并似是丁卯年中授书此。 事皆论三许挺分也） 阿映遂能绝志山林。 懃心道味。 净神注精。 研澄虚镜。 玄渟独宴。 孑栖偶真。 乃翁道远之畴匹。 姜伯真之徒也。 服｛手邑｝〈夜〉［液］。 卒获其益。 亦至事也。 昔又入在临海赤山中。 赤山一名烧山。 遇良友王世龙。 赵道玄。 傅太初者。
chunks.translated_text:
At Eastern *Cen* (corrected to 岑, meaning "peak"), one may forever purify—
Why then be entangled by things?

Composed by the Lady of the Central Watch on the night of the twenty-third day of the sixth month.

*(The two preceding poems bear Yang’s calligraphy, later transcribed by Yuan. On the twelfth day of the fifth month, Zhongjun Yu inscribed these words. [This nine-character note appears outside the scroll. All that follows seems to have been conferred in the *dingmao* year, concerning the division of the Three Xu.] )*

Ah Ying thus resolved to renounce the world, dwelling in mountains and forests,
Diligently cultivating the savor of the Dao,
Purifying his spirit and focusing his essence,
Polishing the mirror of emptiness to clarity.
In solitary serenity, he rejoiced in the profound,
Alone yet abiding in union with the true.
He was a peer of Naiweng, master of distant Dao,
And a companion to Jiang Bozhen.
Consuming the *ye* elixir,
He ultimately reaped its benefits—
A matter of utmost consequence.

Formerly, he also entered the Red Mountain of Linhai,
Red Mountain also called Burning Mountain,
Where he encountered worthy companions:
Wang Shilong,
Zhao Daoxuan,
And Fu Taichu.

chunks.original_text: 此数子始以晋建兴元年渡江。 入东山中学道耳。 并与相见。 数人之业。 皆胜于映矣。 映遂师世龙。 授解束之道。 修反行之法。 服玉液。 朝脑精。 二三年中。 面有光华。 还颜反少。 极为成道。 但恨其所禀不饶。 不得高品之通耳。 于是司命敕吾举之。 使奏闻上宫。 移名东方诸。 署为地仙。 时三官都禁左郎。 遣典柄侯周鲂。 主非使者严白虎。 来于赤山中。 即欲执之以去。 且诘其罪状。 吾时禁〔牙〕。 （谓应作讶字）又乃驰启司命。 司命即遣中侯李遵握火铃而来。 呵摄之。 于是鲂及白虎乃走去耳。 李遵未来之时。 映惧怖失胆。 亦丧气矣。
chunks.translated_text:
These several individuals had initially crossed the river in the first year of *Jianxing* of the Jin, entering the Eastern Mountains to study the Dao. They all met one another there. The practices of these several men all surpassed Ying’s. Ying thus became a disciple of Shilong, receiving the Dao of untying the bonds and cultivating the methods of reverse practice. He ingested the Jade Fluid, refined the essence of the brain, and within two or three years, his face radiated luminous splendor, his complexion reverted to youth, and he attained the utmost in Daoist accomplishment. Yet he regretted that his endowment was not abundant, preventing him from achieving the highest rank of transcendence.

Thereupon, the Director of Destinies commanded me to recommend him, submitting a memorial to the Upper Palace. His name was transferred to the Registers of the Eastern Direction, and he was appointed an Earthbound Transcendent. At that time, the Left Minister of the Three Offices’ General Prohibition dispatched the Keeper of the Handle, Hou Zhou Fang, and the Envoy of the Unorthodox, Yan Baihu, to the Red Mountain, intending to seize him and take him away, interrogating him regarding his transgressions. I was then struck dumb (the character likely should be *ya*, "astonished"). I swiftly sent an urgent report to the Director of Destinies, who immediately dispatched the Central Attendant Li Zun, wielding a fire-bell, to come and rebuke them. Thereupon, Fang and Baihu fled.

Before Li Zun’s arrival, Ying was terrified, his courage failing, and his *qi* dissipated.

chunks.original_text: 亦赖｛龙共｝幼节李开林助映为答对。 亦几至败也。 自无此二人及其师王世龙。 亦早恶矣。 鲂〔诰〕（谓应作诘字）之亦有实。 映答对亦可可。 三官出丹简罪簿。 各执一通而问映云。 夫欲学道慕生。 上隶真人。 玄心栖｛进貌｝。 恭诚高灵者。 当得世功相及。 祸恶不遘。 阴德流根。 仁心上逮。 乃可步真索仙。 度名青府耳。 云何父手杀谢弓。 且乱逆三光。 又许朝斩李｛玉己｝之头。 以代蔡扶之级。 又走斩射潘｛其丝｝等。 支解铃下曹表等。 水沈汤云之尸。 火烧徐昂之骸。 绞杀桓整。 刳割振｛口会｝。 酷害虐暴刑〔揽〕（谓应作滥字）四十有三。 张皇讼冤。 事在天帝。
chunks.translated_text:
Also relying on the youthful integrity of Li Kailin, styled Longgong, who assisted Ying in his responses—had it not been for these two and their master Wang Shilong, matters would have long since turned dire. Though Fang’s interrogation was grounded in truth, Ying’s replies were barely adequate.

The Three Offices produced vermilion tablets inscribed with the register of transgressions, each holding one copy as they questioned Ying, saying: "One who aspires to the Dao and yearns for life, who submits to the Perfected Ones above and nests their profound heart in reverent sincerity, who venerates the lofty numina—such a one ought to have worldly merits to their credit, misfortunes and evils unmet, hidden virtue spreading its roots, and a benevolent heart reaching upward. Only then may they tread the path to transcendence and have their name inscribed in the Azure Bureau. How then did your father’s hand slay Xie Gong? Moreover, you threw the Three Luminaries into chaos. You further promised to behead Li Yiji in the morning to substitute for Cai Fu’s rank. You fled to slay and shoot Pan Qisi and others, dismembered your retainer Cao Biao, drowned Tang Yun’s corpse in water, burned Xu Ang’s bones in fire, strangled Huan Zheng, carved up Zhen Hui, and committed cruel, violent, and wanton atrocities against forty-three souls. Their clamorous grievances now lie before the Celestial Thearch."

chunks.translated_text:
Piled high as mountains are your calamitous transgressions,
not a single meritorious deed to your name.
Moreover, you originally belonged to the Way of the Bo Clan,
yet feasted on the blood of living folk—
long-standing offenses and karmic debts
were already listed in the registers of the Three Bureaus.
Yet you presumptuously slipped through the net,
serving as a bondsman to the true qi.
Father and son, a single household,
each pledged to different masters,
living in discord,
never sharing the same libation wine.
Such grievous guilt
is now under dark scrutiny.
With sins so amassed,
how could you ever attain transcendence?
How dare you deceive the courts of the Most High,
hoping to have your name inscribed in the Purple Register of Immortality?
You have no defense.
The authorities will surely seize you.

Thereupon, he drew himself up, let out a long howl,
shook his coarse robe, and ran his fingers through his hair.
Then, composing his breath and sealing his lips,
he roared in reply:
“The Great Dao shows no partiality,
but befriends only the good.
Heaven and Earth have no intent,
yet mercy follows virtue.
Thus at Banquan, blood flowed in rivers,
yet the Dragon-Beard’s uprising met no resistance.
The Three Miao dyed the wilds crimson,
and the deer fled through the scarlet grass—
did this hinder the lofty communion of the Great Sage’s numinous transformations?
My seven-times-great father was Xu Zia."

chunks.original_text: 积仁着德。 阴和鸟兽。 遇凶荒之年。 人民饥馑。 加之疫疠。 百遗一口。 阿乃施散家财。 拯其众庶。 亲营方药。 懃劳外舍。 临人之丧。 如失其亲。 救人之患。 如己之疾。 已死之命。 悬于阿手。 穷垂之身。 抚之如子。 度脱凶年。 赖阿而全者。 四百八人。 仁德不〔队〕。 （谓应作坠字）后当锺我等。 是以功书上帝。 德刊灵阁。 使我祖根流宗泽。 ｛广阴｝光后绪。 故使垂条结华。 生而好仙。 应得度世者五人。 登升者三人。 录名太上。 策简青宫。 岂是尔辈所可豫乎。 言毕。
chunks.translated_text:
"Accumulating benevolence and manifesting virtue,
he harmonized yin with birds and beasts.
When years of famine came,
the people starved,
and pestilence struck,
leaving but one in a hundred alive,
he then distributed his family’s wealth
to rescue the multitudes.
He personally prepared remedies,
laboring tirelessly in the outer lodgings.
At another’s funeral,
he grieved as if he had lost his own kin;
in relieving another’s suffering,
he agonized as if it were his own affliction.
Lives already lost
hung by a thread in his hands;
the destitute and dying
he cradled as his own children.
Those who survived the calamity,
relying on him to endure—
four hundred and eight souls.
His benevolence and virtue never faltered,
and later, they would be bestowed upon us.
Thus his merit was inscribed before the Celestial Emperor,
his virtue etched in the Numinous Pavilion,
causing our ancestral roots to flow with generational blessings,
our lineage to radiate with luminous posterity.
Hence the branches droop with blossoms,
and from birth, we have loved the immortal arts.
Five of us were destined for transcendence,
three have already ascended.
Our names are recorded in the Most High’s register,
our deeds chronicled in the Azure Palace’s annals—
how could the likes of you presume to share in this?" He finished speaking.

The *Scripture of Preserving Life* states: “Master Xu was thus able to entrust his form to the hidden transformation—his nocturnal liberation following Lord Zhang of Zhen’nan. Thereby he nurtured his hun-soul in the Grand Yin, concealed his po-soul within the earth, with the Four Numinous Ones guarding his essence and the Five Elders preserving his store. After sixteen years, he nearly beheld me in the Eastern Flower. Once attaining the hidden and unobstructed, none perceived him as unreal.”

(Master Xu here refers to the Attendant. According to records, Master Zhang served as General Zhen’nan and died in the twenty-first year of Jian’an. Buried east of Ye, forty-four years later—during the fourth year of Ganlu in Wei—his water-sealed coffin opened, revealing a body as if alive. It was lifted onto a bed, whereupon he raised a fly-whisk to cover his face, laughed loudly, and died again, necessitating reburial. External accounts describe the event thus, though the method of nocturnal liberation remains unclear. In Master Xu’s case, it appears not to have involved sword or staff.)

The above was spoken by Perfected Ying: “From antiquity to the present, life and death possess their ford; the manifest and the hidden meet differently. Concealing the past and extinguishing knowledge—those who align with the world in this—all practice the conduct of Dao attainment. As for those who ride the jade elixir once, make the ninefold blossoms take flight thrice, revel in cloud-liquor at dawn, or wander amidst flowing yellow; who swallow golden nectar and chew jade sprouts—these ascend at once, riding the light into the void, darkly ascending to the Supreme Subtlety. The following four entries are recorded in the hand of the Prefect:
When a person dies, one must examine their form. If they appear as in life, it is *shijie* (corpse liberation). If the feet are not discolored and the skin remains unwrinkled, it is also *shijie*. If the eyes remain undamaged, indistinguishable from a living person, it is likewise *shijie*. If the hair falls out entirely yet the bones lose their form, it is still *shijie*. Those who achieve *shijie* in broad daylight are transcendents, not subject to the usual examples of *shijie*.

The following entry is transcribed in Jia’s hand:
If one temporarily dies and enters the Great Yin, passing provisionally through the Three Bureaus, the flesh may turn to ash and decay, the blood settle, and the pulses disperse—yet the five viscera continue to live. The white bones become jade-like, the seven *po* spirits attend, the three *hun* souls guard the dwelling, the Three Primes suspend their breath, and the great spirit seals itself within. Upon reviving, the blood is gathered anew, flesh nurtured, fluids generated, and form reconstituted—surpassing even one’s appearance before death. chunks.translated_text:
**Initiation into Destiny and Transmission of the Dao, Chapter One**

The Dao is transmitted.

*(This section was copied by both the Chief Clerk and the Secretary, with the title as given. It is unclear whether this is an ancient Daoist text or a revelation delivered during Yang’s descent. Its principles align perfectly with the true scriptures, and it is suspected to be the teaching of Master Pei. The reason for this is as follows: According to the *Scripture of Treasuring the Spirit*, the Dao states, "My master is the Red Pine of the Southern Marchmount." Moreover, the practices of the bedchamber were only received and cultivated by Master Pei in his youth. The *True Records* contain the words, "I once regretted that this [understanding] came too late." This phrase also seems to echo the speech of the pure and numinous.)*

The Master said:
The Dao is the undifferentiated origin of life. When the origin is perfected, then the Supreme Ultimate arises. The Supreme Ultimate is the parent of Heaven and Earth, the mystery of the Dao. Thus, the Dao has a great return—this is called Pristine Reality. Without the Dao, reality cannot be perfected; without reality, the Dao cannot be fulfilled. If the Dao is not fulfilled, how can its pristine nature be perceived? Therefore, it is called the great return. Perceived, it is called the Wondrous; fulfilled, it is called the Dao; put into practice, it is called nature. Nature and the Dao share the same essence. The essence delights in the perfect Dao, for the Dao causes it to be so.

*(This explains that the human body naturally harmonizes with the Dao. Thus, Heaven’s mandate is called nature; following nature is called the Dao; cultivating the Dao is called teaching. Now, using the Dao to teach and refine nature into reality is to become one with the Dao.)*

The Master said:
The Most High is the descendant of the Dao, who discerns the Dao’s root and penetrates the Dao’s foundation. Thus, they are the Perfected of the Highest Clarity and the teacher of the Old Lord.

*(This refers to the Most High, the August and Numinous, the Great Dao Lord of the Jade Dawn, who is the teacher of the Left Perfected of the Supreme Ultimate and the Central Yellow Old Lord.)*

The Master said:
The Old Lord is the disciple of the Most High. At the age of seven, he grasped the essentials of longevity. Thus, he is the Perfected of the Supreme Ultimate.

The Master said:
The Supreme Ultimate has four Perfected. The Old Lord resides on its left, bearing the talisman of the divine tiger, girded with golden bells, holding the purple-feathered staff, and wearing the headscarf of golden essence. When he travels, he is attended by the canopy of flowering dawn and rides the cloud of the Three Primes.

*(These two passages are drawn from the *Scripture of the Nine Perfected*, discussing the Central Yellow Old Lord. The Yellow Old Lord is the teacher of the Perfected of the Grand Void and the Red Lord of the Southern Marchmount. Since Master Pei studied under the Red Lord, he revered his origin and expounded upon his rank and virtue.)*

The Master said:

The Twelve Trials of Immortal Dao must all be passed before this scripture is conferred. These twelve matters are the great trials, all witnessed by the Perfected of the Great Ultimate. How could one not be vigilant?

The Master said:
Long ago, Liu Weidao of Zhongshan, who studied the Dao of immortality on Mount Fan of the Zhong Mountains, spent twelve years there. An immortal tested him with a stone weighing one hundred thousand *jin*, suspended by a single white hair, and bade Weidao lie beneath it. Weidao’s countenance showed no change, his heart was at ease, and his body at peace as he lay beneath it for twelve years. The immortal tested him repeatedly, sparing no trial, yet Weidao awakened to them all. Thereupon, he was bestowed with divine elixir and ascended to heaven in broad daylight. (This man likely lived in the Han era.)

The Master said:
Long ago, there was Lord Green Crow, who received the teachings of an enlightened master and thoroughly grasped the wondrous principles of immortality. He entered the Hua Mountains to study the Dao and spent four hundred seventy-one years there. Though he underwent the twelve trials, three remained unpassed. Later, he ingested golden *shuijiao* and ascended to the Great Ultimate. The Lord of the Dao of the Great Ultimate deemed that, having failed three trials, he was but an immortal and not a Perfected One—how much less could a worldly mind suffice?

The Master said:

Suddenly, they beheld an old man, his head and beard snowy white. The three knew him to be a great spirit, and they kowtowed until their foreheads bled, tears and sobs mingling in overwhelming joy. They drew near to beg for the Dao. The old man then produced seven scrolls of plain silk scripture and bestowed them for recitation. The three brothers all studied them with utmost devotion.

Presently, a white deer appeared at the mountain’s edge. The two younger brothers set aside their scrolls to watch it, but the eldest, Zhou Jun, never ceased his recitation. When the younger brothers returned, Zhou Jun had already surpassed them by seven thousand repetitions. (These events enter the realm of the inconceivable. Yet one must always follow this principle and take heed in similar cases.)

When accumulated merit reaches a thousand, even with transgressions, one may still attain immortality. When merit reaches three hundred but transgressions outweigh it, one’s descendants may attain immortality. When merit reaches two hundred, one’s grandchildren may attain it. If one has neither transgressions nor merits but relies on the merits of ancestors, one may still attain immortality—this is what is meant by "the lingering blessings of forebears." Those lacking resolve and burdened with many transgressions may attain wealth and nobility, but immortality remains beyond hope.

(This section sets the standard for merit and transgression—how can one not strive?)

(There are two copies of this text in the hand of an Assistant Clerk. Though titled *An Account of the Art of Serving the Herb*, it largely expounds on fundamental principles and general theories, seemingly not the author’s original intent. The Lady of Purple Tenuity is rich in talent and elegant in sentiment; her words flow with abundance and ease. She traces matters from beginning to end, ever transcending the bounds of reason. In later passages, she elucidates the subtleties of the Yellow and Red with profound clarity.)

Now, the morning’s first light gathers in primordial vastness, and the profound origins of the hidden dawn remain unordered. The Eight Directions are in chaos, and the numinous gates unopened. One may only gaze serenely into the empty void, allowing nature to take its course in tranquil stillness. Then, pure tones softly resound, and harmonious winds arise in unison. The twin luminaries shine with radiance, and the clouds of dawn await no invitation. They cradle the sprouting of the uncarved, blocking the myriad sources at the loom’s outset. All life returns to the true, and every kindred spirit conceals its beginnings. How could one wish for a lifespan of ten thousand years as mere mortality? Rather, one should long to embrace the talisman of longevity and dwell in eternal harmony. Why trouble oneself with the obscure realms of the spirit or delve into the illusory externals of esoteric arts?

For those whose forms lack the means to attain the true and whose vessels cannot bear its use, it is truly fitting to tread the wondrous subtleties of the Celestial Origin, to push the myriad essences to their utmost refinement, to seek the Nine Wefts and bring forth life, to behold the distant illumination of the morning light. Gazing upward at the misty qi, one sees the numinous clouds coiling through the void. Looking down upon the Six Pitches, one perceives the Eight Winds fanning their might. The Great Void emits the howl of the hidden depths, and the circular luminaries cast their radiance upon the empty sky. Then, purple mists gather in beauty, waves surge against crumbling peaks, floating vapors shape the landscape, and the clear light flees in flight. The Five Phases engage in mutual destruction, the Four Seasons clash and cast aside. Metal and Earth draw close, while Water and Fire form enmity. Forests and grasses halt their growth, and the hundred rivers open and close. Thunderous lightning rages and boils, thunder shakes east and west, splitting and shattering. Heaven is in turmoil—this is the calamity of the Yang Ninth. Earth is obstructed—this is the convergence of the Hundred Sixth. The excess of the Celestial Stem reaches its limit, and one sees the blood of the flock of dragons spilled across the fields of Earth. Thus, fortune and misfortune collide, and the multitude is shown omens of disaster.

Fan Lingzi was devoted to the Dao of immortality from his youth, persisting thus for many years. Later, he encountered Sima Jizhu, who was about to enter the mountains of Changshan. After seven years, he entered a stone chamber. In its northeast corner lay a stone *pian she*. (This is pronounced with the *ye* rhyme of *zuo*; it is a large jar. It may also be a stone *pian hu yong*.) Whenever Jizhu went out, he would tell him, "Beware—do not open this." This warning was repeated many times.

Those who tread the level Way shall see the reclusive attain true felicity, while those who dwell in secluded abundance shall find no path unblessed. Yet to brave peril is to journey with corpses borne in procession; to venture northeast is to lose companions and meet with regret. Should the great rivers prove unkind, the clarity of the Kan well’s depths shall sink into ruin. All this arises when humanity loses its true nature, when things turn against our harmony. Myriad shifts unfold, and spirits and ghosts ply their schemes, even causing Heaven and Earth to lose constancy, making the common folk their concern.

Thus did the Supreme Perfected One take pity on the restless multitudes, opening the dark ford to awaken the worthy. Thereupon, guiding through a hundred transformations and grasping the principles of life in full, those who dwell in fortune and virtue remain ever whole, while those who abide in peril and harm wither and break. Those who master the Six Qi attain fixed longevity; those who ingest the numinous fungus achieve divine ease. Wondrous formulas and supreme arts unfold within the mysteries of the Clear Void. Golden tablets and jade slips are compiled upon the Terrace of Commissions and Plumes. Subtle and profound, the divine chant resonates, the true radiance merging and parting. To sing its verses is to rein in the dawn at the Grand Tenuity; to employ its Way is to wheel through the Nine Peaks. Carriages and canopies arrayed in the ranks of floating rosy clouds, gazing back at the Terrace of Literary Splendor. Some turn the furnace to refine cinnabar’s hidden essence, grinding and forging the purple nectar of gold and azure. The lush jade efflorescence surges in splendor, the Eight Precious Stones shimmering as they soar. Crimson fluids swirl in eddies, the dragon embryo hums in concealment. Tiger foam and phoenix brain, cloud-laden jade frost, the lunar elixir of the Great Ultimate, the Three Rings of Numinous Steel—with but a knife-tip’s measure, the divine wings unfurl. Then, donning the celestial scriptures of the Empty Sky’s upper texts, entering the chambers of Primordial Beginning, the jade tones of the resonant texts issue from the Palace of the Three Mysteries. Precious silks bear the gifts of the Three Origins, flowered pendants emit from the cinnabar groves’ chambers. The August Thearch bestows the purple leaps of exalted joy, the Supreme Perfected grants the fiery bells of flowing gold. Divine youths open the carriage shafts as the Nine Phoenixes cry in unison. Heavenly pipes startle the void, morning bells chime in scattered resonance. Raising the body and lowering the banner, the Eight Effulgences float in the sky. Dragon carriages and tiger banners fan out across the eight directions, ascending to the utmost tips of Eternal Yang, descending to repose in the orchid halls of inverted shadows. Moon consorts harness their teams of four, sunlight illumines the visage; spirit maidens embrace the quilts as incense smoke overflows the windows. A glance and a turn—how the circular net strides beyond! What need to speak of the ninety thousand li? Only then does one know the Way of the lofty immortals stands supreme, the subtleties of seeking the numinous are profound, the attainment of ingestion and adornment unites with the divine, and the workings of fortune and misfortune suddenly become manifest.

Had it not been for the noble scion’s *Yellow and Lao Jade Writ*, the *Thirty-Nine Perfected Scriptures of the Great Cavern*, or the *Supreme Hidden Mystery of the Seven Origins of Vast Emptiness*, none would have found peers in this art. Yet there are those who, by embodying the spirit in concentrated thought, treasuring and refining the Hall of Light, and journeying at dawn to the Six Numinous Ones, cause the Five Viscera to blossom with radiance. They guard and seal the Primal Pass, inwardly preserve the Nine Perfected, and circulate the Three Qi to irrigate the Cinnabar Field—this, too, is a secondary path.

For one whose cinnabar sincerity is as plain as coarse herbs, what need is there for the grand sacrifices of the eastern neighbor? Instead, one may augment with five-cloud cassia, water-plantain roots, yellow essence, southern candle and yang grass, eastern stone and azure-green, pine and cypress resin and fruit, sesame and poria—all implements of nurturing life, by which longevity may be attained.

I have further observed the strengths and weaknesses of plants and trees, noting those that swiftly benefit the self, yet none rival the manifold proofs of *Atractylodes*’ efficacy. Of late, killing qi has shrouded the heavens, baleful fumes have stilled the light, malevolent demons have surged forth, and a hundred ailments have converged. Whether from wind-cold binding the Passes or flowing swellings and chronic afflictions, misfortunes have assailed without warning, and illnesses have arisen beyond expectation—day by day, they gather in throngs.

Now, *Atractylodes* qi checks demonic fluids, exhaled smoke subdues and breaks the joints of evil. It fortifies the interior and gathers the hun-soul, enriches the blood and engenders the brain, expels malignity and induces the true, guards essence and defends life.

Consuming it as food renders the spirit supple and pervasive, bestowing radiance and lightness. Taking it in pills or powders dispels the hundred diseases, and the five viscera brim with fluid—thus vision endures long and grows ever clearer. The ancients called it the "crimson essence of mountain spirits" and the "quintessence of *Alpinia*." The *Tai Shang Daoist Inscription on Immortality* states: *"If you desire long life, consume the mountain essence. If you desire to soar lightly, consume the mountain ginger."* Such is its meaning.

I do not claim that all other substances should be reduced in favor of *Atractylodes* for benefit. Yet the efficacy of *Atractylodes* qi is precisely what this age requires. In this latter age, illness abounds—it is fitting to take and employ it. Though the Dao may be inwardly sufficient, one still fears the calamities of external affairs. Even when the form is outwardly replete, there may yet be the flaw of inner collapse. The extremes of Zhang and Shan serve as warning enough.

*Atractylodes* can grant long life and enduring longevity, and secondly, it can repel the myriad afflictions of malevolent demons. I have seen recluses in the mountains and forests who, having mastered this Way, live for eight hundred or a thousand years, standing shoulder to shoulder with the Five Peaks. Yet people, burdened by excessive writing, cannot even record one or two methods to demonstrate it.

Now I compile several formulas for taking *Atractylodes* to enlighten those who cherish secrecy. If one truly believes and employs them, they may avert sudden and violent disasters. When great peace arrives, the four directions will harmonize, the celestial weave will nurture life, calamitous fumes will vanish, the five poisons will conceal their forms, the two luminaries will ever watch over, and the myriad things will flourish of themselves. At such a time, you may act as you will—no more will there be untimely ruin.

What I have spoken of *Atractylodes* is meant to urge those with intent to take and use it, thereby averting these disasters and ailments.

Of late, however, lesser scholars have vied with one another in confusion, often employing indiscriminate concoctions and the methods of the *Yellow Writ* and *Red Realm*. These indeed contain the true essentials of harmonizing the two complementary forces of life. If one unites in the Dao, breaks free from the snares of the world, aligns with the six directions, follows the seasonal nodes, averts disasters, dispels misfortunes, congeals essence, and treasures the embryo—above, the spirits of the brain will not wane; below, the three fields will overflow. Advancing and retreating in proper measure, calamities will be dispelled; warp and weft will align, and health will endure. Enemies will grasp the reins without faltering, and the six armies will march far and return whole—such are its benefits. Yet this is not the grandest affair of the immortals’ tradition.

Alas, how perilous! Though these are arts of mutual generation and methods of transcendence, they resemble driving an ice chariot through the fiery regions or sailing a fire boat upon drowning waters. Without true rectitude, failure is all but certain.

Some may defy celestial patterns, harbor slanderous malice and envy, causing the spiritual root to stagnate and block, the cycles of fortune and misfortune to diverge. They violate sacred vows and offend the luminous, incurring the wrath of the Three Officials. Or they provoke enmity and chain disasters, leading royal armies to defeat. Or they bury captives alive and slaughter the surrendered, soaking the fields with blood. Or they exhaust their horses’ strength yet still press onward—if they then plunge deep into the northern frontier without resistance, will they not surely perish beneath the Xiongnu blades? Their bodies will die abroad, their families be executed at home. How can one not be cautious? How can one not be cautious?

I have witnessed many such cases—few gain benefit, only vain strivings for survival, sighing endlessly over the cycle of rebirth. How much better to guard the cinnabar truth within the Crimson Palace, summon the primordial spirit to the Mud Pill, preserve the vital fluids without loss, seal the hidden arts at the Gate of Destiny, ingest sacred herbs to nurture life, rinse the mouth with flower-streams in clear rivers, study the profound and wondrous secret formulas, and recite the hidden chapters of the Most High. Then one may dwell high among the peaks and ridges, reckoning time alongside gold and stone. What lord could claim such a one as friend? What emperor could make them a subject? Far from the Five Turbidities of the dusty world, ever in purity awaiting the true. Leisurely and carefree, I delight in my clouds.

*(Note: The subsequent prescriptions are absent in both versions, though two separate formula texts appear to correspond to this method. They have been compiled in the third scroll.)*

This passage appears in two appended manuscripts—one on yellow paper, one on azure—where the Azure Lad of the Directions remarks:

"To pursue the Dao is bitter; not to pursue it is also bitter. From birth to old age, from old age to sickness, guarding the body until death—its sufferings are boundless. The vexations of the heart and the accumulation of sins perpetuate the cycle of birth and death, its bitterness beyond words. How much more so for those who fail to live out their natural span?

To pursue the Dao is bitter: maintaining purity to preserve the true, guarding the mysterious to contemplate the numinous, seeking teachers through hardship, enduring hundreds of trials, diligently keeping the mind from lapsing, resolutely focusing the will—this is the utmost bitterness. To regard the rank of lords as transient, gold and jade as mere bricks and stones, and fine silks as rags—only then can one be said to truly inquire into the Dao."

The Azure Lad of the Directions further states: "One who cultivates the Dao and severs the roots of love and desire is like a hand grasping a string of pearls—one by one, they will eventually be exhausted. Gradually removing external evils will also reach an end. When all is exhausted, the Dao is attained."

Again, a parable likens it to an ox bearing a heavy load through the mire: utterly spent, it dares not glance left or right, hastening only to escape the mud and find respite. For the Daoist, the passions and desires are far worse than that mire. With a steadfast heart set upon the Dao, one may avoid the manifold sufferings and likewise attain the Dao.

*(A cautious note records that the Supreme Minister’s audience contained no oral transmissions—only these two admonitions and a single song-poem, which may not have been personally witnessed or recorded by Master Yang.)*

The Perfected King of Western Citadel declared: “For a being to depart the Three Evil Paths and attain human birth is difficult. Having attained human birth, to leave the female form and become male is difficult. Having become male, to possess all six senses and four limbs intact is difficult. With the six senses complete, to be born in the Central Kingdom is difficult. Having been born in the Central Kingdom, to encounter a lord of the Dao is difficult. Having encountered a lord of the Dao, to be born into a family that studies the Dao is difficult. To possess a heart of kindness and benevolence is difficult. With a benevolent heart awakened, to believe in the Dao, virtue, and long life is difficult. Having believed in the Dao, virtue, and long life, to encounter the era of Great Peace under the *ren-chen* cycle is difficult. How can one not be exhorted to diligence?”

*(The Three Evil Paths refer to rebirths where one fails to become human—namely, as birds, beasts, or insects and livestock.)*

The Lady of Purple Prime declared: “There are five difficulties in the world. The first is that poverty makes bestowing alms difficult. The second is that great wealth makes studying the Dao difficult. The third is that controlling one’s fate to avoid death is difficult. The fourth is that obtaining and beholding the Cavernous Scriptures is difficult. The fifth is that being born in the sagely age after the *ren-chen* cycle is difficult.

Long ago, I asked the Most High: ‘By what means may one come to know one’s past lives?’ The Most High replied: ‘The Dao and virtue are formless; knowing them brings no benefit. What is essential is to guard one’s resolve and practice the Dao. It is like polishing a mirror—once the grime is removed, clarity remains, and one’s own form becomes visible. He further said: ‘Contemplate the Dao, practice the Dao, and have faith in the Dao, and you will attain the root of faith. Its blessings are measureless.’

The Lady of Purple Tenuity declared: “One who practices the Dao is like one who carries fire into a dark room—the darkness vanishes, and only light remains. When one who studies the Dao preserves correctness, ignorance is extinguished, and correctness alone endures. Wealth and sensual pleasure in relation to oneself are like a small child coveting the honey on a blade’s edge—its sweetness is insufficient to delight the mouth, yet it brings the peril of a severed tongue.”

The Lady of Mystic Clarity declared: “The entanglements of a man with wife, children, and treasured home are more grievous than imprisonment in shackles. Imprisonment in shackles may yet be pardoned, but the passions of wife and children—even when they bring calamity as dire as a tiger’s maw—one still willingly casts oneself into them. Such transgressions admit no pardon. Emotional attachments ensnare a person as surely as one who grasps a torch and walks against the wind. The fool who does not release the torch will surely burn his hand. The poisons of greed, anger, and ignorance dwell within the human body. If one does not swiftly remove this disaster through the Dao, peril is certain. This is what it means for the ignorant to burn their hands.

One who practices the Dao is like wood upon the water, following the current as it flows. It neither strikes the left bank nor the right bank. It is not seized by men, nor is it obstructed by ghosts and spirits. Nor does it rot and decay. I guarantee it will reach the sea. When a person practices the Dao, is not deluded by filthy desires, is not deceived by manifold evils, and advances with unflagging resolve and no doubt, I guarantee they will attain the Dao.”

The Lady of the Southern Culmen said: “From love arises sorrow; when sorrow arises, fear follows. Without love, there is no sorrow; without sorrow, there is no fear. Once there was a man who recited scriptures late into the night with such grief that his emotions were deeply stirred, and suddenly he was overcome with longing for home. The Perfected of the Most High then appeared in the guise of an ordinary man and went directly to ask him: ‘Have you ever played the zither?’ The man replied: ‘When I was at home, I used to play it.’ The Perfected said: ‘What is it like when the strings are slack?’ The man replied: ‘They do not sound, nor do they evoke sorrow.’ The Perfected asked again: ‘What is it like when the strings are too taut?’ The man replied: ‘The sound breaks, and it becomes mournful.’ The Perfected asked once more: ‘What is it like when slackness and tension are balanced?’ The man replied: ‘All notes harmonize, and the eight tones resound in wondrous concert.’ The Perfected said: ‘Studying the Dao is the same. When the mind is properly attuned, it is like playing the zither—the Dao may be attained.’

Of all great desires, none is greater than sensual pleasure. Its transgressions know no bounds, and its consequences admit no pardon. Were it to have even one more counterpart, not a single person under heaven could practice the Dao.

Those who study the Dao—no act of hidden virtue is greater than bestowing kindness and delivering salvation, and no resolve is greater than guarding the body and serving the Dao. Their blessings are vast, and their lives are firmly established. If someone bears ill will toward me, I do not accept it; the ill will returns to its source. Serenely gazing at heaven and earth, one aspires to become a flying immortal.
Serenely gazing at mountains and rivers, one aspires to become a flying immortal.
Serenely gazing at the ten thousand things, one cherishes the compassion of their nurturing and sustaining.
Constantly maintaining such a heart, one attains the Dao.

Human life is but an illusion,
a brief sojourn between heaven and earth.
Yet if one refines qi and nurtures spirit,

When the Dao is perfected, one dwells together with heaven and earth in the Great Vastness.
If one penetrates emptiness and embodies non-being,

One who can fathom stillness
will find it invisible to sight, inaudible to hearing.
The root of life and death is easily untied,

To endure in the Dao is to nurture life.

Ascending to the two realms of vital qi,

Ever maintain the urgency of remembering one’s morning meal—none who do so fail to attain their aim. Cherish qi as one cherishes one’s own face and eyes—none who do so fail to preserve it whole. Yet faces and eyes may still be marred, just as qi may still be lost. What men cherish most is ever their face and eyes, fearing defilement, and only secondarily their four limbs. Were one to cherish qi as the first and most pressing concern of the whole body, I would seldom see men wither away.

*(Note: The qi spoken of here refers to the seminal essence of the bedchamber, not the qi of breath.)*

Men, following custom, seek after florid reputations—like burning incense: all around may smell its fragrance, yet they do not realize it scorches itself to ash. When the incense is spent, its qi vanishes; when the name is established, the self perishes. Thus the lofty withdraw and smile, keeping to purity and stillness.

Life, as a thing, is like the sun, moon, heaven, and earth—these four images stand directly opposed to the arising of life. Lose life, and the four images also perish. It is not that the four images perish, but that the perishing of life destroys them. Were life to endure always, the four images would endure always—not because the four images endure, but because I can make life endure. Enduring life can even generate that which casts no shadow—what need to reckon with the four images?

Disaster strikes, calamity arises, form decays, qi scatters—what manner of affair is this? It seems to arise from much speech without holding to the One, from many schemes seeking mere escape. Thus the lofty nest collapses and its branches fall; a hundred victories are lost in a single defeat. Alas for the talent of one who might have become a transcendent—how could it be ruined by the folly of a mere stripling?

The swan and heron face the southern journey,
their distant wings stirring the air.
Amid the wilds of ten thousand and a hundred,
those birds deem themselves sufficient.
Yet the turtledove sighs at their meager reach,
and the great Peng laughs at the span of their flight—
a mere hand’s breadth.

Content with what is content, right and wrong settle of themselves.

The eight clauses above are all from Yang’s writings. The perfected of antiquity held solely to the tally of numinous unity, yielding to the transformations of dark contemplation and compliant compliance. They illuminated the level path to harmonize with change, and grasped the hidden pivot to align all things. Therefore, beyond the bounds of spontaneity, they preserved it without discourse; within the realm of governance, they discoursed without debate.

In former times, the mystic wind faded and vanished, the dusty qi thickened and spread. The great Way sank into oblivion, and the shallow and false flourished. Those who galloped and raced cast aside the true beyond the edge of the cliff; the restless and anxious thronged the marketplace of form and reputation, gluttonous for gain. Those who wielded cunning gave rise to the calamity of drifting and dissipation; those who coveted and sought brought upon themselves the burden of self-aggrandizement. They strayed from the constant in pursuit of what they fancied, and departed from the ultimate rightness for what was not right.

Which is dearer, name or self? The Daoist’s solemn *admonition* (should read *admonition*).

To tread the depths is the utmost warning of guarding the One. How lamentable indeed!

On the night of the eighth day of the sixth month, *Preserving Life* addressed Steward Xu: To know that the boundless harms one’s nature, and that the heart, swayed by likes and dislikes, disturbs the true—how could this compare to guarding the root, purifying the empty and tranquil, and dwelling in the cultivation of the Three Spirits? When in office, remain free of affairs. *Yi the Perfected* inwardly refines; entanglements do not sully his clarity, nor do rivalries disturb his heart-mind. Such is the Daoist in office. Those who dwell in *Xiu the Mysterious* and abide in lofty solitude, though mountains and rivers collapse, do not glance aside. Those who preserve the Dao and guard the true, though cold and heat, hunger and thirst assail them, remain unguarded. This is the utmost of single-minded devotion.

Thus the true Dao cannot be sought through opposition, nor essential words heard by chance. Where there is a pair, there is no truth. Where external things are combined, truth and falsehood intermingle. The traces of truth and falsehood are clearly discernible.

The natural principle of Heaven is to delight in life and abhor death. Human sentiment is ever thus moved—weeping and mourning are but the sorrow of parting, the rites of hastening to the bier. Internally, they express emotion; externally, they accord with ritual. This is what the worthy and the common alike uphold, and none may transgress it. Though I, Mu, inwardly cultivate the Dao, outwardly I remain bound to the customs of the world. I have not yet cast off my robes to dwell in the mountains, nor girded myself with rope to wander alone. Thus I cannot but follow the rites that harmonize emotion and propriety, aligning inner and outer in perfect accord. Should I one day violate this, not only would I fail to bear the weight of affection, but I would also fear the harm that would befall me.

Your words, my lady, are tender and attuned to feeling, yet vast in their guidance of the Dao and enduring in their instruction—truly far-reaching. I shall humbly heed your admonitions, ensuring that sorrow does not turn to harm, that weeping does not exceed restraint. I will dwell in the Dao as I please, without daring to transgress. Respectfully submitted.

**From the Writings of the Attendant (Yuan):**
*True Sayings, Scroll Six. True Sayings, Scroll Seven. "The Transmission of Destined Appointment," Part Three.*

Embodying the lofty workings of destiny, savoring the mysterious and masticating the real, I summon and draw near the radiant luminaries, congealing and stilling the six spirits. My luminous guidance shines forth in the eight directions of clarity. I yield to the numinous root, treasuring and refining the three measures. Nurturing the fluids and harmonizing the hun-soul, even should a rushing wind howl and rage, it could not assail my true nature. Though a tempestuous gale may surge and darken, how could it disturb my pure and unadulterated essence?

Thus I empty myself and chant in stillness, with a void heart awaiting the gods. I tend and gather the hundred absences, dwelling in the utmost truth. Let no cares or burdens intrude upon the mysterious abode; let no sorrowful thoughts disturb the crimson ford. In serene detachment and distant contemplation, I rejoice in the shared radiance of light. Then the supreme joy naturally resounds in both ears, like jade chimes ringing in the empty pavilion. My mouth is filled with fragrant winds, my eyes behold the threefold clouds, and in my reverence for the four seasons, I move and pause.

Daily attainment of the perfected truth—
wherever the gaze alights, all has already merged with the divine.
For the true person’s attainment of truth
is ever gained through this alone.
To feign truth without possessing it
is also through this that one stumbles and falls.

Should errors and ailments accumulate,
grief and sorrow fill the embrace,
worldly affairs ever burden the mind,
clinging to external paths,
seeking harmony for the multitude’s ears,
or chasing the heart’s worldly aging—
suddenly, a mournful wail arises,
like a child’s ceaseless weeping.
Long lamenting the dead and grieving the departed,
one’s essence scatters, spirit disperses,
the three *hun*-souls perish,
and in the void of perverse fate,
the *po*-soul summons *wangliang* spirits.
They seize my empty formation,
bringing forth a hundred afflictions.
How could one grasp the Way of life
only to rush toward the chamber of death,
or cast the numinous wind
to tread upon the corpse’s abode?
To hurl one’s auspicious signs
into foul and defiled realms?

I have heard of the lofty and victorious yet still proceed in ease,
often witnessed the luminous precepts yet remain unresolved in doubt.
Thus I array petitions upon the altar,
causing the stench of corruption to taint the hidden scriptures.
The four poles strike their drums,
the Three Officials brandish their golden spears.
How could one forget the sworn covenant?
The Great Beginning wanders there in vain.
The divine tiger bares its claws,
the venomous dragon displays its fangs—
the eight directions stand desolate in sincerity.

Alas, where could one flee?
Only after the body’s departure
does one realize the worth of pure companions,
and that the speaker’s words were not empty.

Yet mournful cries disrupt truth,
offending the upright.
Why does the enlightened lord not dwell always in the land of fortune,
but here shake his robes and return to his chamber?

On the night of the eleventh day of the first month, An Fei declared.
*(This passage concerns the ninth day of the first month in the year of yin, when Jiuhua addressed Yang Jun with mockery, prompting the Southern Perfected’s later discourse. Yang’s writing.)*

The perfected return their hearts to the One Correct,
and the Dao’s standard rests in eternal trust.
When the heart returns, the correct spirits harmonize;
when trust is aligned, auspicious omens arise.
This is the natural response,
requiring no reliance on dual extremes.

Delusion gives rise to right and wrong,
suspicion breeds doubt and semblance.
Lurking within, it harbors the mind of estrangement.
Outwardly, it grasps at scrutiny;
inwardly, it knots the threads of derision.
Abandoning the primal awakening at the founding,
deviating from the mysterious ladder to indulge in secret suspicion—
such are these followers.
I foresee their downfall,
never their establishment.

Those who cherish fear—
are they alone in this?
On the night of the thirtieth day of the second month, the Lady of Southern Marchmount addressed Attendant Xu.
*(This was conferred upon the Attendant, now spoken to admonish Yang Jun. Let none doubt the matter of Jiuhua. Yang’s writing.)*

Thus, gazing upon the vast waves that reach the heavens,
one knows they do not rise from the pools of *shuikua*.
Beholding the boundless black wings of *xuanhan*,
one knows they do not emerge from the ranks of mere scribes.
*(Purple Tenuity’s words:)*
When myriad blossoms gather, the dragon’s pattern forms;
when all voices unite, the *Yunshao* harmonizes.
Only when bitterness and sourness are complete
does the fine flavor blend.

How does that man compare to Liang Boluan?
*(The Lady of Zhonghou’s words. "That man" likely refers to the Attendant.)*

Liang’s virtue was narrow;
this one’s desolation and distant qi are far greater.
The tree that shades ten thousand *mu*
must rise from the loftiest peak.
The waves that surge to the heavens and shake the hills
must issue from the source of *Bantong*.
How vast is the worthy who accumulates hidden virtue—
he resembles the lord of *Fenyi*.
*(Purple Tenuity’s reply. *Fenyi* refers to the state of *Shanshanshi*, a comparison to King Tai of Zhou. From "shades ten thousand *mu*" to "source of *Bantong*" are also from the "Extensive Analogies," with *xiangling* altered to *zhencen*.)*

The farther north he goes, the more his wisdom closes.

The wise value discerning the Dao’s resonance across a thousand generations,
grasping the traces of rise and fall.
The untamed scales roam the garments of the great wilderness,
free from the woes of snares and tethers.
The numinous wings beat upon the peaks of *Xuanpu*,
escaping the perils of nets and *sigen*.
How keenly they perceive fortune and misfortune!
*(The Immortal of Life Preservation’s reply. This again combines two passages from the "Extensive Analogies," altering *jijing* to *jiluo*, *linghu* to *lingyu*, and *zhaoluo* to *luosigen*.)*

To pursue the flight of the shadowless foot
yet fail to gallop freely at *Lüliang*;
to be one who swims the *shuiling* waves of the abyss
yet be unable to ascend perilous heights—
truly, this one’s talent is extraordinary.

far from the snares of worldly dust.

chunks.translated_text:
On the night of the second day of the seventh month, the Young Lord transmitted this text. That same evening, the Chief Scribe also received [a dream]. (This is the character for "dream." True texts often appear thus.)

The pivot of life and death, the convergence of gain and loss—how much more pressing this becomes. Why not dwell afar in the profound savor of the Dao, delighting in emptiness and transcending the mundane? To seek near-term responses is to invite ever more [delay]. This, too, is a path leading to loss.

May you embody lofty refinement and not pursue matters down to the finest detail.

On the night of the twenty-sixth day of the seventh month, the Lady of the Purple Tenuity transmitted this composition, instructing that it be given to Chief Scribe Xu.

*(From the Young Lord of Lesser Mao Peak, a total of eighteen slips in Yang script.)*

At midday on the twenty-seventh day of the seventh month, Hua Hou, Registrar Xu, was to enter meditation. At that time, nothing further remained—this was merely to guard against what had not yet come to pass.

The reason I could not recently report my grave illness was out of caution regarding the precepts. Moreover, if worldly people knew of the distress of those not yet afflicted, they would surely violate the prohibitions of the Three Bureaus. This would bring further harm to the body, compounding illness and severing recovery.

Why then do you indulge in such excessive worry? Which is dearer, name or body? This is worth reflection.

Even if one were to substitute the small for the great—what would that avail a father? If both great and small were to come, what would that avail a mother? To weaken one’s own body is to bring litigation upon one’s own family. The Three Bureaus have their own settled affairs; worry [or grief] will not resolve them.

Only those who attain equanimity within and without may escape dread and disquiet.

On the sixth day of this month falls the Red Grandson’s Day of Severance. This was addressed beforehand. Though the matter is now suspended, there is nothing further to fear. Yet the Four Marshals have turned against me, and I am confined within the capital’s禁. On that day, they will dispatch corpse-killing messengers to observe you. Though no further anxiety remains, on that day your parents will enter seclusion. Should illness arise during seclusion, it will bring no suffering. I, too, shall watch over you on that day.

The above three matters were spoken by the Lesser Mao Lord.

*(The following three entries are recorded.)*

On the sixth day of the eighth month, when parents take their infant into seclusion to burn incense, face north, and present their pleas to the Two Lords, you will naturally witness something. What you see will bring no suffering whatsoever. At midday, the one who wore azure robes and patterned trousers the previous day will appear, lingering before the seclusion chamber—this is the Lesser Lord. You may approach and make your entreaties.

At midday on the sixth day of the eighth month, a man wearing a flat-topped cap, with long, flowing beard and mustache, dressed in purple leather trousers and an unlined jacket, will arrive leading a yellow-robed maiden. This man is Wang Yan, Marshal of the Ghostly Hosts. Yan acts for the benefit of others, bringing the maiden to be seen. On that day, the maiden may be bound. The scribe of the floral missive will, on that day, enter the well to assist the master. He will come at midday and depart shortly after.

Therefore, you must vigorously direct the wind toward the grave and present the litigation talisman to repel the onslaught of poisonous qi. Do this three times, and the examiners will conceal themselves.

The scattering of obscuring mists and the deployment of examiners all arise from one’s failure to present offerings. The afflicted, gripped by fear, thus engage in inner warfare of essence and womb. Hence, maladies spread and erupt—not confined to a single body alone. The purpose of submitting the memorial is precisely to curb the expansion and contraction of the tiger’s fangs. Thus has it been expounded in the *Prophecies of Fan Zhonghou*.

(Fan Zhonghou, whose given name is *Jinmao*, is the compiler of the *Southern Perfected Transmission*.)

Xu Hou ought to apologize for his deceit. The clerks and soldiers of the Lady of the Southern Perfected have so reported in the grand memorial.

As for the Lesser Lord: to employ the lesser in place of the greater—what further entreaties are needed? Should we petition the Most High to halt this? As for the Lesser Lord: are the fangs likewise? Hush, hush—you are but a disciple. What concern is Xu’s fang to you? How dare you pursue this further?

The maiden and Hou share a writ of water and fire. I have recently received the command of the Southern Perfected to thoroughly bind and seize them. A mere ghostly underling, ungovernable—what cause for worry? This, too, is what the Prefectural Secretary Xu has striven to overcome.

As for the Lesser Lord: Xu Hou is reproached by his father-in-law, and the reproach is severe. Yet he does not take heed of family matters or the comings and goings of guests. Such negligence is indeed deserving of censure. Why must this recur? This is the fault of the household elder’s strictures, not my doing. A solemn apology to the Dipper will surely bring release.

Marshal Fan, in recent times, has grown weary of deceit and wishes no longer to involve himself in these affairs. I did not permit it. Now, there is no need for action. The deceitful must be swiftly healed and sent away. The Dipper, ever thirsty, drinks what must not be drunk; overfed, it grows sluggish and consumes what must not be eaten. The daughter-in-law is inattentive—yet she must not be left uninformed.

Is this the reproach of a deceased father-in-law? Thus, one ought to be diligent in household affairs. Yet this persists without end. Might it lead to receiving instruction beneath the father-in-law’s roof? On the night of the second day of the eighth month, the Lesser Lord penned this letter and had it delivered to Master Fu. *(Right: ten items in Yang’s hand.)*

The messenger sent by Marshal Xu stole six dogs from another household and steamed them—*with fire*—beneath the marshal’s hearth to eat together. Why did the marshal not inspect this? The foul, rank qi tainted the meats and rice. Having eaten, they walked upon the road—this has already offended the Star of the Perfected One. There was a white dog; the common folk had prayed to the local earth deities with offerings to Xu. How could they have someone steal and boil it? The earth deity declared that Marshal Xu ordered this, not that petty men stole of their own accord. Secretly investigate this. You were beneath his roof and did not perceive it—how could such a thing occur? This is sufficient to be considered an illness. Be cautious.

On the night of the sixth day of the eighth month, the Lesser Lord of Mao wrote this to Marshal Xu. It is also fitting to address the Lady of the Southern Marchmount with words, entreating that illness be cured. Further, one ought to address the Two Lords of Life-Preservation and the Register of Destinies, with words akin to those for the Lady of the Southern Marchmount. The afflicted should personally petition the Dark Master for relief. Without this, recovery will not come.

Yiqian spoke of this recently on the Dao.

chunks.translated_text:
[Separate Review]
(These two characters are written on the back of the title paper)

The four clauses above were written by Yang. The petition of Nansheng Xu Yufu. Yufu, defiled by corpse impurity and tainted flesh, has received the sagely compassion of deliverance. Each edict of admonition bestowed is a profound grace upon his descendants. He constantly looks up in reverence to the numinous beneficence, forever relying on the celestial {vast shade}.

Yufu, with his dull and stubborn inferiority, is by nature difficult to instruct. Though he strives day and night, he remains plagued by transgressions and faults. This night, in a dream, he awakened to this realization. Reflecting on this, all is Yufu’s own culpability. Overwhelmed by shame and dread, he has no ground to stand upon.

The numinous Dao is lofty and empty; a man of flesh cannot yet grasp the true Dharma. He can only hold fast to sincerity and reverence, cultivating the precious mysteries. Yet he fears the numinous decree is too profound, the admonitions too subtle. Yufu, dull and benighted, cannot fully comprehend. Such sins accumulate day by day, and his violations of the precepts and commandments number in the thousands and tens of thousands.

If the Divine Mother, in her benevolence, would deign to pardon and absolve him once more, then today his anxiety and distress would be profound, his liver and gall shattered. He can only {break} his bones in remorse for his faults, though it does nothing to amend past wrongs. To repeatedly submit petitions and cause such trouble is unseemly, and his shame and fear compound.

Yufu pledges his sincerity and begs to swear an oath. From this day forward, he will purify his heart and renew his devotion, making covenant before Heaven and Earth. He will guard his form in stillness and follow the teachings with discipline. He begs for the pardon of his father Mu, his elder brother Huya, and all their transgressions, great and small. If Yufu has failed in his duties, he begs to bear the punishment himself. May all, great and small, be absolved.

If the Divine Mother would show mercy and permit Yufu to reflect on his faults and amend his errors, then his entire household, in perfect unity, would receive her grace. Thus, they would forever behold the Three Luminaries and be granted life anew.

Respectfully submitted.

chunks.translated_text:
Here the text records Huya’s illness—this is Yuan’s farewell address to Nan Zhen. (Yuan himself copied this version.)

Huya must be cautious never to tread again in dampness. Even seeing others newly afflicted by dampness startles the Three Origins into mourning. Dampness delights in killing men. On the twenty-fourth day of the eighth month, Nan Zhen declared:

Those who study the Dao often fail to exercise caution in their affairs and thus bring upon themselves a hundred ailments. Yet they blame the gods and spirits. Lying exposed to wind and moisture, they reproach others for failing to shelter them—all fools, unfit to be taught the mysteries.

Preserve life and warn Huya.

*(The following two entries bear Yuan’s hand.)*

Moments later, he intoned to himself:
Morning blossoms gleam by the well at dawn,
Nine canopies tilt against azure clouds.
Before this, jade scepters were commonplace—
I knew not the cedar among ten thousand streams.
Released in an instant from darkness,
Why must the guest of Yin be human?

*(Some say this is a warning—if a warning, then let him change.)*

Later that evening, Ying spoke:
Those who see form cling to their allotted tasks in Confucianism and Mohism.
The sunken wanderer treads the words of mystery and chants of emptiness.
Such men may yet awaken—late or soon.
Do the Xu brothers still have hearts?
I fear only hollow ears.
Let them try once more to comprehend—
beware the subtle path.

On the twenty-eighth day of the ninth month, Mao Baoming declared:
Whether this endeavor succeeds or fails depends entirely on you.
The Register Lord has spoken thus:
To betray inner truth is to break faith with the heart.
The three *hun* lose their authenticity;
once the true is scattered and confused,
the *po* seize the interval.
One who practices the Dao must ensure that inner and outer are as clear as mirrors,
palace and note resonate in harmony,
spirit moves within,
and divinity descends without.
This is no empty claim.
In former days, I too was thus—
all men smelted their hearts.
Now that has ceased.
Those who require smelting and reform remain in the lower ranks.
Hence my earnestness,
my hope that none linger here.
Lately, there has been some progress.

*(These are the words of the Lesser Lord.)*

Worldly affairs are not what I seek;
why heed the turns of fate?
The man of the Dao will naturally be seen.
Do not fret midway.
I wished to inquire of Yang,
and thus came to know—
so I composed this.

Guangyu Yuehe, styled Daoji, was the second son of Liang. From childhood, he possessed talent in rhetoric and literary composition. During the Shengping era, he served as Prefect of Danyang, submitting memorials to abolish over sixty corvée labors for the various marquises. At the beginning of the Taihe era, he became Commandant of the Army. Such conduct does not resemble that of an evildoer. Perhaps he heard warnings and cultivated goodness, thus securing his reprieve.

Yet Xiyi Hui’s father, without cause, slaughtered hundreds of people and seized their wealth and treasures. His transgressions were grave and his retribution severe. The aggrieved spirits (originally written as *yuan*, meaning "resentment") constantly lodged complaints, and the celestial bureaus had long since settled the case. By law, Hui’s entire family should have been exterminated. However, since his cultivation of virtue was profound, he alone escaped. How could his descendants be spared? Hui may preserve his natural lifespan, but the affairs of the immortal Dao are far beyond his reach.

The Perfected One of the Great Primordial answered Prefect Xu:

Xiyi Hui’s father, Jian, was frugal and upright, with noble aspirations. He should not have committed such killings and plunder. Perhaps this occurred when he first crossed the river...
