[The following four clauses, transcribed by hand, were brought by Lu Na from the right:]

Balanced and serene in substance, profound and wondrous in spirit,
His divine craftsmanship surpasses all bounds—
He dwells in truth and nurtures life.
In the Great Mystery, he plants his bamboo slips;
In the Great Simplicity, his name is inscribed.
Within, his radiance illumines the Golden Court;
Without, his luster polishes the Jade Splendor.
With crimson chariots drawn by four steeds, he summons the host of spirits,
Galloping through the Dark Realm of the Dragon, soaring on clouds through the ethereal void.
Surely he shall befriend the lords of the Leisure Terrace above,
And oversee the governance of the Great Purity below.

On the night of the seventeenth day of the eighth month, the Lady Wang of the Purple Tenuity bestowed this teaching, instructing Prefect Xu to convey it to Hui.

Hui, your brilliance shines afar, your hidden resonance congeals in mystery.
The lofty melody ascends, yet you linger in dreams, fleeing from truth.
Gaze upward to soar through the clouds and mist,
Look downward to scatter the roots of spirit.
With flying steps, you traverse the Four Awakenings;
Inwardly, you contemplate the Seven Conditions—
Then you shall surely receive the vermilion script and elegant bamboo slips of the Emperor’s chamber,
Your dark voice resounding in eight directions,
Your body dwelling upon the Five Peaks.
Thus, bathe the embryo and pay homage to the Origin,
Exhale and inhale the Six Fluids,
Move with ease through the Three Paths,
And instruct this luminous blessing.
Above, you may ride the empty vastness of the chariot of space;
Below, you may reverse the blossoming of youth and transform blackened hair.
Yet if your form is ensnared by the net of glory,
If you churn the wheels in the garden of splendor,
If you ride the waves to chase after things,
If your jade hairpin chimes in the wind and dust of the world—
Outwardly bearing the name of one who seeks the Dao,
Inwardly beset by a hundred worries—
You will merely exhaust your heavenly years in restless thought,
And in the end, return your bones to the Three Bureaus.
If your fasting is not wholehearted,
Your awakening will be in vain.
Can this be called a mind that does not exhaust its words?

Now, to practice truth:
One must exhale the Three and inhale the Four,
Ride the Seven and swallow the Nine.
Yet now, your breath is insufficient,
Your steps disordered.
The spirit leaks, flowing back to its source;
Essence scatters, the embryo disturbed.
Though you may fast for days,
You know not the Dao, and your years are lost.
Do you wish to ascend this crossing?
You have not yet grasped it.

Those who seek long life are many as the ford’s waters;
Those who tread the path of the numinous are countless as the sands.
Why must you use an ice vessel to hold fire,
Or hasten to repay debts to the Three Bureaus?

The words of the Central Lord, conveyed by Prefect Xu to Hui.

Wang Yunzhi, of the same clan as his cousin Wang Shu’s son, was a man of wisdom and administrative ability. He served as General of the Central Army of Henan and Governor of Jiangzhou, later promoted to Defender-in-Chief and Governor of Kuaiji, enfeoffed as Marquis of Panyu. He died at the age of forty and was posthumously honored as the Loyal Marquis. Gao Qi was also known as Gao Ling.

(Note on *Gentleman of the Expectant Gate*: a central court office, though this title does not appear in the records—only *Gentleman of the Xiumen* is attested.) Fourteen entries have been transcribed from Pingning’s compilation.

To observe things and assign them their proper roles, to inwardly align with the luminous spirits, to entrust one’s nature and life to the lofty perfected, and to commit one’s form and *qi* to divine oversight—this is how one strengthens the far-reaching and preserves the authentic for an autumn’s span. Now that the master of virtue has settled his spirit upon trust, clarified his mind in serene stillness, and embraced reverence with perfect compliance, he is surely favored by Heaven. Yet his descendants are few, and some may yet fade away—perhaps the numinous gateway has lost its weft, and the hidden mechanism remains unsettled.

In this era, the five *qi* radiate their brilliance, ever illuminating the chambers of Wen Chang. The Three Stars weave their splendor, each time adorning the *jade pivot* within. Thus the mysterious moisture nurtures the embryo, and its roots flow forth. According to the *Inner Records of the Nine Unions*, the bamboo is the essence of the Northern Mechanism, receiving *qi* from the constellation of the Dark Chariot. Its hollow roundness and inner purity, its layered yin enfolding whiteness—all arise from deep roots spreading their fruit, binding abundance in profusion.

chunks.translated_text:
Command the lord to plant bamboo beyond the northern chamber of the inner residence, that the fair ones may wander beneath it. Thus shall Heaven stir the numinous mechanism, and descendants greatly increase. Pregnancies shall be preserved whole, and births shall be long-lived. The subtle and manifest shall flourish, ever guarding propitious purity. This is the secret rule of the profound ones, and those who practice it find it most efficacious.

On the twenty-third day of the sixth month, the Lady of the Mid-Candidate addressed the lord:
*(Emperor Xiaowu was born in a renxu year—this should correspond to a xinyou year. Later, it is said: "The seat of the Grand Minister stirs," and thereafter he ascends the throne, which would be in a houwu or wei year. This discrepancy is vast.)*

The numinous herb and the *Guangyin* esoteric method, gazing upward, receive the essence of the revolving luminaries. *(The characters "洗洗" appear to be a marginal note beside "竹," likely a variant of "言先," echoing the meaning of the *Mao Odes* line: "The locusts’ wings flutter—may your sons and grandsons be as numerous.")* Flourishing and luxuriant, its sprouts abound; layered virtue must surely prosper. Composed by the Lady of Purple Tenuity: "Fortune and Harmony shall bear two sons, their abundant virtue destined for the age." *(Fortune and Harmony seems to have been the humble childhood name of Lady Li; in the *Book of Jin*, she is called Junrong. The two sons are Emperor Xiaowu and his younger brother, Daoji.)*

That same night, the Mid-Candidate spoke again:
*(The following three entries are in Yang’s hand, later transcribed by an aide.)*

"Since the virtuous artisan has already concentrated his spirit and the profound model descends from Heaven, matters of safety or peril ought not yet be inquired into. The lord’s devotion is most earnest; that I have not yet reciprocated is because foreknowledge of events is difficult to discuss."

Of late, the celestial *qi* has surged wildly, and the shadows of yin have shifted repeatedly. Venus has sundered its form between the two celestial markers, its turbulence seething beneath the Purple Chamber. The king detests this; the Son of Heaven has cause for concern. The seat of the Grand Minister stirs. Now I offer a cryptic verse in secret counsel:
*(The following passage and the cryptogram were transcribed by an aide, appended to his own record of revisions on the same sheet. The original text is woven in a circular pattern, making it difficult to decipher. Here, the lines are extracted and arranged sequentially, though the transmission was likely oral, with Yang later altering the interpretation. All pertain to affairs of the Jin dynasty, with clear corroboration.)*

---
*Is deception the subtle essence of the Way?*
*Must I reveal Heaven’s secrets?*
*There is an art of ten thousand gold measures—*
*Seek a master swiftly to expel the rebellious and evil child.*
*From this, govern the barbarians and pacify the age;*
*Heaven’s mandate rides forth, the treasure borne aloft.*
*O wondrous dragon, how sorrowful!*
*Between the ages, one must ponder what is fitting.*
*The divine radiance reverses its course;*
*The reckoning lies here—whether there is or is not, none can say.*
*Who shall quell the surging armies and stabilize the imperial house?*
*Be cautious of the earth, for the royal chamber draws near.*
*The elder son shall perish first, his metal flawed;*
*Fivefold chaos arises, virtue in disarray.*
*The fire’s number misses its time; the throne shall shift—*
*From afar, omens of misfortune appear, the artisan’s design unravels.*
*Threefold the rule, yet the artisan’s footing is unsure;*
*No need to fear distant perils—pluck them out, secure the fief.*
*Inch by inch, its depths are unfathomable;*
*Liu Xiang alone discerns the signs of what is to come.*

*Three and five, the auspicious portents of Heaven’s era—*
*Prosperity and change alternate, cycling in succession.*
*Essence, qi, and spirit—subtle and wondrous, they join the Two Modes.*
*Beware of transmitting them to the common or the wise;*
*To the worthy alone should they be bestowed.*

*Seal Heaven, govern Earth—nothing is amiss.*
*If you, child, can treasure and conceal it, Heaven shall know.*
*Is the essence of my Way subtle and wondrous? How could it deceive?*
*There is a marvelous divine plan for war’s onset.*
*Fire, inch, three, five—the auspices of Heaven’s era.*
*Prosperous ages alternate, cycling in succession.*
*The luminous artisan guards virtue—beware of reckless thought.*
*Drive out evil, expel rebellion—swiftly seek a master.*
*The art of ten thousand gold measures, the dragon’s radiance.*
*The reckoning surges; the third son’s loss is fated.*
*None can fathom its source—Liu Xiang alone knows.*
*With misfortune plucked out and disorder quelled, the imperial foundation is restored.*
*Riding Heaven’s mandate, the age is pacified and leveled.*
*Who shall curb the rebellious? Who shall fix the appointed time?*
*The artisan’s resources are insufficient—fear not distant peril.*
*Within five generations, truly, sorrow abounds.*
*Alas! The reckoning is set; the imperial seat falters.*
*Soon, strange omens shall arise in profusion, the golden chamber at hand.*

Place a musk sachet at your neck,
to ward off the onrush of water’s curse.
Nightmares shall cease utterly.
Ever guard the Three Passes—this is most excellent.

The Right Radiance spoke to the Duke.
(Wherever "Duke" appears, it refers to when Emperor Jianwen served as Prime Minister.)

The following is a passage from Yang’s writings,
(the five characters written in red):

The Perfected of the Great Prime spoke to Director Xu:
(What follows is not the true teaching.)

I once met Le Zichang of Nanyang,
a man of unadulterated simplicity.
He neither sought a master nor received instruction,
but followed Heaven and entrusted himself to fate.
He knew nothing of the methods for cultivating life,
yet his conduct never transgressed evil.
His virtue harmonized with the natural,
and though he did not attain longevity,
at death he ascended to the Hall of Blessings.
Refining his spirit and receiving qi,
his name was recorded in the Emperor’s register.
Thus he was appointed Attendant of the Gate of Cultivation,
ranked just below the immortals.
This was due to his inborn destiny,
as well as the accumulated virtue of his ancestors,
whose flowing blessings had shaped him.

Had he but roughly understood the principles of nurturing life
and received even a single word of the Supreme’s secret,
then in seeking the Dao,
nothing would have eluded him.

The reason people do not fulfill their allotted years,
but often meet untimely ends in the world,
is that some encounter the calamities of war,
cutting short their glory and emolument,
or leaving their descendants without posterity.

Those who aspire to the Dao,
though they harbor lifelong devotion
and ceaselessly seek with diligence,
may still encounter true scriptures,
delving into the profound and subtle mysteries.
Many admire such pursuits,
yet few attain ascension.

The scriptures are not without wonder,
nor do the numinous lack response.
But the foolish follow one another blindly,
unaware of the root of cultivating the true,
or the methods of nurturing the spirit, fostering nature, and securing stability.

From youth onward,
many incur harm within their forms.
The First Emperor of the body is not governed,
and the hundred spirits scatter in alarm.
Ten thousand trials arise—
this is what is meant by the overgrown city,
where thorns flourish within.

Without wondrous arts to guide oneself,
or the cultivation of the Dao to seek immortality,
one may covet glory and yearn for nobility,
only to fail when on the verge of success.
All this stems from losing the true and violating qi,
blind and benighted,
unable to recognize this mechanism.

Thus years are stolen, lives extinguished,
and ten thousand affairs come to naught.
Such is the path to seeking life.

The distance from life grows ever greater—
all is but vain self-affliction.
The Supreme possesses the Dao of the Mysterious Mechanism,
the essentials of the *Seven Spirits in the Pillow* gleaming forth.
This Dao is subtle, wondrous indeed!
At first, it was not transmitted to the dull and vulgar below.
Those who possess this Dao:
the First Emperor governs within the Mysterious Palace,
the ten thousand spirits stand guard,
and the heart aligns with Heaven.
Following the formulas with care and cultivating it,
one may ascend mountains and cross seas—
ten thousand trials cannot touch them.
Cultivating immortality and ascending in transcendence,
all desires follow the heart.
Is this mere empty speech?

Your father and son have inherited the Mysterious Mechanism through the generations,
mastering its principles to connect with the true.
Thus, your divine talents in spirit-cultivation
are praised by the host of perfected beings—
not by my acclaim alone.
Therefore, I shall inscribe you together in the *Records of Immortals*,
free from any suspicion beyond reason.
I have already consulted you on this,
so you may know my heart.
Receive and employ the *Golden Dragon and Jade Fish*—
this cannot be omitted.
The reason for this is that when you appear before the Supreme,
your numinous radiance must be somewhat prepared.

The *Divine Tiger Talisman* recently transcribed
seems to me insufficiently refined—
it would be best to rewrite it well.
Regarding the matter of *Xiang* and *Wang* you mentioned earlier,
when I recently met with *Xiyi*,
I also sensed good intentions,
though what was achieved was modest.
Still, you may naturally preserve your heavenly years.

I have seen the *Biographies* you composed—
no easy labor—
yet you were able to narrate the sacred traces,
unraveling and crafting marvels.
This is Heaven stirring your heart.
Yesterday, I also met with the Lord of Life and Destiny,
who greatly approved.
In the unseen realm, it shall surely be repaid to those with karmic affinity.
If your descendants know how to *burn incense and summon the Sacred Peaks*,
praying to the Heavenly Perfected,
their responses will surely descend.
Is this empty speech?

The Xie family, through the Tang and Chen dynasties,
has flourished like a luxuriant forest—
most gratifying indeed!
As for Anshi’s earlier audience,
what was bestowed is as we recently discussed in person.
There is no need to elaborate further.

The scripture states:
When performing the rites,
face north while holding the *Hidden Writ*—
this is for those who have just begun to study the wondrous Dao,
who have not yet ventured into subtleties afar,
who do not comprehend the cardinal directions of stellar positions,
nor recognize the pointing of the Mystic Dipper.
Thus, they must face north while holding the text to gradually seek understanding.
Once the meaning of the text is grasped,
and the turning of the stars with the seasons is known,
one should naturally follow the Dipper’s pointing,
proceeding and pacing accordingly.
In this way, there is no fixed direction—
not always facing north.
Facing north in all cases
is only for beginners.
Perhaps this can be understood by analogy—
other such matters need not be asked again.

(This answers the inquiry of the Chief Clerk regarding the meaning of facing north while holding the text in the *Scripture on Soaring Steps*.)

The Most High Perfected’s method of pacing the Way of the Five Stars
brings the Five Stars to descend into the chamber.
Holding the breath to ascend the net,
one must first invoke the names of the Five Star Ladies.
Only then may one cross the net and tread upon the stars.
This means that upon first ascending the net,
one pauses to invoke the names.
After invoking the names,
one then crosses the net and treads upon the stars.
If, upon reaching each star,
one can once more silently invoke the name of the star’s position,
it is all the better.
If this becomes cumbersome and difficult to maintain consistently...

Simply follow the established method as before. In ancient times, Master Yushagong, Beili Zichang, and the Old Man of Changling all ascended to heaven by adhering to this practice, never shirking its demands on account of difficulty. This is what is meant by "managing one’s livelihood." Merchants and traders toil ceaselessly—do they shrink from peril or hardship? Their sole aim is profit. If seekers of the Dao were to apply themselves with the same devotion as merchants, what could prevent them from attaining immortality?

Yet it is lamentable that beginners often claim to be wholly devoted at first, only to grow lax over time. Great Mystery’s cloudy forms,
Spiritual steeds soaring lightly—
Guard and benefit the twin gates,

Morning fluid ascends to the Mud-Pill Palace.

Entering the chamber of stillness: first step forward with the right foot, then bring the left foot forward to align with the right. Only then proceed as usual. This allows one’s petition to be presented and heard above.

It further states: Bathe frequently. On every *jiazi* day, one should wash one’s hair; if not, then at least on the first day of each month. This enables communion with the numinous. Bathing is not to be feared for its frequency—what is to be feared is one’s own inability. By washing away the stench of the corpse, the Perfected may enter.

The above six instructions were commanded by the Dark Mystery Master for practice and application. *(The preceding six clauses largely resemble those mentioned earlier, being a summary of received teachings. Here, they are recorded in greater detail, with two additional clauses appended for the Chief Scribe’s reference.)*

When ingesting immortal elixirs, always face the direction of one’s natal destiny. After ingestion, do not speak of death, mourning, or inauspicious matters, lest it harm the embryo and injure the spirit, rendering the elixir useless.

The Lord of Life of the Eastern Minister. *(This clause originally followed the transmission of the* Mysterious Perfection of the Luminous Hall *method.)*

The *Scripture of the Nine Transformations and Ten Transmutations for Renewal* of the Most High states: If one treads upon filth or any impure place, one should bathe and perform the *Dissolution of Form* to purge it. The method employs ten *liang* of bamboo leaves and four *liang* of peeled peach bark, boiled in one *hu* and two *dou* of pure water until it reaches a single boil. Adjust the temperature and bathe the body, and all filth will be dispelled. This not only removes impurity but also prevents damp impediment, sores, and itching. Bamboo is hollow, plain, and internally white, while peach repels evil and breaks filth—thus these two substances are used to purge the turbidity within the body. When celestial beings descend to wander the earth and return, they invariably use this water to cleanse themselves. Even the talismanic waters and incantations of the mundane world—mere minor arts of external alchemy—cannot compare to this formula. If one bathes, it is even better, though this water is not used for washing the hair. The pure essence for refining the corpse is precisely for bathing—truly wondrous and arcane.

The above was commanded for use by the Lady of Purple Tenuity.

Having performed six bows twice over, they shall kneel, press their foreheads to the ground, and say:

“Reverently I address the Supreme Great Dao, the Lofty Void, the Jade Dawn, the Grand Simplicity, the Purple Palace, the Eight Numinous Ones, and the Three Primordial Lords; the Central Yellow Elder, the Peerless White Prime, the Supreme Emperor; the Five Elders, the High Perfected, the Upper Immortals, the Three Sovereigns of the Grand Culmen’s Imperial Essence. I, your disciple of the Great Grotto’s Three Luminaries, on this auspicious night, when the Celestial Pass opens ninefold, do ascend my petition to the Jade Emperor, the True Lord on High, beseeching to attain longevity in the world above, to live for boundless eons, to ride at the hour the yellow dawn’s green canopy and dragon-carriage ascend to the Purple Court, and to command the myriad spirits.”

On the night of the tenth day of the tenth month, perform the visualization practices of the Cavern Secrets within your bedchamber. It is auspicious to remain alone and sleepless. That evening, the Guardian Scriptures Jade Lads and Jade Maidens, along with the Supreme Ultimate Masters of the Celestial Prohibitions, will descend from the void to observe you. On this night, burn incense with utmost devotion, as though awaiting their arrival. Whether sitting or lying down, engage in visualization, scripture recitation, or contemplation of the Real—whatever your intent directs. However, you must not attend to other matters that evening, for this is not the Way of seeking the Dao. If you maintain vigilance on this day, all the more will goodness accrue. At the outset of receiving the Cavern Secrets, you should consistently cultivate this practice, holding it firmly in mind.

Should you encounter ill dreams, they may arise from three causes: first, the mischief of the *po* souls; second, the testing of the heart; third, the predations of the corpse-demons. To dispel them, upon awakening, press the philtrum with your left hand thirty-four times, and gnash your teeth thirty-four times. Then softly intone:

*"Great Cavern of the True and Mysterious,
Refine and forge the Three Hun Souls:
The First Hun swiftly guards the Seven Po,
The Second Hun swiftly guards the Mud-Pill Palace,
The Third Hun receives the heart’s command.
Swiftly invoke the Supreme Lords of the Three Origins.
I have encountered an inauspicious dream—
The Seven Po and the wandering corpse
Have conspired with the source of myriad evils.
Hasten to summon Peach-Kang, Guardian of Life,
To report above to the Imperial Lord.
The Five Elders and Nine Perfected
All stand guard at the gates of the body.
The Yellow Chamber’s Divine Masters,
The Purple Gate Generals,
Wielding halberds and shaking bells,
Dispel and extinguish the malign influences.
Turn misfortune to fortune,
Severing all ties to life and death."*

Conclude. If you lie down again, you will assuredly receive an auspicious response. As for the baleful *qi* of ill dreams, it will be sealed beneath the Three Passes. After three years, only spiritually resonant dreams will manifest, and all dreams will become clear reflections of future events, utterly free from inauspicious omens or ill portents.

*(The character for "evil" [恶] as written by the Chief Scribe places* xin *beneath* you*. Its meaning is akin to* xin *beneath* xi*, signifying the harsh and malevolent heart of Metal in the West.)*

If you encounter an auspicious dream in the night—a good dream that your heart deems favorable—this is a sign of blessed resonance. Upon awakening, rub your eyes thirty-four times and gnash your teeth thirty-four times. Then softly intone:

*"Supreme High Essence,
Three Emperors of Cinnabar Spirit,
The Crimson Palace shines with clarity,
Blessed resonance conveys its message.
The Three Origins’ gentle *po* souls,
The Heavenly Sovereign bestows the scriptures.
All endeavors harmonize,
Ascending as flying immortals to the Upper Clarity,
Ever in the company of Jade Perfected,
Together assembling in the Purple Court."*

Conclude. These are the secret formulas of the Great Cavern, transmitted to those who first cross its currents.

*(These three matters also pertain to the affairs of the Cavern Chamber and Great Cinnabar school. The true scriptures have not yet been revealed to the world. The texts circulating in the present age merely touch upon these matters, with many additions and omissions.)*

The hun and po souls are refined and tempered, the six bowels harmonized and at peace—this is the Dao of longevity and deathlessness. 〔 〕〔 〕. The apparition soared before the palace hall, filling the Emperor with joy. He inquired throughout the court, and the learned scholar Fu Yi replied: "Your servant has heard that in the land of Tianzhu there is one who has attained the Dao, known as the Buddha. I have heard he can fly through the air and his body emits a radiant light—this must be the divine being from your dream." The Emperor then understood. He dispatched envoys—Zhang Qian, the Feathered Forest Captain Qin Jing, Academician Wang Zun, and eleven others—to the Great Yuezhi Kingdom to procure and transcribe the *Forty-Two Chapters of the Buddha’s Sutra*, which were later stored in the fourteenth chamber of the Orchid Terrace’s stone repository. At once, he ordered a Buddhist temple built north of the road outside the western gate of Luoyang. He also commissioned a Buddha statue and a depiction of Hariti at the Cool Terrace of the Southern Palace. The Emperor was deeply moved, and even before constructing his own mausoleum, he had a Buddha image installed in the palace hall. At that time, the realm prospered and the people lived in peace; distant barbarians, admiring the transformation, willingly submitted as vassals. The arrival of Buddhist images in China thus began in the reign of Emperor Ming.

*(This account roughly aligns with external records, though it appears Buddhism had already been present in Chang’an for some time—Pei Jun’s case being one such instance. Moreover, the Dharma originated in Tianzhu and Gandhāra, not the Yuezhi lands, which sets this account apart.)*

chunks.translated_text:
Now, desiring to speak of the various minor *fangzhu* where the Buddha is revered, it is fitting first to recount these matters.

According to records, the Zhang Qian mentioned here was not the one from the Former Han—perhaps only their names coincided. Fu Yi, styled Zhongwu, is attested in the *Book of Han*. The Qin princes Jing and Zun are obscure. This temple is called the White Horse Temple. Emperor Ming was later interred at the Mausoleum of Manifest Virtue; what is called here the "Longevity Mausoleum" refers to the practice of Han emperors, who, while still reigning, prepared their tombs in advance—much as people today construct their own burial mounds—rather than naming an actual mausoleum. External records also state that the court dispatched Attendant Gentleman Zhang Kan (or, as some say, Gentleman of the Palace Zhang [Xin]) to Tianzhu to copy and bring back scriptures and images, along with śramaṇas. Yet even this account may not reflect the true transmission, for it likely derives from the old notes of Master Yang. Nevertheless, in the authentic scriptures and pronouncements, references to Buddhist matters appear frequently.

The *fangzhu* are aligned with the four directions, hence their name. Each face measures one thousand three hundred *li*, and the four faces together span five thousand two hundred *li*. Its height reaches nine thousand *zhang*. There stands the Ever-Bright Mount Tai, and the Moonlit Mound, each encircling four hundred *li*. The minor mountains and rivers resemble those of our world, yet their grasses and trees flourish more luxuriantly, and their blossoms and fruits are more resplendent. The herb of immortality abounds, as do springs of sweet water; those who partake of them do not die.

The Palace of the Azure Lord is situated atop the Eastern Florescence Mountain, covering two hundred *li* in extent—entirely the abode of celestial immortals and highest perfected beings. Its halls and chambers are wrought of gold, jade, and luminous jasper. There is also the Dark and Frigid Mountain, upon which stands a separate outer palace, its structures spanning two hundred *li*. To the east and west of the great *fangzhu* lie smaller *fangzhu*, each three thousand *li* distant. These minor *fangzhu* also measure three hundred *li* on each side, encircling one thousand two hundred *li*, and each possesses its own Palace of the Azure Lord.

Moreover, they teem with middle-ranking immortals, numinous birds, and sacred beasts. The great *fangzhu* lies opposite the southeast of Kuaiji, yet from the shore of Kuaiji it appears seventy thousand *li* away. Gazing northeast, one sees the Scalding Vale and the Land of the Fusang Tree, which are another sixty thousand *li* distant from the *fangzhu*. (The *fangzhu* is the *yi* region, the Scalding Vale the *jia* region; thus from *yin* to *chen* spans ten thousand *li*. The five corners and seven directions are spoken of in terms of diagonal angles, totaling fourteen thousand *li*—hence the seventy thousand *li* from Kuaiji.)

To the west of the great *fangzhu*, atop the minor *fangzhu*, many follow the Dao of the Buddha.

Amidst these lands stand pagodas, intricately carved from gold and jade. Some rise a hundred *zhang* in height, their towers numbering in the dozens. Those who dwell above are all filial and deathless, for they partake of the deathless herb. They ingest the essence of the Five Stars and study the *Xia Gui Zang Jing*, employing its methods to traverse the skies. (Note: The *Xia* canon is called *Lian Shan*, the *Yin* canon *Gui Zang*—this differs from the present text. Though they follow the Buddha’s Way, they do not adopt the form or robes of *bhikṣus*. The world calls them the true household of bodhisattvas.)

To the east of the great *fangzhu*, atop the minor *fangzhu*, lie many rare and numinous treasures. There is white jade wine infused with golden nectar, and the Azure Lord stores celestial treasures here in abundance. Many immortals also dwell here, partaking of the deathless herb and drinking this wine. Their bodies take on the luster of gold and jade. They often play the Nine Numinous Flutes for their own delight. The sound of the flute carries forty *li*, its thirty holes carved into bamboo two or three *chi* long. When the nine flutes play in unison, the hundred beasts dance, and dozens of phoenixes arrive to harmonize with the melody.

The Palace of the Great *Fangzhu* is the Azure Lord’s constant abode. Those who dwell above are celestial perfected ones and lofty immortals, where the lords of the Grand Ultimate, the ducal ministers, and the various Directors of Destinies reside. Some practice the method of ingesting the rays of the sun and moon. Though they have already attained the Dao and become perfected, they continue this practice. (Mount Huo and Red City are also bureaus of the Directors of Destinies. Only the Grand Prime Perfected, the Lady of the Southern Marchmount, resides there. Li Zhongfu is in the West, Han Zhong in the South, and the remaining thirty-one Directors of Destinies are all in the Eastern Flower Capital. The Azure Lad serves as the Grand Director of Destinies, overseeing all. Master Yang also states: the Eastern Dipper’s attendant—it is unclear which rank he holds.)

Direct your attention inward and visualize a symbol within the heart, as large as a coin, glowing red. Then visualize the sun with nine rays rising from the heart, ascending through the throat to the teeth, where the rays linger before returning to the stomach. After a long while, with eyes closed, clearly perceive the heart and stomach, then exhale and rinse the mouth with saliva thirty-nine times before stopping. Perform this thrice daily. After a year of practice, illnesses will vanish. After five years, the body will radiate light. After eighteen years, one will surely attain the Dao, casting no shadow at noon, repelling a hundred ghosts and a thousand malign influences. Constantly visualize the sun within the heart and the moon within the Mud Pill Palace. At night, ingest the moon’s essence as you do the sun’s. Visualize the moon’s ten white rays descending from the brain into the throat, where the rays do not pass the teeth but return to the stomach.

This is the method of the perfected ones of *Fangzhu*, recorded in the *Sutra of Great Wisdom*, upper and middle chapters. Those who practice it steadfastly will witness the Great Peace. (This likely corresponds to the seventh section of the *Seven Chapters of Wisdom for Dispelling Demons*.)

The above was imparted by the Lady of the Southern Culmen. Practicing the Way of the sun in the heart and the moon in the Mud Pill Palace is said to be simple and easily grasped. Those who persist without interruption will expel the Three Corpses from the body, cure a hundred illnesses and a thousand afflictions, and master the Way of refining the hun and restraining the po. When the sun and moon perpetually illuminate the body, ghosts will have no place to hide. The Azure Lord still practices this method. I am one such practitioner and now reveal it to you. You may discreetly share it with those of sincere intent.

Practicing this Way does not hinder the methods of ingesting the sun and moon as prescribed in the precious scriptures; combining them is even better. Immortals accomplish a thousand tasks in a single day and night without feeling weary. How diligently they cultivate the Dao! Life must not be squandered.

(The "precious scriptures’ sun and moon" refer to those used in the Purple Texts.)

The above was imparted by the Lord of Western City. (This was also told to Master Yang, who was instructed to share it with the various Xu.)

To pursue the Dao is like shooting an arrow: one must aim straight and not waver to hit the target. Enter the mountains with unwavering resolve, and you will attain the true Perfection.

So instructed the Mysterious Clarity. (Note: The two lofty perfected ones, Mysterious Clarity of the Southern Culmen and Western City, should not have further revelations. Only one precept and one poem each remain. It is unclear when this teaching was imparted.)

The above eight passages are from Yang’s writings. Practicing these four Ways, according to the superior methods of the Jade Mystery, will astonish the senses within a year. One may then diligently pursue them without doubt.

(The Central Lord’s records on this matter lack the preceding pages, so the exact method is unknown.)

So says the Perfected One of the Grand Ultimate.

Reading the *Daodejing*’s five thousand characters ten thousand times will summon the cloud chariot to receive you. If after completing ten thousand recitations it has not yet arrived, read it twice a month. You must depart only when the cloud chariot comes.

The above two passages are from a certain master’s writings.

Shanshi Yuan received the method from Master Meng: at dusk, first recite the *Huangting Neijing* once before sleep, so that one’s hun and po may be naturally refined. Practicing this for twenty-one years will also lead to immortality—this is equivalent to ten thousand recitations. Reciting three or four times each evening is excellent.

The Lady of Northern Peak, Jiang, said: "Reading this sutra also keeps one free from illness. It is the Way of not dying." (This [second] method of twenty-one years, one recitation per evening, does not amount to ten thousand recitations. Perhaps "one" should be "seven" or "eight." Such is the Sun’s power, the might of its spirit.

Abandon its Way,

chunks.translated_text:
When one’s dwelling nearly adjoins a burial mound—
the northeast of a grave is called *Zhengjueming*,
the northwest is called *Jiuhu Yi*—
these are both inauspicious sites for tomb litigation.
Should one encounter the deceased therein, the omen is all the more certain.
For those who frequently have such dreams:
upon waking, face upward, tap the teeth three times, and recite this incantation:

“Supreme Primordial, Lofty Mysterious,
Nine Capitals’ Purple Heaven,
Order the soul, guard the life,
Exalted Plain Perfected One.
I bear the supreme method,
receive the teaching of the Great Mysterious.
Long life and enduring vision,
spirit soars, body transcends.
Tombs and graves forever at peace,
ghostly litigation and treachery blocked.
Soul and spirit harmonious and joyful,
malign qi dispelled without trace.
Wandering specters and formless apparitions—
dare they offend my spirit?
The Northern Emperor rebukes and restrains,
draws the qi into the abyss.
Attaining the *Zhulu* of the Supreme August,
reverently memorializing Jade Dawn.”

Recite this twice, then tap the teeth three more times,
and one will no longer dream of burial mounds or the ghosts of deceased kin.
This is the Northern Emperor’s secret incantation.
Those of sincere and virtuous intent may all practice it.
For those who frequently suffer inauspicious or ominous dreams,
this method may be applied—
thus ghostly qi is extinguished,
and demonic spirits scatter and dissolve.

*(This should be transmitted only to those under the authority of the Chief Clerk. Only those of the Xu surname and the *yu* tone are permitted. Now it is said that the northeast is *Zhengjueming*—this differs from other accounts. Moreover, the name *Jiuhu Yi* does not appear in the *Tomb Manuals*.)*
For cases where the arms fail to respond...

chunks.translated_text:
When qi of deep-wind toxin lingers within the vessels,
binding and clinging to the bones, causing numbness—
acupuncture and moxibustion are fitting.
With acupuncture and moxibustion, the ailment is cured.
Moreover, one should apply the Northern Emperor’s Incantation of the Crooked and the Winding.
If performed a hundred times, the illness will also dissipate.

First, slowly press and massage the arm with one hand.
After a long while, when finished, close the eyes and turn the gaze inward.
Swallow saliva three times, tap the teeth three rounds,
and with a composed mind, softly intone:

“Supreme Four Mysteries,
Five Flowers and Six Courts,
Three Hun and Seven Po,
Celestial Pass and Earthly Essence,
Divine Talismans and Guarding Spirits,
Heavenly Embryo and Radiant Above,
Four Limbs and Hundred Spirits,
Nine Joints and Myriad Numina—
receive the register from Jade Dawn,
inscribe the scripture in Jade City.
Jade maidens attend the body,
Jade lads protect the life.
Forever aligned with the Two Luminaries,
ascend as a flying immortal to the Upper Clarity,
long abiding with the sun and moon,
years extending into the distant future.
Transcend and rise as an immortal,
attain the Great Peace.

Flowing wind congeals into sickness,
injected ghosts take flight in five directions.
Specters and tomb-qi,
yin-qi swirling about—
they encroach upon my four limbs,
disrupt my flourishing and decline.
Supreme Heavenly Ding,
Dragon and Tiger radiate might,
slaying inauspicious ghosts,
shattering wind and demonic influences.
Examine and expose hidden grievances,
concealed poisons and wrongs—
restore me to my ordinary state,
sun and moon shining together.
If examined and found in violation,
the Northern Asterism will seize and crush.
Should any dare to test,
they shall face the majesty of the Radiant Above.”

When finished—
*(This too should be reported to the Chief Clerk. The Chief Clerk suffers from frequent nightmares, constantly afflicted by tomb-injections, and also plagued by drinking accumulations and numbness in both hands. Thus, he is often taught these methods, with acupuncture and moxibustion to follow.)*

If a disciple is sincere,
press and massage the afflicted area,
applying this method.
However, do not require closing the eyes and turning the gaze inward—
only swallowing saliva and tapping the teeth.

In former times, a man named Tang Lan,
dwelling in the forests of Linlü Mountain,
was struck by a ghost,
his entire body unresponsive,
as if wrapped in cotton.
A Daoist taught him this method of pressing and massaging,
and the ailment was immediately dispelled.

This is the Northern Emperor’s Method of the Crooked and the Winding.
For all illnesses involving crookedness or winding,
applying this method is most effective—
not merely for wind-numbness or unresponsiveness.
*(Tang Lan’s origins are unknown; it is unclear from which era he came.)*

The Northern Emperor possesses these several methods, which are also employed among the schools of the lofty immortals. There is also the *Scripture of the Crooked and the Winding*, stored in the residence of the Western Duke of Clarity. (King Wen of Zhou was the Western Duke of Clarity.) Zheng Zizhen was the grandson of Zheng Kangcheng. He now resides on Yangzhuo Mountain. In his early studies, he suffered for years from unresponsiveness in both legs. In his later years, he used acupuncture and moxibustion, combined with the incantatory method of the Crooked and the Winding, and within a hundred days, all ailments were dispelled. (Zheng Xuan had only one son, who was killed by bandits. He had a posthumous son named Xiaotong. This son neither entered the mountains nor suffered from leg ailments. This Zizhen is also not the one from Gu Valley—his comings and goings are contradictory, and no reliable evidence can be discerned.)

Tang Lan now resides on Mount Hua. He obtained the *Method of the Rainbow Elixir* and, having compounded and ingested it, attained immortality. (From the preceding passage to this point, all should be considered *Instructions for Preserving Life*.) Thirteen rounds of acupuncture and three rounds of moxibustion cure all ailments. The left hand surpasses the right. The meridian of the Lesser Yang winds within the left elbow, so thirteen rounds of acupuncture are appropriate to regulate the internal meridian and enter the Lesser Yang. Moxibustion warms the qi, causing it to float upward; when the arm’s blood is afflicted by wind-numbness, three rounds of moxibustion are appropriate to supplement and stabilize the flow of fluids, ensuring the sinews remain unobstructed. Moxibustion should be applied to the *Youguan* of the hand, the *Fengxian*, and the *Five Streams*—these three locations are critically important. One must await an auspicious day.

I now part ways to instruct you separately, ensuring you do not lose this method. When the body is deficient and contracted, illness invades. If you have now recovered, and can truly reduce strenuous activity, the wind-affliction will surely be dispelled. I shall now regulate the qi of the tomb’s inscriptions for you. Since you are slightly improved, you may also ascend the tomb to present your memorial. I will submit it through the proper channels, and thus the inscribed qi will be cut off.

In former times, a man from Dengyi Cloud Mountain had attained the Dao but suddenly refused to transmit his teachings to either hand. I sent someone to instruct him to apply moxibustion to the Fenghuai and Qujin points. Within six or seven days, he could perform the Five Animals’ Frolics. Once the effects of acupuncture are complete, you should focus on the moxibustion sites. Moreover, meditating on the practice of the Dao is no different from physically performing it.

Long ago, Lord Zhao Cheng’s legs were so debilitated he could not rise. Morning and night, he constantly meditated on bowing to the Supreme. After thirty years, a Perfected One of the Supreme bestowed upon him a dose of Flowing Brightness Sandalwood Elixir. Immediately, he could stand and walk, and later attained the Dao.

Here at the foot of Huming Mountain, when engaging in meditative bowing or mentally practicing the Dao, one should burn incense on both sides, as if preparing to perform a ritual. When lying awake at night, visualize the solar image in your right hand, grasping it so that the sun’s crimson radiance ascends from your arm to the elbow and armpit. After a long while, the solar rays suddenly transform into fire, burning through the arm until it is completely permeated inside and out. Then silently recite:

*"O Radiant Upper Prime of the Four Luminaries,
At the division of solar and lunar qi,
Flowing light shines resplendent,
Infusing fluid to congeal the hun-soul.
Divine radiance scatters its brilliance,
Sweeping away filth and refining mist.
Pervading wind and qi,
All hundred evils are incinerated.
Grant me long life,
With limbs whole and sound.
Let the harm-inflicting dead be bound
And delivered to the Northern Asterism."*

After reciting, meditate for a long while, then release the body and forget the self. [This is *Preserving Life*’s account of the secret incantation for dispelling demons.]

*(This scripture has not yet been revealed to the world. If it is indeed part of the *Sevenfold Wisdom* restricted texts, it is unclear how the Young Lord could have seen it.)*

The above eight clauses were transcribed by the clerk. Yesterday, I presented the tomb matter to inquire of Lord Xun. Fan Youchong, a Han-era Gentleman of the Imperial Secretariat, was skilled in geomancy. He devoted himself to the study of tombs and dwellings. By the end of the Wei dynasty, his teachings had spread to this region during the reign of Emperor Tong. He stated: *"My present tomb holds the Green Dragon’s commanding qi. He constantly practiced the method of absorbing and drawing in the twin luminaries and ingesting the auroral mists for over forty years, yet perceived no benefit. His son, however, followed the same practice for eighteen years and ascended to heaven in broad daylight. Later, the Perfected of Southern Marchmount suddenly descended to instruct Zhongfu, saying: "The reason you have not attained ascension is that your body harbors grave illness—your brain palace is depleted, sinews lack fluid infusion, and your numinous essences remain unsurging. Though you have connected with the luminaries and ingested auroral mists, it has brought no true benefit to your body." Thereupon, Zhongfu began to take medicinals to treat his illness while continuing his practice. After another eighteen years, he too ascended to heaven in broad daylight. Now he resides in the Dark Realm, where he received scriptures and was appointed Perfected of Central Marchmount, presiding over the Nine Mysteries’ bureau—a post he still holds today. (This account closely aligns with essential matters. No further distinction is made between Zhongfu and his son.)

The student of the Dao must first pacify the heart and nurture the spirit, ingesting medicinals to treat illness so that the brain palace is filled to fullness and the primordial essence remains unspilled. Only then may one preserve the spirit and ingest auroral mists, drawing in and exhaling the twin luminaries. If one frequently engages in sexual congress, leaking and discharging essence, then qi becomes foul, the spirit flees, and the numinous essence withers to exhaustion. Even if one were to receive the Dark Stave, Jade Records, Golden Scriptures, or the Great Ultimate, how could one escape the bonds of non-life?

Of old, former masters often warned of this matter, saying: "For the student of the Dao, one act of congress dissipates a year’s medicinal potency; two acts dissipate two years’ potency. Beyond three, the medicinal potency thus dissipated is entirely lost from the body." Therefore, the perfected and transcendent ones ever guard against this, regarding it as the greatest taboo against the continuity of life. (This principle accords perfectly with the purport of all scriptures.)

In the study of the Dao, one must silently nurture the spirit, drawing qi to its utmost and exhaling it gently. One must not speak loudly or shout, lest the spirit and qi become labored and impaired. Those who practice thus do not cultivate life.

For all who preserve the radiance of the spirit and engage in the affairs of the perfected transcendent ones, they must not lend their clothing to others, nor wear garments not their own. All items such as headscarves, coarse robes, shoes, and clogs should be kept fresh and abundant, for the three hun and seven po may dwell within them, and these are also taboos for the five spirits, as dampness and defilement must be avoided.

On the eight seasonal nodes, one should observe fasting and solemnity, devising good deeds to advance the methods of the Dao. Beware of anger, contention, joy, or wrath on these days, and do not impose punishments or authority, for these are grave transgressions and great taboos in the eyes of heaven and humanity. These three principles also accord with the purport of the scriptures.

For all who delve into the profound Dao or recite sacred scriptures, after every ten or twenty words, one should once or twice lick the lips and swallow the saliva. After every hundred or fifty words, one should two or three times click the teeth to summon the spirit and harmonize the blood and qi, allowing the numinous fluid to congeal and fill, so that the Imperial Unity may rejoice in its abode. This is what is meant by "the qi of the center is not labored, the blood’s inception is not leaked." (This is a separate method not found in the scriptures.)

The method for students: one must not weep tears or spit excessively, for these actions deplete the fluids and leak the essences, causing the throat and brain to become greatly exhausted. On the days of *jiǎ-yín* and *gēng-shēn*, when corpse-ghosts vie to disrupt the spirit and stir defilement, one must not share a mat with a spouse nor engage in face-to-face conversation. Instead, maintain purity, remain awake, and guard against these days, dispelling all desires.

On one’s own life-day, face the corresponding direction, click the teeth three times, and with the heart, bow twice while softly reciting the incantation:

Triple Union of the true.
Chamber of the womb, supreme radiance,
Mother mysterious, Father primordial.
You give birth to my five viscera,
Gather my spirit and essence.

Command spirits and employ the divine.

All methods of Shangqing teeth-tapping and saliva-swallowing follow specific procedures, with a fixed sequence of prior and subsequent steps. They must not be practiced in a disordered or mixed manner, lest the true spirits become confused. Tapping the teeth summons the spirits of destiny; swallowing harmonizes the true. Harmony is received and circulated through the Six Fluids. To govern the spirits, one must sound the drum and proceed in orderly ranks.

On the sixth day of the ninth month and the third day of the twelfth month, one must enter seclusion and avoid all contact with women. If the Six Corpses stir in chaos, the stored blood will be disturbed, scattering and dispersing. The Three Hun will lose their guard, the spirit will wither, and the qi will depart—accumulating until death follows. The reason these days are taboo is not merely to restrain licentiousness or prevent the loss of fluids. It is to pacify the Female Palace, which resides in *shen* (the ninth earthly branch), while the Male Palace resides in *yin* (the third earthly branch). *Yin* and *shen* clash in mutual punishment, and this punitive force intensifies. On these days, the male and female Three Corpses emerge within the pupils of the eyes: the female corpse beckons the male, and the male corpse beckons the female. Disaster and harm flow between them, depleting the spirit and corrupting the true. Though one may not perceive it, the form is already damaged—blood flows from the *Niwan* Palace as the Three Corpses wage war within the eyes. On these days, even the most beloved of women or the most cherished of wives must not be faced. My former master attained immortality solely by cultivating this Dao, without extending exceptions even to the closest kin who might be without intent. You must be vigilant in this.

---

The *Zhen’gao*, Scroll Ten and Scroll Eleven, and *Jishen Shu*, First Chapter, state: The region of Jinling is the rich marrow of the Cavernous Void, the earthly lung of Juqu. Countless tread its soil, yet none comprehend it.

(These words were orally transmitted by the Lord of Life-Preservation. According to oral tradition, this should have been recorded before the sixth month of the *yichou* year, during the *jiazi* era, when the discussion of this mountain’s blessed origins began. Its soil is fertile, hence called "rich marrow." When waters rise, it floats, hence called "earthly lung." Though generations have traversed it, none have known its true location.)

The source of Mount Juqu curves to embrace, thus it is named the Village of Juqu. It lies one hundred and fifty *li* across the river; seek, and you shall find it.

(All passages hereafter in large purple script are records from the transmissions of the Three Lords Mao. As these transmissions are treasured and closely guarded, few have seen them. Here, I have carefully transcribed the accounts of the mountain to corroborate and clarify. The mountain’s form bends and winds, extending east and west in meandering turns, hence the name Juqu. The mountain’s ridgeline divides its boundaries: west and north belong to Jurong County, while east and south belong to Yanling. Since Jurong was established as a county, its village no longer exists. In ancient times, it likely lay near Shuxu. Today, the mountain is one hundred and fifty to sixty *li* from the Jiang River at Stone Gate, measured by footpath.)

East of the Jiang River, amidst the small marshes near Jinling, lies Mount Juqu.

(Here, Jinling refers to Moling, not the "earthly lung" of Jinling. The small marsh is today’s Chishan Lake. Gazing directly from the Jiang River toward the mountain, its position aligns east and west as described.)

This mountain is a cavernous void of inner vision, containing a numinous abode. Its grottoes open in four directions, its caves and peaks stretch long and unbroken. The ancients called it the Void Terrace of Jintan, the Convenient Chamber of the Queen Mother, the Eastern Window of Qingxu, and the Secluded Depths of Linwu. Its caverns interconnect, forming yin paths that lead in all directions—seven routes, nine springs, and four crossroads—making it a true cavern-palace of the immortals.

(This describes the interconnectedness of the grotto-heavens. The Queen Mother resides in the Linwu Grotto beneath Baoshan in Taihu, where the Dragon Might Elder entered and obtained the Five Talismans of Lingbao. Qingxu is the name of the Wangwu Grotto-heaven, indicating that Huayang is linked to this site.)

The mountain’s shape resembles the character *si* (巳), hence its name, Juqu.

(Today, standing atop the Xuan Ridge of Middle Mao Peak, one gazes before and behind at the ranges and ridges. They coil and curve, with Great Mao as the head, winding east, then north, then west, then north again, then east-northeast to the Great Transverse, folding back and forth like the leftward-written character *si*.)

Jinling cannot be harmed by war or flood, nor afflicted by plague or disaster. The *Yellow River Chart*, *Zhong Yao Yuan* Chapter, Scroll Forty-Four, states: "The altar of Jujin contains a mound where neither war nor sickness treads, nor do surging waves ascend." This is the very blessed land. If your heart awakens to this, it is your fortune. Yet know: from whom did this awakening arise?

(This *Yellow River Chart* was received by Shun and Yu, along with the *Luo Book* and its kind. Over forty scrolls remain today. These words were also meant for the Director of Records, signifying that his enlightenment came from the teachings of Lord Yang, which I have further expounded.)

Within Mount Juqu lies the land of Jinling, spanning thirty-seven or thirty-eight *qing*. This is the earthly lung of Jinling. Its soil is fertile, its well water sweet and pure. To dwell here is to attain transcendence and witness the Great Peace. The *Yellow River Chart’s Inner Yuan Classic* states: "The earthly lung has good soil and clear water. The mountain of Juqu, the mound of Jintan—here one may transcend the world and ascend to the Curved City." The *Yellow River Book’s Middle Chapter* also says: "The mountain of Jujin contains a mound where neither war nor sickness treads, nor do surging waves ascend." This is the meaning.

(The *Yellow River Chart* mentioned later refers to the same passage from the *Zhong Yao Yuan* Chapter. Though the characters for "mountain" and "altar" differ, the principle remains the same. This specifically describes the earthly lung of Jinling—a single tract of land with such properties. Other places may not share these exemptions.)

Jinling was anciently called the Land of Crouching Dragons. The *Yellow River Chart* examines the inverse, and thus records the turning of the kalpas.

chunks.original_text: 方来之定名耳。 至于金陵之号。 已二百余年矣。 （寻金陵之号。 起自楚时。 至秦皇过江厌气。 乃改为秣陵。 汉来县旧治小丹阳。 今犹呼为故治也。 晋太康三年。 割淮水之南属之。 义煕九年。 移治〈阙〉［斗］场。 元煕元年。 徙还今处。 此是江东之金陵耳。 传所言二百余年者。 是吴孙权使人采金。 屯居伏龙山。 因名金陵。 自然响会。 所以叹河图之逆兆也）句曲山秦时名为句金之坛。 以洞天内有金坛百丈。 因以致名也。 外又有积金山。 亦因积金为坛号矣。 周时名其源泽为曲水之穴。 按山形曲折。 后人合为句曲之山。 汉有三茅君。 来治其上。 时父老又转名茅君之山。 三君往曾各乘一白鹄。 各集山之三处。 时人互有见者。 是以发于歌谣。 乃复因鹄集之处。 分句曲之山为大茅君中茅君小茅君三山焉。 总而言之。 尽是句曲之一山耳。 无异名也。 三茅山隐｛山连｝相属。 皆句曲山一名耳。 时人因事而谕。 今故有枝条数十作别名。 旧不尔也。 （今以在南最高者为大茅山。 中央有三峰。 连岑鼎立。 以近后最高者为中茅山。 近北一岑孤峰。 上有聚石者为小茅山。 大茅中茅间名长阿。 东出通延陵句曲。 阿西出通句容湖。 就以为连石。 积金山。 马岭相带。 状如｛土棣｝形。 其中茅小茅间名小阿。 东西出亦如此。 有一小马岭相连。 自小茅山后去。 便有雷平燕口方嵎大横良常诸山。 靡｛进也｝相属。 垂至破｛网正｝涜。 自大茅南复有韮山竹吴山方山。 从此迭障。 达于吴兴诸山。 至于罗浮。 穷于南海也）山生黄金。 汉灵帝时。 诏敕郡县。

The designation "to come" is but a provisional name. As for the name "Jinling," it has already endured for over two hundred years. (Tracing the name "Jinling," it originated in the time of Chu. When the First Emperor of Qin crossed the river, he found the qi oppressive and thus renamed it Moling. Since the Han dynasty, the old county seat lay at Small Danyang, still called the "former seat" today. In the third year of Taikang of Jin, the lands south of the Huai River were apportioned to it. In the ninth year of Yixi, the seat was moved to 〈missing〉 [Dou]chang. In the first year of Yuanxi, it was relocated to its present site. This is the Jinling east of the river. The "over two hundred years" mentioned in tradition refers to when Sun Quan of Wu sent men to mine gold and encamped at Crouching Dragon Mountain, whence the name "Jinling" arose—a natural resonance. Thus does one marvel at the *Yellow River Chart*’s inverse omen.)

In Qin times, Juqu Mountain was called the Altar of Jugold, for within its grotto-heaven stood a hundred-zhang gold altar, whence the name derived. Beyond it lay Mount Jijin, likewise named for its accumulated gold altars. In Zhou times, its source and marsh were called the Cavern of Curved Waters. Observing the mountain’s sinuous form, later generations combined the names into Juqu Mountain. In the Han, the Three Mao Lords came to govern there, and the elders renamed it the Mountain of the Mao Lords. The Three Lords once each rode a white crane, alighting in three separate places on the mountain, seen by many at the time. Thus arose folk songs, and the mountain was further divided into the Three Mountains of the Great, Middle, and Lesser Mao Lords, corresponding to the cranes’ perches. In sum, all remain but a single mountain—Juqu—without other names. The Three Mao Mountains, though linked in sequence, are but one name: Juqu. Later generations, interpreting events, have since branched it into dozens of alternate names, though originally it was not so. (Today, the southernmost and highest is called Great Mao Mountain, its central ridge crowned by three peaks standing like tripods. The next highest, nearer the rear, is Middle Mao Mountain. To the north, a solitary peak with clustered rocks is Lesser Mao Mountain. Between Great and Middle Mao lies Chang’e, its eastern extension reaching Yanling and Juqu, its western leading to Jurong Lake, forming a continuous stone ridge. Mount Jijin and Horse Ridge encircle it like a rampart. Between Middle and Lesser Mao lies Xiao’e, its eastern and western extensions mirroring the same pattern, linked by a small Horse Ridge. Beyond Lesser Mao Mountain’s rear stretch Lei Ping, Swallow’s Beak, Square Peak, Great Horizontal, and Constant Mountain, all connected in unbroken succession, descending to Po[net] Du. South of Great Mao lie Scallion Mountain, Bamboo Wu Mountain, Square Mountain, and beyond them, a chain of ridges reaching to the mountains of Wuxing, extending to Luofu and ending at the Southern Sea.)

The mountain yields gold. In the reign of Emperor Ling of Han, an imperial edict commanded the commanderies and counties [to mine it].

chunks.original_text: 采句曲之金。 以充武库。 逮孙权时。 又遣宿卫人采金常输官。 兵帅百家。 遂屯居伏龙之地。 因改为金陵之墟名也。 河图已得之于昔。 可谓绝妙。 （今大茅山南犹有数深坑大坎。 相传呼之为金井。 当是孙权时所凿掘也。 今此山近东诸处。 碎石往往皆有金砂云。 兵帅仍屯居伏龙。 今则无复有。 唯小近西有述墟。 昔乃名朮墟。 今是良民。 述墟前十数里。 大茅有吴墟村。 以号而言。 乃欲相似。 而复不关金陵。 长史宅西北。 近长隐小冈下。 乃时有故破瓦器。 焦赤土甚多。 疑是人居处。 既经耕垦。 基域不复存而了无井。 亦恐如长史井堙没耳。 又小茅大横不见采金处。 大茅金井。 若是复不应顿如此远居。 二三疑昧）金陵之土。 似北｛亡邑｝及北谷关。 土坚实而宜禾谷。 掘其间作井。 正似长安凤门外井水味。 是清源幽澜。 洞泉远沽耳。 水色白。 都不学道。 居其土。 饮其水。
chunks.translated_text:
The gold from Juqu was mined to replenish the imperial armory. By the time of Sun Quan, he again dispatched palace guards to extract gold and regularly deliver it to the authorities. A military commander led a hundred households to garrison and settle the land of Fulong, which was then renamed Jinling. As the *Hetu* foretold in ancient times, it was indeed most wondrous.

(To this day, south of Great Mao Mountain, several deep pits and large hollows remain, traditionally called "Gold Wells," said to have been excavated during Sun Quan’s reign. In the eastern foothills of this mountain, fragments of stone often contain grains of gold. The military commander and his garrison once settled in Fulong, but no trace remains today. Only to the west lies Shuxu, formerly known as Zhuxu, now inhabited by common folk. Some ten *li* ahead of Shuxu, near Great Mao, stands Wu Xu Village, whose name appears similar but bears no connection to Jinling. Northwest of the Prefect’s residence, near the small ridge of Changyin, broken shards of pottery and scorched red earth are frequently found, suggesting former habitation. Though the land has been cultivated and no foundations remain, nor any wells, it may be that the Prefect’s well, too, has long since been buried. Neither Lesser Mao nor Great Horizontal show signs of gold mining, and the Gold Wells of Great Mao seem too distant to be the same site—these matters remain uncertain.)

The soil of Jinling resembles that of Bei[lost city] and the northern valley passes: firm and fertile, well-suited for growing grain. Digging wells here yields water akin to that outside Feng Gate in Chang’an—clear springs with deep, distant sources. The water is white in color.

Those who dwell on this land and drink its water, however, do not pursue the Dao.

The land thus appears clearly—hence it is not obscurely revealed. (The Lord of Life Preservation stated: According to the *Biographies*, the Jinling site spans thirty-seven or thirty-eight *qing*, though this likely refers to its outermost boundaries. As for the verified record, it is indeed just over ten *qing*, with the elevated, level ground being the suitable dwelling place. Ascending the site and surveying it as described, one may readily grasp its contours. One who roughly discerns the location—if they are an immortal transcending the world or one of the seed people—will naturally arrive without hindrance. Yet if unworthy, merely bringing hands to build a dwelling will surely see it fail to stand in any direction, swiftly compelled to relocate. The careless and vulgar multitude must not forcibly claim this place.)

To the left and right of Jinling lie valley streams and mountain sources. On the left of the ridge stands a mountain, while to the right flows a stream named *Muhuhu* Valley. West of the ridge lies a source called Yang Valley. The *Inner Classic of Named Mountains and Records of Blessed Lands* states: "The hidden dragon’s land lies west of Willow Valley and to the right of Jintan, fit for lofty dwelling"—this is precisely the blessed land of Jinling. (Now called Willow Valley, its source emerges from the spring behind the fields of Xiao Mao’s Tian Gong, flowing southwest to the head of Shuxu, where it enters the great [stream]. As for Yang Valley, its name has since vanished, though behind the ridges of Changyin Mountain lies a small [stream], flowing west before turning south, also converging at the head of Shuxu. Elders further say that the source of Yang Valley arises before Zhong Mao and behind Da Mao, where several streams merge into one, exiting the mountain to flow due west before turning north, likewise joining the great [stream]. Where the two [valleys] intersect lies this very site. Its general orientation is east-west, though not perfectly aligned—hence the reference to both left and right. Yet whether today’s two valleys are the same as those of old remains uncertain. Though passed down by elders, transmission has gradually eroded, and the sources’ courses have shifted.)

chunks.translated_text:
(Though no fixed landmark may serve as evidence,) in high antiquity this mountain was called Gang Mountain. The *Record of Confucius’ Blessed Lands* states: “Between the ridges of Gang Mountain lies the Hidden Dragon’s Domain, where one may escape floods, ward off illness, and attain long life.” The reason it was originally named Gang is that its substance resembles that of a golden altar. Thus, though a hundred generations have passed and its name has changed a hundred times, it is no longer called by its original name—truly lamentable.

(According to present accounts, a long and massive mountain northeast of Xiao Mao is called Da Heng Mountain, originally named Yu Gang Mountain. This mountain lies east of what is now called the Hidden Dragon’s Domain. The world also refers to the Hidden Dragon’s land as Dead Serpent Ridge, which roughly corresponds to the old name. Observing its length and increasing height, it is also called Chang Yin. *Yin* is pronounced *yu jin* [隱, rhyming with 觐], meaning “to conceal and shield.” Though this Gang Mountain is strewn with small stones, it remains habitable. From the southeast near the Prefect’s residence to the area around Lei Ping, there are many suitable dwelling places. Jiang Yuanchu of Yixing and others have now established fields and homesteads at the foot of the ridge, roughly four or five *li* from the Prefect’s residence.)

Beyond the Golden Court of Tongbai and the Golden Mound of Wu’s Juqu, it is a blessed realm for nurturing the true and a numinous site for attaining the divine. When the waters of the five Yaos poured eastward into the sea, all people fell ill and died—what could the soldiers of Wu’an do to me? For I dwell near the secluded gate of the Terrace of the Sun, relying on this to wander at ease.

(The above was orally transmitted by the Perfected Lord Wang of the Right Assistant [Wang Zhenren] and secretly shown to Lord Xu. This refers to the lands of Wu and Yue spoken of by the Divine Lord of the Dawn of Tongbai. Of these, only the two golden sites are the most blessed. *Wu’an* refers to the Qin general Bai Qi, who attacked Zhao at Changping and in a single day buried alive four hundred thousand men—no military slaughter in antiquity was more brutal. Hence, it is cited here as an analogy. This is what is meant by “soldiers and plague do not come, and great waves do not ascend.” Since it lies near a grotto-heaven and is guarded by divine immortals, it can ensure that the three disasters do not encroach. The preceding five entries are from Yang’s writings.)

Within the great heavens lie thirty-six grotto-heavens of the earth’s center, the eighth of which is the grotto of Juqu Mountain, encompassing one hundred fifty *li* in circumference. It is named the Golden Altar of Huayang Heaven.

(According to the transmitted records, up to the tenth heaven, these include the five sacred peaks, the eight seas of immortals, and the grottoes of distant barbarian lands. Since these fall outside the present scope, they are not enumerated here.)

The grotto’s walls are entirely of stone on all four sides, above and below. The flat upper area lies beneath the soil, emerging above ground only after thirteen or fourteen *li*.

(This refers to reaching the summit of the great mountain.) It spans forty-five *li* east to west and thirty-five *li* north to south, perfectly square and level. Its hollow interior measures one hundred seventy *zhang* in height, while the lower part is one hundred *zhang*. Below, the land still rises in mounds and recumbent *earth dragons*, while the upper vault is perfectly flat.

(As previously stated, the high part is one hundred seventy *zhang* and the lower part one hundred *zhang*, meaning the center is elevated and the four sides gradually slope downward. The present statement that “the upper vault is perfectly flat” refers to its surface being level without depressions or protrusions, not that it is flat like a board. It may also mean that when one ascends the mounds, one is lower relative to the heavens.)

Within its hollow, there shines a yin radiance by night and the root of the sun’s essence by day, illuminating this empty space so brightly that it rivals the sun and moon. The yin radiance governs the night, and the sun’s essence governs the day. Their forms are round like the sun and moon, flying within the dark void.

(According to the various grotto-heavens, each has these names, though with slight differences. They are likely the sun and moon of the great heavens, their essence divided to shine here. Since they govern day and night, they must rise and set, their brightness and dimness matching the sun and moon of our world. At the edge of the great heavens, one cannot reach the end, but the boundaries of this small heaven may nearly be touched and seen. The rising and setting of its sun and moon must therefore have limits, appearing and vanishing suddenly rather than through any aperture. Yet their size remains unknown.)

The Grotto-Palace of Juqu has five gates: two side gates to the south, side gates to the east and west, and the great northern side gate—altogether five auxiliary gates.

(Today, the great cavern on the mountain’s south side is the western side gate of the southern face. The eastern gate seems to lie within the ridge of cypress branches. The Liangchang Cavern is the great northern side gate, though the eastern and western gates are not apparent. The Middle Lord stated that the eastern side gate lies at the mouth of Small Mao, east of Middle Mao, and that entering here brings one closest to the grotto-heaven, though the outer opening is very small and blocked with stone. Details follow later. Thus, the western side gate should be similarly concealed, likely at the place now called the Stone Tomb. The cypress ridge has two or three cavern mouths, but the true gate may not open there. If one seeks these three gates with pure devotion, they may yet be found. Though the southern side gate’s outer entrance remains wide open, the inner passage is blocked, likely due to excessive defilement. The great northern cavern still sees the comings and goings of spirits and gods, but true immortals do not enter or exit through the five gates—they pass through all barriers as if they were nothing. These gates exist to show the structure of the mountain grotto or perhaps for those from outside who are meant to enter.)

Within the void, stone steps wind outward to meet the gateways, allowing passage up and down. Those who come and go in haste do not realize they are within the grotto-heaven and assume they tread an outer path. Since the light of the sun and moon is no different, and the plants, trees, waters, and marshes are indistinguishable from those outside, with birds flying to and fro and winds and clouds thickly gathering, there is nothing to arouse suspicion.

Such is the divine palace of the grotto-heaven—its numinous wonders boundless, beyond discussion or delusion.

(Those who gather herbs in the world often mistakenly enter such grottoes, where all appears thus, and so they do not find it strange.)

Of late, I have wandered alone with my staff, hoping to record in detail all that I hear and see.

On the eastern side of Middle Mao Mountain lies a small cave. Its mouth is no larger than a dog’s burrow, barely wide enough for a person to enter. Yet the deeper one goes, the more spacious it becomes. A massive boulder seals the entrance, leaving only a small opening the size of a cup, guarded by the mountain spirits. This boulder occasionally opens of its own accord—it is called the Hidden Palace’s Lateral Gate. After purifying myself through fasting, I sought it out and found the way in, easier to traverse than the entrance to the Good-and-Constant Grotto. Within, many sandy paths twist and turn, and where they cross streams, passage is not always smooth. The route is also long, less convenient than the small Lateral Cave’s entrance. Descending straight down for three or four *li*, one arrives directly at the Hidden Palace’s Eastern Mysterious Side Gate. Two hundred paces inside the cave’s mouth, the darkness suddenly gives way to daylight. (This is the grotto-heaven’s eastern gate, its hidden dimensions now discernible. Yet I have not dared to venture in lightly. Earlier accounts claim the cavern palace extends thirteen or fourteen *li* beneath the earth, whereas this passage reaches the Side Gate in only three or four *li*. This is because the entrance lies near the mountain’s base, and the gate itself is not level. One must descend several more *li* after entering to reach the palace proper. The instant brightness within is due to inner light illuminating the space, not sunlight from outside.)

Great Mao Mountain also has a small cave on its southern face, nearly identical to the first. It is called the Southern Convenient Gate, its mouth likewise sealed by stone. However, if one purifies the heart with sincere fasting and directs devotion to the Controller of Fate, ascending the mountain on the second day of the month to extend invitations and offer prayers, one will naturally be granted an audience. If sincerity is absolute, how could the Hidden Palace remain unseen? What manner of man was Zuo Ci? (This is the eastern Convenient Gate on the southern face, likely located among the stone caves of the Cypress-Branch [Stone Dragon]. Many small caves dot this [Stone Dragon], making them difficult to distinguish at a glance. Only through profound spiritual resonance will the way open.)

Those who regularly ascend the mountain on these two days to extend their welcome, offer prayers, and make entreaties—referring specifically to the second day of the twelfth month—rarely observe the eighteenth day of the third month, though it has occasionally fallen in the first month. Nowadays, the second day of the twelfth month is often bitterly cold with snow, and few from near or far come to the mountain. Only on the eighteenth day of the third month do officials and commoners gather in throngs, with hundreds of carriages and four or five thousand people, both Daoists and layfolk, men and women, their numbers resembling the crowds of a bustling city. They ascend the mountain together, chanting the *Lingbao* hymns of praise, and once the rites are concluded, they disperse. How can there be any among them with profound sincerity or secret communion, yearning to behold the divine Perfected? Even if one or two truly devoted souls appear, they are hindered by the clamor and defilement, unable to focus their minds or express their devotion. Thus, those who seek to be drawn near and receive favor have no means of attaining their goal.

Only in the secluded dwellings of the central cliffs, where access is restricted and the years kept pure, can one avoid the mingling of crowds. Since these places lie beyond the grotto and across the ridge, people naturally remain unaware of them.

On the southwestern slope of Mount Liangchang, there are habitable sites—former residences of the Lord Controller of Fate—where one may also compound the elixir. (When the Lord Controller first crossed the river, he established his dwelling here to purify himself and confront spirits and ghosts. Now, the term "slope" [*chui*] suggests a boundary or edge, and this location should properly lie west of the great ridge behind the Director’s residence. Yet elders today claim it is the flatland northwest of Great Mao Peak, among the pear trees of the low-lying area called *Xiabo*, said to be the former abode of the Lord Controller. The soil there is rich from cultivation, and many bricks, tiles, and relics of former habitation are unearthed, confirming it as a place once dwelt in. It is also said that the site is potent and must not be defiled. If this is indeed the case, then it should be described as west of Central Mao Peak, not so far as Liangchang. The statements of the Great Perfected are generally imprecise, mentioning whatever location they happen to cite.)

In former times, the forests and thickets at the foot of the mountain stretched far and wide, obscuring the sky and blocking the sun, offering countless secluded retreats. Now, with logging and farming, the land is open and accessible in all directions, and even the mountains have become exposed. Times change, and circumstances differ—no longer can the past serve as a standard. Yet these claims are not of long ago.
