The above is the Lord of the Register’s reply to the Prefect’s earlier letter, concluding the discussion of matters concerning Mount Juqu. The Prefect’s original letter is no longer extant; only this later response remains, arranged here in order of the topics addressed.

The preceding twenty-one items were all transcribed by clerks. In my youth, around ten years of age, I heard elders in Xuxu (this should be written as *xu* [墟], though it has long been rendered as *xu* [虚]—the name of a village in present-day Shanxi) speak of how Mount Mao was once home to immortals and even had a marketplace, though they had long since departed. Later, when I asked Lord Bao about the mountain’s condition, he replied that the immortals still resided there and had not moved away. This mountain is the western gate of the Dongting Grotto-Heaven, connected to the Baoshan range within Lake Tai, which is why the immortals dwell within it. However, he mentioned only the Middle Immortal Lord by name, making no reference to his three brothers, nor distinguishing their seniority, nor noting that the Lord of Life holds a more exalted rank and governs separately in the Eastern Palace. As no records of this have been seen, it becomes clear that there are distinctions in rank and hierarchy.

I now respectfully heed your instruction and amend my understanding accordingly. (The Prefect later added in another reply: “I have drafts of this letter preserved, which is why I was able to compile and record it. However, the opening section of the previous page is missing, so this does not begin at the original start.” Lord Bao was Bao Qingjian of Jurong, universally called “Bao.” By the time of this reply, he had already received the transmitted records—this was the beginning of the *yichou* year.)

Proceeding three or four *li* directly down from the mouth of Little A, one arrives at the Eastern Dark Gate of the Yin Palace. Entering two hundred paces into this cavern mouth, the interior becomes as bright as daylight. I wonder whether this distinct radiance of the grotto-heaven is drawn from the sunlight to illuminate the cave, or if it possesses its own luminosity. Within this grotto-heaven, the palaces and bureaus are vast, said to comprise hundreds of halls and chambers. The officials here include the two Immortal Lords, brothers, as well as other immortals—how many men and women reside within? Are these merely stone chambers, or are there also halls of gold and jade? Are the palaces connected to Dongting and Baoshan? Did Lord Bao and his sister, Lady Zhu, ever enter this palace while in the mortal world? Were the two of them not yet deemed worthy of ascension and thus appointed as subterranean lords? Where is their seat of governance?

I, dull and ignorant, venture these questions, fearing they may give offense. (The matter of Lord Bao and his sister was not mentioned in the Middle Lord’s earlier letter; this must have been separately conveyed. Now, these questions are raised again, along with inquiries about the grotto, to which the *Dinglu* has provided further replies.)

The market’s stone platform and the name of the marketplace endure because of this. Today, I remain steadfast in my devotion to the Dao.

I was initiated into the mysteries at the Golden Portal of the Primal Register, transcending worldly traces and ascending to the pure void. How vast and distant is the mark of the mysterious! How deep and remote the abyss of wondrous caverns! To master oneself and purify the heart, to bathe in the fragrant streams—if one can achieve this, now is the time.

Your last letter spoke of glimpsing essential principles and cultivating the Five Spirits. You claimed to have journeyed west to the gardens of *Menliang* and roamed east to the Mystic Isles, yet without striving to the utmost, seeking only to be guided and drawn forth. Such words, if truly rooted in the heart, may indeed open the way. The cultivation of the Five Spirits, too, has reached my ears. Yet the Dao drifts upon external traces, untouched by inner truth. Thus, the cloud chariot’s sacred shafts, though aligned, remain distant.

In ancient times, Zeng Shen and Hua Qiao (from this, we know Hua Qiao was once graced by the descent of the Perfected) responded to the summons of the age, for matters may arise unexpectedly. The waters need not be still; if one has the destiny but lacks the resolve, it is the very affliction Shen Gong lamented—meeting the ultimate yet failing to act, like spilled water that cannot be gathered again. Thus, the ancients said: *"When the time comes, do not hesitate; the mountain recluse claps his hands in joy."*

Those who study the Dao must not rely solely on their innate endowment but must preserve and uphold purity and wholeness. Then may they gallop toward the age of the pine, turn the wheel through the Purple Clarity, where the numinous vision resounds on all sides, and the mysterious tones harmonize in chorus. Jade chimes resound through the clouds, attuned without deliberation—this may be called the hidden treasure of the secret Dao, the supreme flourishing of true radiance.

You, Jian, have long held such aspirations; now I merely return to your former intent. (This letter appears to be Master Pei’s words, while Yang’s letter does not connect to the later questions of the Mystic Emperor. It may not be Master Zhong’s reply. Moreover, the original four letters of the Chief Clerk no longer survive.)

As for the Mystic Emperor: of old, the Yellow Emperor’s son, Changyi, wed the daughter of Mount Shu, and she bore Gaoyang, whose virtue was titled *Ruipian* and *Yupian*. *Ruipian*’s father dwelled in the land of Weak Waters, while *Yupian* himself was tempered at the ford of the Seven Rivers—this is the Mystic Emperor. Wielding the trust of the myriad spirits and overseeing the host of gods to guide all things, he commands the hundred qi, summons thunder and lightning. Thus, riding his chariot of primordial union, he journeyed north to Youling, south to Jiaozhi, west across the Flowing Sands, and east to the Coiling Tree. All beings, great and small, all gods within the light of sun and moon, were subject to him. Traversing the four directions and circling the eight extremities, wherever there were mountains of jade terraces or mounds of yin palaces, he transported the stones of Anxi to seal and fill them. Casting bronze from Mount Yu into precious tripods, he offered one each to the divine peaks of the Grotto Mountains—not merely Mount Juqu alone. This is the so-called Mystic Emperor.

(What follows is Master Zhong’s reply to the four inquiries posed earlier, written on the blank space above. The account of *Ruipian* and *Yupian* aligns with the *Five Talismans*, except the latter omits the matter of burying the tripods.)

Bao *Qingjian* and his sister were both seventh-generation descendants of Li Zhan and Zhang Lü, originally from the northern village of Duling. They kept an inn at the Wei Bridge, accumulating hidden virtue and yearning for the Dao in hopes of transcending life.

When Empress Yin was interred, the wives of the two-thousand-*shi* officials from the capital and neighboring commanderies were to gather at the imperial mausoleum. An imperial edict inquired into the matter, and Minister of Ceremonies Feng Xi replied, "Governor of Runan Han Chong embraces austerity and reveres the Dao, forgetting his own form. Though he holds high office, his wife spins and weaves herself. His governance is benevolent and unburdensome, treating the people as if they were wounded. Profound in wisdom and erudition, he possesses the discernment of a noble man—truly a luminary in the darkest night, a Zichan for Your Majesty. His wife, unaware of the virtue of frugality, weeps over her lack of fine clothing, which only serves to illuminate Chong’s illustrious power."

There, he encountered Master Ma Huang, who said to him: “Your benevolence has moved Heaven and Earth, and your hidden virtue has touched gods and spirits. The Supreme One is about to reward your sincerity. He has sent me to lead you to the Way of longevity. I am an immortal official. Are you willing to follow me?”

Yi then kowtowed and struck his breast, saying: “From my youth, I have cherished the pursuit of longevity. Now, by good fortune, I have met a divine immortal. I beg to serve and attend you.” Master Ma Huang then took Yi into Mount Tongbai, where he transmitted to him the Eight Arts of Concealing the Earth and the method of ingesting the essence of the Five Stars. He later bestowed upon him the name Donghua. Upon arriving in the grotto, Yi was appointed Left Director of the Central Bureau of the Register of Destiny.

*(The* Book of Han *states: Yi, styled Zixiang, was a native of Yingyin. His family was immensely wealthy, and he was always generous in his aid, though he did not regard it as a personal favor. Once, while traveling in Runan, he encountered Zhang Jizha of Chenliu, who was hastening to his teacher’s funeral. Zhang had met with cold and ice, and his carriage had broken down, leaving him stranded on the road. Yi saw him and said: “You are diligent in fulfilling your duty to the end and hastening to righteousness—your journey should not be delayed.” He then dismounted, gave Zhang his carriage, and departed without revealing his name, urging his horse onward. Zhang suspected it was Yi. Later, when he deliberately passed through Yingyin to return the borrowed carriage, Yi shut his gates and declined to see him, pleading illness. He remained steadfast in his resolve, refusing all official summons.)*

Yi, styled Zixiang, follows the pattern of matching given names with their meanings, for *xiang* (相) also signifies "mutual." *Xiang* is pronounced *xiliang* (息亮切). It remains unclear which of the two is the correct interpretation.

The *Liexian Zhuan* by Ma Huang records that during the Yellow Emperor’s reign, there was a horse-master named Ma Shi. The *Dinglu Fu* lists a *Dianbing Zhifa Lang* (典柄执法郎), who was Chunyu Zhen, styled Shuxian, overseer of trials for those pursuing the Dao. Zhen was a native of Shangyu in Kuaiji. During the reign of Emperor Huan of Han, he served as magistrate of a county in Xuzhou, and later, during Emperor Ling’s reign, as an aide to the Grand General. From youth, he was devoted to the Dao, skilled in arts and calculations, and practiced the ingestion of sesame and *huangjing* (黄精). Later, he retreated into the Wu Mountains of Wumu to live in seclusion, where he encountered the immortal Huiche Zi, who transmitted to him the *Hongjing Dan Jing* (虹景丹经). Through cultivation, he attained the Dao and now resides in the grotto as *Dianbing Zhifa Lang*.

The *Zhouyi Cantong Qi* states: "During Emperor Huan’s reign, Chunyu Shutong of Shangyu received arts from Xu Congshi of Qingzhou. Observing the celestial patterns, he divined disasters and anomalies, often with accurate results. Due to his mastery of these arts, the commandery recommended him as a *fangshi* (方士), and he was later promoted to Market Director of Luoyang." These accounts differ only in minor details.

There is no Wumu Mountain in Wu; however, both Lou and Wuxing have Tianmu Mountains, which may be the same. Huiche Zi does not appear prominently elsewhere.

On the night of the first day of the twelfth month, the *Dinglu Jun* (定录君) spoke of the Northern River Controller of Destiny, whose post had long been vacant and was temporarily filled by Tao Jun. Jun appeared to be a native of Qiantang. In his youth, he served as an administrative aide in the commandery, later carrying his satchel to the Imperial Academy to study. He was well-versed in classical arts, disasters, and anomalies. In his later years, he became Governor of Jiaozhi. At the end of the Han, he abandoned worldly life and entered Zengcheng Mountain to study the Dao. There, he encountered Dongguo Youping, a man from the Qin era who had long lived in seclusion in Zengcheng and attained the Dao. Youping taught Jun the arts of ingesting the Nine Essences, refining *qi*, and aligning the heart with the auxiliary stars. Jun cultivated these practices and achieved the Dao, now residing in the grotto.

Zhang Fan, styled Gongyi, was a native of Xiuwu in Henei. His grandfather [pronounced *qian*] served as Minister over the Masses in the Han, and his father, Yan, as Grand Commandant. Yuan Wei sought to marry his daughter to Fan, but Fan declined. Naturally serene and devoted to the Dao, he declined all summons to office. Later, he served as Gentleman Consultant and participated in the military affairs of Chancellor Wei Wu, earning profound respect. Fond of relieving the destitute, he kept no surplus wealth at home. He died in the seventeenth year of Jian’an.

His younger brother, Cheng, styled Gongxian, was also renowned. Appointed Gentleman Consultant for his upright conduct, he later served as Remonstrating Censor, Grandee of Zhao Commandery, and Prefect. He followed Wei Wu on a western campaign, falling ill and dying in Chang’an. The accounts of their names and styles vary greatly. Cheng and Feng appear similar but were not Yuan’s sons-in-law. If this were Fan, his style would differ. Upon close examination of their deeds, it seems more likely he was the elder brother.

The *Book of Wei*’s biography of Wang Xiu further states: Xiu frequently traveled to Nanyang, often lodging at Zhang Feng’s residence. When Feng’s entire household fell ill, Xiu tended to them. However, the Zhang brothers had once taken refuge in Yangzhou under Yuan Shu—never under Liu Biao—and thus should not have been in Nanyang. These inconsistencies cast doubt.

The Mountain Chart Noble Scion appears in the *Arrayed Transcendents’ Biographies*, as recounted by the Lady of Zhonghou. (Investigating the grotto affairs, all were described by these two lords. Yet in these two entries, only the Lady of Zhonghou is mentioned—likely because she was originally an official in the Eastern Flowery Palace.)

In the second year of *Yongchu*, a summer drought persisted, and despite prolonged prayers, no response came. Thereupon, (Chang) gathered and buried over ten thousand corpses, and timely rain fell in abundance. His rank later reached *Guanglu Xun*.

*Mingchen Shilang* Zhang Taozhi was the mother of Zhu Yuyu, Han *Sili Xiaowei* of Pei. When Yuyu was executed alongside Chen Fan, his mother had long practiced hidden virtue. Upon hearing of her impending relocation, she was only then appointed *Shilang*.

(Ju Yuyu was a native of Pei. Among the "Eight Worthies" of the *Huan-Ling* era, he was later implicated in the case of the partisans. Li Ying and Du Mi were both imprisoned and died, though not contemporaneous with Chen Fan.)

*Mingchen Shilang* Xia Fu, styled Zizhi, was a native of Chenliu. From youth, he loved the Dao, consuming *zhu* and *er*, and harmonizing with *yunmu*. Later, he entered Mount Wu, where he received the *Lianhun* method from the Red-Bearded Master. He also encountered the True Man of Tongbai, who transmitted to him the *Huangshui Yunjiang* method. He attained the Dao and now resides in the grotto.

In his youth, Fu was summoned by the public office, yet he hung the summons on a mulberry tree and departed—such was his lofty and unyielding resolve.

(Later Han records and the *Biographies of Lofty Recluses* both state: Xia Fu was a native of Yu in Chenliu. In his youth, he was a scholar. During Emperor Huan’s reign, he was recommended for his forthright speech but declined the post. Of upright character, he did not align with the partisans. Resented by the eunuchs, he was ensnared in the proscription of the partisans. To evade disaster, he cut his beard and hair, altered his appearance, and fled to the forests of Mount Linlü, where he worked as a laborer. Later, he returned home, shut his door, and refused to see anyone. He died before the partisan ban was lifted. The Red-Bearded Master appears in the *Liexian Zhuan*; Tongbai refers to the Right Assistant King.)

The remaining individuals cannot be recounted in full, but all were chosen for their steadfast integrity and uprightness, their embodied seclusion and spiritual clarity—qualities befitting a *Shilang*, regardless of gender.

(As previously mentioned, there were seven in total; here, only two women and one man are described.)

The above was recounted by the Lord of Life-Preservation.

(This likely follows the *Jie Zhonghou*’s announcement.)

*True Reports, Scroll Twelve. True Reports, Scroll Thirteen. The Pivot of Spirit Verification, Part Three.*

Among the rulers of the underworld, there are three ranks. Among the titles of ghostly marshals, there are likewise three ranks. All these are bestowed upon those who have accumulated merit and virtue in the world, whose deeds have ripened into fruition—whether through personal pursuit of longevity and attainment of the Dao, or through the virtuous conduct of descendants that glorifies their ancestors, or through recitation of the *Dongxuan* scriptures, whose transforming influence extends to ancestors seven generations prior. *(The *Dongxuan* refers to the *Great Dongxuan Scripture*; reciting it ten thousand times enables the refinement of the bodily essence in the Southern Palace for ancestors from the seventh generation onward, allowing them to receive the transformation into embryonic immortals. This is not the *Dongxuan Lingbao Scripture* as commonly referred to in the present age.)*

The paths to seeking transcendence are not singular, and the means of attaining it are manifold. In essence, it is through the accumulation of hidden deeds in the world that all may achieve this vast renewal of life. Their names are recorded in the Eastern Flower Registry, selected and inscribed by the Celestial Emperor, and they are not subject to the jurisdiction of the Three Officials’ bureaus.

Those not subject to the teachings and regulations of the Nine Palaces, nor engaged in the practices of refinement and transformation, though dwelling within the grotto-heavens, are the lowest among these rulers. According to the Siming method, this rank requires one hundred and forty years before qualifying for a single promotion. Only upon this first promotion may one ascend the immortal ranks and receive the commands of the immortals.

*(According to the Sword Classic, the rulers possess extensive hierarchies and promotion timelines, with vast disparities in duration. The numerical designations of these ranks differ from their titles, where greater numbers confer higher status—such is the structure of their hierarchy.)*

The second rank of underworld rulers may directly embark upon the immortal path, ascending through the immortal grades. After one hundred and forty years, they are promoted to fill the positions of the *Guanjin* (Custodial Offices), which resemble the scattered clerks of the mundane world. This rank represents the middle tier among underworld rulers. Li Dong and others currently belong to the first rank.

*(Li Dong, a native of Qu’e, served as a household leader and libationer. His original documents still exist, and he followed the methods of Bao of Nanhai. In the first year of Yongchang, when the Master was twenty-three, he received from Li Dong the Six Jia Yin-Yang Traveling Kitchen Talismans. The third rank comprises the highest of the underworld rulers. They may freely enter and exit the halls and chambers of the immortals, roaming the lands of the divine provinces. She wept bitterly for a long while before departing—this too was deemed extraordinary. Yet it remains unclear why both brother and sister should inherit the blessings of seven generations: the brother executed while the sister attained transcendence—this cannot be the Northern Dipper of the Daoist tradition. The ghostly bureaucracy has its own Northern Dipper Lord, who governs life and death.

(According to records, when Sun Hao’s defeated general Zhang Ti’s soldier Liu Rong fell ill and died, after three days he suddenly rose with a great cry, saying, “I reached the gates of the Northern Dipper, where I saw men binding Zhang Ti.” Startled, he faltered, and that very evening, Zhang Ti perished in battle. This would seem to correspond to the Fourth Palace. As for the Fifth and Sixth Palaces, whose domains remain obscure, they may well be the courts of judgment and retribution.)

The Supreme Emperor of the ghostly bureaucracy is the Northern Emperor, who presides over the First Heavenly Palace and governs all Six Heavenly Palaces. The remaining four palaces are each administered by the Four Luminous Lords.

(Though each is said to govern one palace, their specific locations are not clearly defined. Since the palaces stand in parallel, they cannot be assigned to the four cardinal directions. Examining the hierarchy of the Lords, the Second Palace is governed by the Western Luminous Lord, the Third by the Eastern Luminous Lord, and the Fourth by the Northern Dipper Lord, with the remaining two following in sequence.)

Each pair of heavenly palaces is overseen by one official, making three officials in total across the six heavens—akin to the offices of penal law, responsible for judgment and punishment. These are perpetually overseen by true immortals and the Lords of Life, who collectively govern them and share the duty of administering life and death. All major decrees and judgments issue from the immortal officials.

(This is the "Three Officials" often invoked in Daoist tradition. The *Scripture on Dispelling Demons* states that Mount Tai has a Left Fire Official, a Right Water Official, and a Female Official, also called the Three Officials, all charged with punishment. Today, the Three Mao Lords oversee them: the Great Lord as commander, and the Lord of Life as inspector. Their subordination to the immortal officials stems from the fact that not all people in the world die; some attain true transcendence and thus fall outside the Northern Emperor’s jurisdiction. Others, though dead, may undergo spiritual transformation and regain form—such cases are recorded by the true immortals. Hence, the office of the Lord of Life governs and unifies these matters.)

The Northern Dipper Lord of the ghostly bureaucracy serves as the examining official for the Daoist Seven Stars of the Northern Dipper. This ghostly office is also subordinate to the essence of the Nine Stars and ultimately answers to the Jade Lord of the Northern Dawn.

(The Northern Dipper in the heavens has its own overseers, so the ghostly bureaucracy mirrors this with a corresponding office. Its authority derives from the *Jade Rotating Square* and the *Jade Tablet*, thus it is ultimately subordinate to the courts of the Most High.)

... [text missing] ... need not all come directly. I shall reveal to you one or two secrets, fellow kindred spirits, so you may know the tranquility of the Dipper’s hidden realm. How can one not be diligent in the Dao?

(These three individuals are not mentioned in other texts. During the Later Han, there was a Li Yun, who also served as Magistrate of Baima and was executed for his forthright remonstrance. The phrase "fellow kindred spirits" refers to his address to the Chief Clerk and his subordinates.)

On the night of the twenty-fourth day of the seventh month, the Lord of Life delivered this message.

(According to earlier records, though the Chief Clerk, Sima, and others were informed by the Register of Destiny, this appears to be the initial account of the grotto’s affairs, dated the eleventh month of the *chou* year. The present mixed account, however, should follow later and is instead dated the seventh month, though it does not correspond to the *yin* year. The sequence is difficult to reconcile. Fourteen entries in total were received from the subterranean authorities, transcribed by clerks into a single scroll.)

She had previously resided in the Grotto of Easy Transitions. Weizi regularly ingested mist-qi, claiming that mist-qi is the essence of mountains, marshes, water, and fire—the fullness of qi within metals and stones. Prolonged ingestion allows one to disperse the form and enter emptiness, merging the body with cloud-qi. Weizi stated that she received this method from Chun Wenqi, the Jade Consort of Eastern Florescence in the Eastern Sea, who is the younger sister of the Azure Lad. Once, Weizi concentrated her thoughts in secluded stillness, her sincere heart moving the numinous, and so Wenqi descended to her. She transmitted the Dao of ingesting mist.

After receiving the Dao of mist-ingestion, Weizi also taught it at times to those studying in the Grotto of Embracing Reality and the Grotto of Easy Transitions. I once obtained this formula, which is excellent and practical. The method of ingesting mist is as follows:

At dawn, in a state of secluded stillness, sit or lie as you wish. First, close your eyes and inwardly visualize, faintly perceiving the five viscera. Then exhale through the mouth twenty-four times. Do this while keeping the eyes closed, so that you see the five-colored qi swirling and coiling around your face in a dense cloud. Next, inhale this five-colored qi through the mouth fifty times. Afterward, swallow saliva sixty times. Then softly recite the incantation:

*"Great radiance emits brilliance,
Numinous mist shifts on all sides.
Bound qi coils and bends,
Five colors fill the grotto-heaven.
Divine smoke converges and opens,
Metals and stones bloom with true essence.
Lush and deep, the purple void,
Refining form to preserve wholeness.
Emerging in light, hidden in seclusion,
Five spirits transform and divide.
United brightness fans the emptiness,
At times riding the six clouds.
Harmonizing and gathering my body,
Ascending to the nine heavens."*

After reciting, knock the teeth together seven times and swallow saliva seven times. Then open your eyes, and the practice is complete. This Dao is wondrously efficacious. Many in the Mystic Capital of the Divine Continent have mastered this art. Can you practice this method? With long practice, you will often ride clouds and mist in your travels.

*(This method of ingesting mist has been transcribed separately for use.)*

(For this is merely a matter of failing to seek with utmost sincerity.) Within Baoshan Mountain grows white *zhi*. There is also the water of Hidden Spring, a true purple in hue. (This is Mount Linwu, situated in the great Wu lake.)

In the time of Gao Xin, there was an immortal named Master Zhan of the Upper Rank who planted plums upon the Earth of Crouching Dragons, filling the land with them. Master Zhan now serves as the Right Guardian of the Nine Palaces. He often tells others: “In former days, while dwelling beneath Huayang, I ate white plums of extraordinary sweetness. The memory lingers still, yet in an instant three thousand years have passed.” (Various chronologies record that from the first year of Yao’s reign—*wuxu*—to the *jimao* year of the Qi dynasty, 2,803 years elapsed. Gao Xin was Yao’s father, so this statement must date to the Jin era. To speak of three thousand years when only 2,800 have passed since Yao’s time suggests that external calendars may be imprecise. For instance, the *dinghai* count would already have been exceeded. The *Bamboo Annals* record a precise span of 2,643 years—an even greater discrepancy.)

Later, Guo Sichao planted the Five Fruits in that same place. The land is also suitable for cultivating *mu-shi*—the *mu-shi* of Blessed Land, used to dispel calamities and the myriad ills. During the Qin, the Daoist Zhou Taibin and Jiang Shumao, the Marquis of Baling, came to reside beneath Mount Juqu. They also planted the Five Fruits and the Five Pungent Vegetables. Shumao was enfeoffed as marquis during the reign of King Xiao of Qin. The place is now named Jiangba after him, for the land took its name from Shumao. (The name remains to this day. A great road runs from behind Small Mao Peak to Yanling, and is called Jiangba Road. However, during the reign of Duke Xiao of Qin, the state had not yet annexed Chu to establish commanderies, and Baling County was only founded in the early Jin. It is unclear how there could have been a marquisate of Baling—likely it refers to the Ba of Bashu.)

Both men attained immortality and now serve as Left Ministers on Penglai. The various Jiangs of Nanzheng are descendants of Shumao. Shumao once wrote to the officials of the Supreme Ultimate Palace, saying: “Formerly, I studied the Dao in Guigu, attained it in Shaoshi, nurtured my *ge-yu* in Huayang, and awaited ascension in the Realm of Leisure. At times, I rode the whirlwind-chariot, feasting in Juqu. I awoke to the swift passage of time, how things endure while people perish—what toil is this?” Taibin was also a man of talent and skill, adept at playing the zither. He once taught Mi Changsheng and Sun Guangtian. Guangtian was none other than Sun Deng, who could play eight notes on a single string—a truly marvelous feat. (Sun Deng is the same “long-whistler” mentioned by Xi Kang of Mount Kuaiji, who also spoke of seeing him play the one-stringed zither. These words are not empty.)

Shumao cultivated the Five Pungent Vegetables and often sold them to purchase cinnabar for his use. Even now, among the mountains, leeks and scallions remain—perhaps his lingering seeds. *“A clear pool girds the numinous peak,*
*Long forests lush with verdant green.*
*The dark bird hides in secluded wilds—*
*In leisurely words, I speak my mind.*
*I ply my oars upon the sacred waves,*
*Bowing my head to seek the Morning Wind.*
*Yet the hour of liberation eludes me,*
*And I wander free among these hills and groves.”*

*“Beyond the Nine Abysses, the waves surge with gods,*
*I refine the Dao and attain the Golden Perfected.*
*This is the feather of the numinous phoenix.”*

Now that the embankments and walls have collapsed and water no longer pools deeply, people treat the land as fields. Yet the terrain remains low and expansive; even slight damming still forms a pond, allowing one to row a boat and sing. But none can trace the footsteps of that distant age—how lamentable!

Later accounts say that Four Courts passed by each year to wander and gaze, for even after his promotion, he still cherished his former home, often feasting in the Eternal Realm and gazing fondly upon his old companions.

Zhang Xuanbin, a man of Dingxiang, was nominated as a Filial and Incorrupt Candidate during the reign of Emperor Wu of Wei. Returning to his hometown, he served as disciple to Ji of Xihe, consuming medicinal herbs and practicing the arts of the Cavern Chamber and White Prime. Later, he encountered the Perfected One Fan Ziming on Shaoshi Mountain, who transmitted to him the Dao of vanishing transformation and concealed radiance. Formerly on Mount Tianzhu, he now resides in the Hua Yang Grotto as the Warden of Prohibitions. The Warden of Prohibitions oversees the offices of waters and rains.

This man excels in discoursing on emptiness and nothingness. Scholars of discourse often uphold the principle of fundamental nonbeing, saying: Nonbeing is the dwelling of Great Being; from it, Lesser Being arises. Accumulating Lesser Being nourishes Lesser Nonbeing; perceiving Great Being reveals the root of Great Nonbeing. Being contains Nonbeing, and Nonbeing contains Being.

At times, dark mists converged in a whirlwind; at others, a fine rain descended in a mist.

The Ministry of Life-Preservation has four Vice-Ministers. This woman oversees torrential rains and waters, as well as the governance of the *Five Mushrooms of Gold and Jade* and the *Herbs of Metal and Stone*. Should one wish to summon a great deluge, one may present a petition to her. (The Warden of Prohibitions also governs rain and water; if seeking rain, one should petition both together.)

By the early Song dynasty, Lady Tan, the Princess Dowager of Jing of Changsha, sponsored a Daoist surnamed Chen and established a Daoist residence northwest of Mount Leiping—this is the present Northern Residence. Later, there was Mount Jurong, and Wang Wenqing, as recorded in the annals, became its master. Learning that Magistrate Xu had once built his dwelling here, he extensively consulted the village elders. In the seventh year of the Daming reign, an elderly adept named Xu Ou mentioned that his ancestor had served Magistrate Xu and passed down knowledge that the magistrate’s residence lay just before the present residence, where the tallow trees stood, and that the well before the refectory hall likely remained. At the time, the site was overgrown with weeds and brambles. Wang then cleared the vegetation and searched, indeed discovering a brick well, its mouth nearly filled with earth. He excavated and repaired it, reinforcing it with tiles. Now it holds fine water, slightly white in hue, perhaps the very water earlier described as resembling that outside Phoenix Gate.

Thus confirming it as the former residence, which had long lain abandoned, with none daring to dwell there. Since it was said to be the "golden chamber to the inner room," it must have been the most fertile ground for crouching dragons. To its northwest stretches a long ridge, called Mount Long Concealment.

Northeast of Mount Leiping lies another mountain, commonly called Great Horizontal Mountain, though its true name is Mount Yu Ridge. The *Records of Famous Mountains* refers to it as Ridge Mountain. At its foot flows a spring where Li Ming once compounded the elixir of immortality and ascended to the Mystic Continent. The site by the water remains to this day. Due east of this mountain stands the ancient tomb of King Yeyi of Yue. (Originally written as *墓*, later generations changed it to *冢*. The mountain now extends far and wide. The later reference to an ancient immortal compounding the elixir likely refers to this place. Li Ming merely stated it lay in a certain region, so it may have been slightly south of here. No foundation traces remain by the water, perhaps gradually reclaimed by overgrowth.)

King Yeyi was the fourth-generation descendant of Goujian. Initially refusing to ascend the throne, he fled into a cave on Mount Jing. The people of Yue lured him out, and later, during the Wu dynasty, he was relocated back to Kuaiji. In the eleventh year of King Xuan of Zhou, he was killed by Sun Zhujiu, who was in turn slain by the people of Yue. How his tomb came to be so far away remains unknown—perhaps there was some numinous quality to this place. Though no definitive burial mound has been found, there appears to be a designated funerary precinct.

The above was spoken by the Lord of the *Dinglu*.

Lu Zihua, Cai Tiansheng, and Long Bogao—all dwelled upon Square Terrace.

Zhang Zuchang was a man of Pengcheng. During the Wu dynasty, he came from the north and gained entry to this chamber. Zuchang feigned death by falling from a carriage, thus concealing his form in this secluded lodge to cultivate the practice of *guarding the One*. He took as his master Bao Cha of Shangdang, fifth-generation descendant of Bao Xuan, the Han dynasty Minister over the Masses. Cha received the Dao from Master Wang. (Bao Xuan, Han dynasty Colonel-Director of the Imperial Secretariat, was slain by Wang Mang. Xuan’s son was Yong; Yong’s son was {Rili}; {Rili}’s son was [name missing].)

Liu Ping’a bore no given name or surname, refusing to reveal them to others. At the end of the Han, he served as Chief of Ping’a in Jiujiang, hence his sobriquet. Skilled in the healing arts, he performed acts of virtue, curing others’ illnesses as if they were his own. While traveling, he encountered the immortal Zhou Zhengshi, who taught him the Dao of *concealment and preservation*. Assuming the guise of a hat-wearing traveler, he came to dwell in this chamber. He regularly ingested the *solar and lunar essences*, his complexion like jade, appearing no older than thirty. (How could the two masters not know his true name? Having once revealed it, they chose never to speak of it again. The origins of Dai Meng’s clan are recounted later.)

Lu Zihua was a man of Shanyang and a disciple of Master Yin. He had already consumed the *rainbow elixir* but had not yet studied the *Inner Canon*. He came to study under the Eastern Minister, receiving and reciting the *Hidden Writ of the Grand Empyrean*. He took delight in the seclusion of Square Terrace and had no desire to ascend to the rank of immortal.

Cai Tiansheng was a man of Shanggu. In his youth, he served as a whistling attendant to the Master of Whistles, selling assorted incense in the wilds to sustain himself. His nature was kind and sincere.

Cai Tiansheng never spoke ill of others. Once, while traveling to purchase incense, he encountered the River Earl’s daughter. Recognizing her as an extraordinary being, he bowed twice and offered her a full eave’s worth of incense. Moved by his sincerity, she taught him the method of paying homage to the Heavenly Emperor and the Jade Sovereign. Thereby he attained immortality, assuming the form of a staff-bearing recluse, dwelling in seclusion upon Square Terrace. The maiden still visits him to this day, and Tiansheng regards her as his master.

Long Bogao was a man of the Later Han. When the Han general Ma Yuan, the Pacifier of the South, admonished his brother’s son, he praised this man as exemplary and worthy of emulation—this was none other than Bogao. Later, Bogao followed the immortal Daolin of the Knife and received the method of fetal ingestion. He also regularly consumed the *Azure Nourishment* formula. Assuming the guise of a drunken death, he concealed himself upon Square Terrace, becoming a disciple of the Master of the Fixed Record. (Bogao’s given name was Shu. A native of the capital district, he served as Magistrate of Shandu during the *Jianwu* era of the Han, rising to the post of Governor of Lingling. When Ma Yuan campaigned in the south, he wrote to his nephew Yan, saying: “Long Bogao is sincere, circumspect, and prudent, his speech beyond reproach. Modest, frugal, and upright, he is both incorruptible and commanding. I cherish and esteem him; may you and your peers take him as your model. Even if you fail to match Bogao, you will still be a man of caution and restraint—like one who carves a swan but falls short, yet still resembles a duck.”)

To the northeast of Thunderflat Mountain and the southeast of Constantgood Mountain lies Swallowmouth Mountain, so named for its three small peaks standing in close proximity. It is also called Squarecorner Mountain. In ancient times, men once compounded the Nine-Cauldron Elixir here. The Recluse delighted in dwelling here at that time, and still frequents the place. Beneath Squarecorner Mountain lies a grotto chamber called the Square Source Lodge, which has two entrances often visible from without. These five men now sojourn here together. (This mountain lies southwest of the Great Horizontal. Two earthen mounds, resembling a shield and a dragon, once stood nearby, though their names are no longer known. The earlier mention of Li Ming compounding the elixir refers to this place. The Recluse—after Yuan the Assistant departed the world and wished to conceal his name—took this title. Here, before receiving his official appointment, he paused to cultivate his practice in the grotto lodge. The mountain still has two small entrances, and the five men, including the four from Fourflat Mountain, come and go freely, often gathering together. Thus, when Master Yang dreamed of Yuan the Assistant, he said, “I have just come from Fourflat Mountain.” The six entries above were newly transcribed by hand, having been conveyed by the Master of Life Preservation.)

Within Deer Track Mountain lies an impassable ravine. The “impassable ravine” is a space of barely one or two *mu*, with no passage leading in or out—hence its name. The grotto chamber is surrounded on all sides by blue-white stone, which naturally radiates light like a silken canopy unfurled. The floor is perfectly level, with stone beds and stone couches of varying lengths, their partitions and divisions as though carved with precision, yet all in perfect order. To the northeast is a small opening, barely wide enough for a person to enter. Once inside, one may proceed two or three hundred paces.

Upon reaching the grotto chamber, the entrance is initially narrow, but grows ever more spacious the deeper one proceeds. Outside the entrance to the south lie three piles of stone. Beneath these piles, a rope may be found. Alternatively, a small stone may be used to cover the cave’s opening. The size of the opening resembles the Three Convenient Gates of Huayang. These gates, too, are sealed with small stones. Without prolonged purification and fasting, the rope cannot be found. The Deer Track Grotto is likewise—it does not admit impure *qi*.

(This mountain now lies within the borders of Southern Xuzhou, directly opposite Maoshan. From the north, it can be seen. Daoist adepts also dwell here. The deer tracks are upon the stone, hence the name. The entrance to the grotto is discernible, yet it is kept solemn and pristine, with none daring to profane it. As this text likens it to the Three Convenient Gates of Huayang, the southern and northern grottoes were originally open, while the remaining eastern, western, and southeastern passages were sealed.)

Shanxing was skilled in the arts of wind-angle divination, mastering the six-day, seven-division method. He could observe qi and foretell fortune or misfortune. He often earned his livelihood through divination. Emperor An summoned him for a policy debate, where he stood out among the scholars. Later, he was appointed magistrate of Wu County. One day, a sudden gale arose, and [Rang] Zong divined that the capital would suffer a great fire. He recorded the date and sent someone to verify—his prediction proved true. The nobles, upon hearing this, memorialized the throne, and he was summoned as a Academician. Zong, ashamed to be known for his divinations, upon receiving the summons, hung his official seal and cord in the county courtyard that very night and fled. He never served again.

His son, [Qi]ye, styled Zhiyuan, inherited his father’s arts and refined them further. His disciples often numbered in the hundreds. In the second year of Emperor Shun’s *Yangjia* reign, he was summoned to the palace. He submitted a memorial on eleven matters and was appointed Gentleman of the Palace. After returning home, he was murdered by a fellow townsman, Sun Li.

Among the others were Wang Shuming, Bao Yuanzhi, and Yin Gai’s wife, along with over twenty more. All dwelled in the Northern Mountains, though their names and deeds cannot be fully recorded here. These few were the masters of the secluded grottoes and mountains. The immortals of these secluded grottoes long for those who seek the Dao, wishing to share their cavern abodes, yet in this benighted age, such people are rare.

(These grottoes, being entirely cut off from the world, serve as the dwelling places of earthbound immortals—far beyond the bounds of the thirty-six heavens.)

The Dao is lost to the adorned. How lamentable! To dwell in a household is to debase oneself.

(*Adorned* refers to those who covet official rank and courtly attire, thus neglecting the Dao. The household is but a temporary lodging.)

The Daoist of Wudang Mountain, Dai Meng, was originally surnamed Yan, named Ji, styled Zhongwei, and lived at the close of Emperor Ming of Han’s reign. Those who cultivate life-concealment all hide their names and birth times, hence he changed his surname to Dai and claimed official appointment under Emperor Wu. Yet this man, from youth, cherished the Dao and virtue, never serving in the world. Orphaned young, he supported his mother; when she died, he observed mourning rites and buried her. Completing his mourning period, he entered Huayang Mountain, consuming *zhu* (atractylodes), rhubarb, Solomon’s seal, mica, realgar, cinnabar, and *zhi* grasses. He received the method from Perfected One Qingling—disciple of Pei of Jizhou—and attained the Way of deathlessness. The Perfected One Pei bestowed upon him a jade pendant, a golden cauldron, scriptures, and the Stone Essence Gold Radiance Talisman. Thereafter, he could move with a light body and vigorous step, traversing the famous mountains.

He was sold to Dongyang. Later, he reported the matter to the authorities but was falsely accused and imprisoned in Wushang. The case nearly resulted in his execution. One night, an old man bestowed upon him a talisman, and a youth in yellow robes came and went. Thus, he was spared. Eventually, he announced his departure from the world.

The youth in yellow robes was none other than the official of the Jade Pendant and Golden Bell. It is said that there was always one person seated beside him—*fu er* (likely *rou fu*, though its form is unclear)—who was the Perfected One of the Grand Ultimate, coming and going at times.

The Perfected Master Pei had thirty-four disciples: eighteen studied the Buddhist Dao, while the remainder pursued the Dao of immortality (*Beixu*—likely a miswritten form of *Pianhuyong*). (His disciples included Liu Xianlin, Xin Zhongfu, and Zhao Zichang.)

The Perfected Master Zhou had fifteen disciples, four of whom mastered Buddhist teachings. (His foremost disciples were Wang *Yuwei* Da, Li Jiandao, and Quan Fajian.)

At Mount Tongbai, there were twenty-five disciples, eight of whom studied Buddhism. (The foremost among them were Yu Hongzhi, Zhu Faling, Zheng Wencheng, and Chen Yuanzi. This list merely highlights the most eminent. Both Xin and Quan appear to bear foreign surnames, likely indicating Buddhist disciples.)

The above eight entries were transcribed by a clerk and compiled into a single connected record.

In the mountains of Huo, there were Daoist practitioners Deng Yibo and Wang Xuanfu, who received and practiced the methods of consuming *qingjing* stone-cooked rice and absorbing the solar cinnabar radiance of *danjing*. Through concentrated meditation in the Grotto-Chamber, after thirty-four years, they attained inner vision of the five viscera and the ability to write in darkness at midnight. On the fifth day of the first month of this year, the Supreme Emperor dispatched a feathered chariot to welcome Yibo and Xuanfu. On that very day, they ascended to heaven riding clouds and dragons in broad daylight. Now they reside in the Northern *Xuanpu* Terrace, where they have been appointed as Perfected Ones of the Central Marchmount. (Yibo was from Wu; Xuanfu was from Pei.)

In the mountains of Huayin, there were Daoist practitioners Yin Qianzi, Zhang Shisheng, and Li Fanghui.

These were all contemporaries of Emperor Wu of Jin. They received from the immortal Guan Chengzi the method of steaming cinnabar and consuming *Atractylodes*, and by partaking of these, gained longevity and vigorous movement. They further received from Su Men’s Zhou Shouling the Dao of consuming the radiance of *danxia*. Having practiced this for fifty years, they concentrated their minds on inner vision, no longer requiring food or drink. Their bodies became light and strong, their complexions like those of youths. On the twelfth day of the second month of this year, the Supreme Unity dispatched a summons to welcome them. On that very day, they ascended to heaven riding clouds. Now they reside in the Dark Realm, where they have been appointed as Perfected Ones of the Lofty Immortals. Zhang Shisheng was named Earl of the Eastern Source. In Mount Heng, there were Daoist practitioners Zhang Lizheng and Ye Mingqi. Lizheng, having entered the mountains during the late Han, consumed *huangjing*, his complexion remaining robust and youthful, perpetually like that of a man of forty. Mingqi entered the mountains at the end of the Wei and consumed pills of *zexie* and cypress seeds. Together they dwelled in a cave, later both receiving from the Western City Lord Wang the *hongjing* cinnabar formula. They had been consuming this elixir for forty-three years, though they suffered from the scarcity of cinnabar. Both emerged in Guangzhou, becoming Buddhist monks during the tenure of Teng Han as Prefect. Thereupon they attained inner and outer clarity, their eyes bright and bodies light, able to travel five hundred *li* in a day. They also practiced *shouyi*, having maintained this for thirty years. On the first day of the third month, the Eastern Florescence dispatched a summons to welcome them. On that very day, they ascended to heaven riding clouds. Now they reside in the Wind Chamber of the Square Cauldron, both having become Upper Immortals. (Teng Han served as Prefect of Guangzhou in the *jiayin* year of the tenth *Yonghe* reign [354 CE]. Their transcendence occurred in the *yichou* year, twelve years later, meaning they had already been consuming the elixir for thirty-two years before emerging once more.)

They further consumed the Dark Elixir. After a long time, they no longer required food or drink, their bodies becoming light and strong, their original forms transformed.

At times, he would sell medicines and move among the world of men, yet none recognized him. Often, he came to the capital’s markets to purchase cinnabar, from which he refined the *Nine-Flowered Elixir*. Upon completing the elixir, a single dose was taken, and the Supreme Unity Dao Lord dispatched an envoy on the seventeenth day of the sixth month this year to welcome him. After lingering three days to bid farewell to his fellow practitioners in the mountains, he then rode clouds and mounted a dragon, ascending to heaven in broad daylight. He now dwells in the Eastern Flower.

In the Wolf Five Mountains of the Eastern Sea, there was a Daoist practitioner named Yu Wengsheng, a man from Kuaiji. Formerly, he received from the immortal Jie Jun the method of ingesting solar essence. During the Wu dynasty, he came to conceal himself in these mountains, where he also practiced the *Way of Cloud-Turning and Form-Returning*. Through prolonged and concentrated refinement, his body grew ever younger, like that of a child. On the twenty-third day of the seventh month this year, the Eastern Supreme Emperor dispatched an envoy to welcome him. That very day, he rode clouds and ascended to heaven. He now resides in Mount Yanggu. (The Wolf Five Mountains lie in the sea, opposite the White Chapter Shore, and are now simply called Wolf Mountain.)

In Red Water Mountain, there was a Daoist practitioner named Zhu Ruzi. At the end of the Wu dynasty, he entered the mountains, where he ingested chrysanthemum and atractylodes. Later, he encountered Xi Gui Zi, from whom he begged the method of transcending the world. Xi Gui Zi transmitted to him essential instructions and the *Method of Visualizing the Mud-Pill Palace*. After thirty years of practice, he could summon clouds and rain within his grotto chamber. On the fifth day of the eighth month this year, the Queen Mother of the West dispatched an envoy to welcome him. That very day, he ascended to heaven in a five-colored cloud chariot. He now dwells on the Terrace of Accumulated Stones. (It is said that Red Water Mountain lies ten *li* south of {Jin Yi} County, accessible by entering three hundred *li* from Nanxi Mouth. The mountain is entirely red, fifty *li* in circumference, and over a thousand *zhang* in height. This should correspond to the Red Rock in the northeast of Yongjia in Linhai. The Red Mountain where Master Xu resided, also called Burning Mountain, is this same place.)

In the Five Sacred Peaks and other renowned mountains, Daoist practitioners number in the hundreds of thousands. This year alone, those who attained the Dao and ascended to heaven are too numerous to record by name. Every year, every month, there are those who depart. Such accounts cannot be exhaustively chronicled; here, only those who attained the Dao in a single year are briefly noted. Some, though unwilling to ascend as immortals, remain for long ages in the Five Peaks and famous mountains—their number is likewise beyond reckoning. Others serve as immortal officials, charged with overseeing the sacred mountains, and these, too, number in the thousands.

On the twentieth night of the ninth month, the *Record of the Pure Numinous* was issued. (The preceding eight entries were transcribed by an assistant and compiled into a single scroll. *Pure Numinous* here refers to Pei Qingling. This ninth month should correspond to the *yichou* year, recording those who attained the Dao within that year.)

Wu Mu was a man of Chang’an. In his youth, he served as a county clerk, abusing his office to extort the people. When the people brought suit against him, the law demanded his execution. Mu fled in panic, escaping deep into the mountains and forests. After days without food, he came upon a stone chamber where he found Master Sun engaged in reclusive study. Around the chamber, millet and sesame were planted, and the room was always filled with food. Mu arrived and begged for sustenance, remaining for over a month without leaving.

Le was the "lesser Hu.")

In Mount Xiaobai, there was a Daoist practitioner named Zhao Guangxin, a man from Yangcheng. At the end of the Wei dynasty, he crossed the Yangtze and entered these mountains. He received from Li Facheng the method of ingestion and from his master Zuo Jun the *Way of Guarding the Dark Center*, through which he perceived the five viscera and mastered the art of penetrating vision. After seventy or eighty years of such practice, he traveled among commanderies and states.

chunks.translated_text:
Sun the Master knew he was a fugitive but initially made no inquiry. He gave him food, tended to his needs, and taught him scriptures and the Dao, expounding on fortune and misfortune. Upon hearing this, Mu’s heart opened and his mind awakened. He knocked his head to the ground, striking his chest in remorse, confessing the origins of his deeds, the conduct of his life, and the facts of his crimes. He begged for a chance to reform. Thereupon, he remained in the stone chamber, sweeping and serving the Master. After forty years, the Master transmitted the Dao to him. Together they gathered herbs and consumed sesame, diligently cultivating the scriptural teachings. After three hundred and twenty years, he ingested the elixir and ascended to heaven in broad daylight.

Zhu {Quantu} was a man of Chenliu. He was lawless, devoting himself to robbery and banditry. Later, when his crimes were discovered and men came to seize him, {Quantu} escaped and fled far to another region. He arrived at Shaoshi Mountain in Runan, where he encountered Master Feng engaged in reclusive study. The Master said that after three years, he would transmit to him the Way of the Perfected Immortals. He remained in the mountains, consuming herbs and cultivating the Dao for thirty-eight years. Later, he entered the Eastern Mountains, living to the age of one hundred and forty-seven. An immortal descended and led him into the cavern of Dayou Mountain, where he became a Perfected One.

Guo Jing was a man of Yingchuan. Orphaned in youth, he had no parents, and his brothers lived in poverty and hardship.

chunks.original_text: 依栖无所。 年十六。 县召为吏。 后得罪。 仍逃伏。 经二月日不出。 遇见郑先生。 救度一切。 以法劝化之。 静遂随郑。 负檐驱使。 经七年。 不敢懈怠。 遂受其导引之要。 饵服山朮茯苓。 得寿三百岁。 复于天维山。 赤松子降受其二人真道。 今在大有洞中为真人。 范伯慈者桂阳人也。 家本事俗。 而忽得狂邪。 因成邪劳病。 顿卧床席。 经年。 迎师解事费用。 家资渐尽。 病故不愈。 闻大道清约无所用。 于是意变。 闻沈敬作道士精进。 理病多验。 乃弃俗事之。 得五十日。 病疾都愈云云。 后诣陆玩之。 受真内道。 玩之不能入山。 伯慈不乐于世。 遂辞去入天目山。 服食胡麻。 精思十七年。 大洞真仙司命君下降。 受三十六篇经。 后服还丹。 白日升天。 今为玄一真人。 （所注云云云处。 是抄事人不能并取。 非本阙也。 有四条。 有人于东间钞得。 云是真书。 而不知谁迹。 亦无所受者。 而辞旨有用。 故纪续之。 又此四人各有所明。 一则酷吏。 二则凶劫。 三则孤茕。 四是事俗。 并世间薄运。 遂能得道。 足知心之所造。 非关善恶者也） 司马季主后入委羽山石室大有宫中。 受石精金光藏景化形法于西灵子都。 西灵子都者太玄仙女也。 其同时今在大有室中者。 广宁鲍叔阳。
chunks.translated_text:
With nowhere to settle, he wandered without refuge. At sixteen, the county summoned him to serve as an official. Later, he committed an offense and fled into hiding, remaining concealed for two months without emerging. He encountered Master Zheng, who saved and delivered all beings, exhorting him with the Dharma. Jing then followed Zheng, carrying his eaves and tending to his needs for seven years without敢懈怠. He received the essentials of Daoist guiding and pulling, consuming mountain yam and poria. He attained a lifespan of three hundred years. Later, on Tianwei Mountain, Master Red Pine descended to transmit the true Dao to both of them. Now, he resides in the cavern of Dayou as a Perfected One.

Fan Boci was a man of Guiyang. His family originally followed worldly customs, but he suddenly fell into madness and evil influences, contracting a consumptive illness that confined him to his bed for over a year. His family invited physicians and expended their wealth, yet his condition remained incurable. Hearing that the Great Dao was pure and required no offerings, his resolve shifted. Learning of Shen Jing’s diligent cultivation as a Daoist and his efficacy in healing, he abandoned worldly affairs to follow him. After fifty days, all his ailments were cured. Later, he sought out Lu Wanzhi to receive the true inner Dao. Wanzhi could not enter the mountains, but Boci, discontent with the world, bid farewell and entered Tianmu Mountain. There, he consumed sesame and cultivated with focused intent for seventeen years. The Perfected Lord of the Great Cavern and Controller of Destiny descended to transmit the thirty-six-scroll scripture. Later, he ingested the returning elixir and ascended to heaven in broad daylight. Now, he is the Perfected One of Mysterious Unity.

*(The passages marked "云云" were omitted by the copyist, not due to any lacuna in the original. There are four entries, transcribed by someone in the eastern region who claimed them to be authentic texts, though their authorship and transmission remain unknown. As their content is meaningful, they are recorded here in continuation.)*

These four individuals each had their own circumstances: the first was a harsh official, the second a violent bandit, the third orphaned and destitute, and the fourth bound to worldly affairs—all enduring the meager fortunes of the mortal realm. Yet they attained the Dao, demonstrating that its realization depends on the mind’s creation, not on good or evil.

Sima Jizhu later entered the stone chamber of the Weiyu Mountain’s Dayou Palace, where he received the *Method of Transforming Form through Stone Essence and Golden Radiance* from Xiling Zidu. Xiling Zidu was the Celestial Maiden of Supreme Mystery. Among those who now reside in the Dayou chamber with him is Bao Shuyang of Guangning.

chunks.translated_text:
The men of Taiyuan, Wang Yangbo, and of Yingchuan, Liu Yuwei, as well as Duan Jizheng of Daijun, all received the Dao from their master, Xiling Zidu. As Jizhu prepared to depart, he left behind a simulacrum of himself upon his pillow and mat to serve as his likeness. His tomb lies south of Shengpan Mountain in Chengdu of Shu Commandery. In former times, Marquis Wu of the Zhuge clan erected a stele before Jizhu’s tomb to inscribe his virtue. At the end of the stele’s eulogy, it reads:

*"In the vast and silent mystery,
Yin and Yang merge as one.
Heaven and Earth unite in balance,
And the ten thousand beings flourish in clarity.
The Master’s principles are manifest—
Discerning softness and hardness.
Spirits and gods bear witness,
While the Six Perfections shine forth."*

(*The* Zhen Gao *states that Jizhu swallowed rainbow essence, yet his head and feet came to rest in separate places. The commentary to the* Sword Classic *says, ‘He ingested the elixir blade, and worms flowed from his body.’ Now, according to the account of the Eastern Minister, he left behind a simulacrum upon his pillow and mat to serve as his likeness—this likely refers to his departure through the ‘spirit-pill transmigration’ method. Since the Han histories do not clearly record his end, there is no way to further discern the details of the matter.*)

The Guangning Master Bao Shuyang was a grandee under King Zhang Er and King Zhang Ao of Zhao during the reign of Emperor Gao of Han. From youth, he cultivated longevity practices. After ingesting cassia powder, he died suddenly in a privy. His tomb now lies on the northern mountain of Jicheng in Liaodong. (Emperor Gao established the Yan Commandery, with Ji as its seat—this likely refers to the time before its division.)

The Taiyuan Master Wang Yangbo was originally Wang Tan, a Palace Attendant and Zhonglang of Langye during the regency of Empress Lü under Emperor Gao of Han. From youth, he consumed *ze xie*. Together with the Marquis of Liu, Zhang Liang, he gathered herbs on Mount Zhongnan, but Wang Yangbo did not keep pace. He then became a disciple of Jizhu. (In the Former Han, Palace Attendants were not eunuchs, and Zhonglang was not an office of the Gentlemen of the Palace—this position may have been established later.)

The Yingchuan Master Liu Hui was originally Liu Feng, a Master of Public Carriages under Emperor Jing of Han. Later, he studied under Jizhu. In his later years, he ingested the essences of the sun and moon, becoming an inner-chamber disciple. After attaining the Dao, he returned to his hometown in his later years. Leaving behind his form in staff and sandals, he died beneath a mulberry tree. His tomb now lies on the western mountain of Ancheng County in Runan.

The Daijun Master Duan Jizheng was originally a recluse. No records exist of his ingestions. In his later years, he studied the Dao under Jizhu.

chunks.translated_text:
Crossing the Qinzhou Reedy Waters, he was detained and drowned, his body recovered and buried by the riverbank. This is present-day Qinchuan in Nanzheng. This man was also an inner-chamber disciple of Jizhu. (Upon examining these four individuals, all employed the arts of the Spirit Pellet and miscellaneous liberations.)

Jizhu had one son and one daughter, both of whom attained the Dao. The son was named Fayu, and the daughter was named Jihua. Both now reside within Mount Weiyu. Jihua is presently reciting the Thirty-Nine Chapters, though she has yet to complete them. (This principle is also difficult to expound in detail.)

Jizhu recited the Jade Scripture and ingested the essence of Bright Cinnabar. His hands cradled the radiance of dawn, and his complexion today remains that of a twenty-year-old maiden. His beard measures three feet in length, black as ink. Yesterday, the Eastern Minister recounted this, just as I have set it down—truly a wondrous affair. Yet I know not how it may truly be. (This line was recorded by Master Yang in a letter to the Prefectural Governor. The phrase of uncertainty may indicate another meaning.)

Jizhu relinquished his form and concealed his light, hiding his traces in Mount Weiyu. The *Purple Yang Tradition* fully records these matters. Last night, the Eastern Minister arrived, and I ventured to inquire about Jizhu’s origins and later years. The Eastern Minister responded, instructing me to set it down separately, as presented above. I hope you will not take offense. Once read, consign it to the flames. (This is Master Yang’s letter to the Prefectural Governor. The *Biographies of Perfected Transcendents* compiled by Zhou Jun of present times records Jizhu’s affairs only briefly. No other authentic handwritten account has been seen. Judging by these words, it appears to be incorrect. It seems there was a preceding annotation, but one line is now missing.)

What follows is the record of the Sagely Master Li. In general, it aligns with the foregoing, though the Eastern Minister has additionally provided annotations. The annotations approach ten thousand characters—a most extraordinary work. Recently, we have discussed many matters of divine transformation, and Jizhu’s case was briefly mentioned. Last month, I was further entrusted with the *Commentary on the Scripture of the Divine Tiger*. The commentary is unlike anything heard in the world, and I myself do not yet grasp its purport. Should I learn of others like Jizhu, I shall certainly report it in confidence. (This is also Master Yang’s letter to the Prefectural Governor. Since it concerns Jizhu’s affairs, I have placed it in sequence here rather than appending it to the lower scroll. The Prefectural Governor, compiling the *Biographies of Perfected Transcendents*, wished to place Jizhu first. Thus, Master Yang sought to inquire about his origins and later years. The two scriptures annotated by the Director of Destinies have yet to be revealed to the world.)

The above ten entries contain Yang’s writings. Fan Anyuan recently remarked, “Zhanzi did not serve the Qi.”

chunks.translated_text:
The Qi forces attacked him. The *Commentary on the Spring and Autumn Annals* states: "Zhan was without propriety." (This refers to an event in the *Zuozhuan*. The character {言甚} is written as 谭. Its pronunciation is *tan*. It is the name of a state. In the thirteenth year of Duke Zhuang’s reign, it was destroyed by Duke Huan of Qi. The reason for recounting this here is unclear, though it seems to allude to something.)

Zhuangzi studied under Master Changsang, who transmitted to him esoteric teachings, whence he was called Zhuangzi. He concealed himself on Mount Baodu, ingested the Northern Nurturing Fire Elixir, and ascended to heaven in broad daylight, whereupon he was appointed to the rank of Attendant Gentleman of the Gate of the Supreme Ultimate. (Master Changsang was the teacher of Bian Que, as recorded in the *Wei Chronicles* and the *Records of the Grand Historian*. If the world truly knew Zhuangzi to have been such a figure, his writings would be all the more esteemed.)

Shi Cun was a native of Qi who styled himself the "Gentle Basin Master." He attained the Dao of escape, transformation, and luminous manifestation, and now resides on Mount Song. Some say that in the past, there was a Master Gourd on Mount Shaoshi—this was none other than he. However, he has not yet received the scriptures of the Most High, and thus has not yet attained Perfection. His practice of the Jade Axe and the Military Fire Talismans represents but a branch of what he has received. Shi Cun was among the three thousand disciples of Confucius. (That one of the three thousand should be such a figure, yet not numbered among the seventy-two, makes clear that the Master did not teach the Dao of immortality. Master Gourd was the teacher of Fei Changfang. The Military Fire Talisman remains extant in the world. The above three entries contain Yang’s writings.)

Han Weiyuan, the Perfected One of Mount Jiuyi, once received teachings from Song Dexuan of Mount Song. Dexuan was a man of the Zhou King Xuan era.

chunks.translated_text:
Those who ingest this *Lingfei Liujia* attain the Dao, gaining the ability to travel three thousand *li* in a single day and repeatedly transform their forms into birds and beasts. Having obtained the Way of the Dark and Numinous, they now dwell on Mount Songgao. Weiyuan followed them for a long time before receiving the method, and through its practice, he achieved the completion of the Way. He now resides on Mount Jiuyi. Among his female disciples were Guo Shaoyao, Zhao Aier, Wang Lulian, and others—several dozen in all—who likewise received this method and attained the Dao. Some roam the Dark Continent, while others dwell on the Eastern Florescence Terrace or the Square Cauldron Terrace; all remain present today.

Just as someone attempted to examine it, the sword suddenly flew into the heavens. Luan Ba once achieved liberation through martial transformation, departing to reside in Mount Linlü. After thirteen years, he returned home and now dwells in Mount Chimei Redstone. (*The Book of Han* states that Luan Ba served as governor of Guiyang and Yuzhang before being imprisoned and executed—this was likely a case of using the *Lingwan* elixir for liberation, as also recorded in the *Transmissions of the Immortals*.)

These three accounts are all excerpted from the hand-copied *Sword Scripture*, a text not easily encountered. Since they describe the deeds of various immortals, I have carefully transcribed them here to supplement the categories. Where do the perfected ones reside? Radiant as the southern star, they embrace the myriad ages, ascending on light to revolve above. Transforming into the Three Ways, with the sun and moon as neighbors, they are truly profound, truly masters—known as the Primal Ones. Changing into the Three Elders, they befriend the ancestors of emperors. How could one know the perfected? They do not come to wander, observing the signs of transformation among mortals, blending with the world as companions. Casting off their feathers and sinking their bells, they rest in the southern lands—how could they delight in omens, lingering long among the俗?

He is the teacher of the Celestial Thearch’s Four Perfected Ones and the companion of the Great One.

Mount Tongbai rises eighteen thousand *zhang* high. Its eightfold ridges encircle over eight hundred *li*, appearing identical from all four sides. It stands at the eastern sea’s edge in Kuaiji, one end submerged in the ocean. Within Tongbai lies the Land of Immortality of Golden Court, forty *li* in circumference, veiled by yellow clouds. Its trees bear jade-teeth and sapphire fruits; its springs flow with stone marrow and golden essence. The mountain is wholly composed of five-colored gold. Journeying south along the Cinnabar River, one finds a cavern where paths converge—passing through it for over thirty *li* leads to the destination.

(This mountain now lies within the borders of several counties, including Linhai. The submerged end is today called Kuocang, situated north of Ninghai County and south of {Jin Yi}. This mountain is the dwelling place of many perfected transcendents and immortals. These two mountains serve as the markers of the Yang Nine and Hundred Six kalpas. When the Hundred Six kalpa approaches, the waters of Yang Perpetuity Mountain recede, while those of Yin Completeness Mountain rise. When the Yang Nine kalpa approaches, the waters of Yin Completeness recede, while those of Yang Perpetuity rise. (When the water’s edge of Yin Completeness emerges so high above the mountain, this should correspond to the Yang Nine kalpa, yet it is spoken of as the Hundred Six—this may be a misstatement. Alternatively, it could mean the water’s rise has reached such a height, not that the water first receded. Yet water seeks its own level and is not swift or turbulent. The two mountains are not far apart; how could one stand so abruptly isolated?)

The following two entries were transcribed by the Senior Scribe: Before reaching the first high mountain west of the temple, at the northern end of Dragon’s Tail, there is a great spring. It bursts forth from the earth, over six *zhang* in length and five *zhang* in width, penetrating six *chi* into the ground. Its flow strikes the earth for over two hundred *bu* before diverging three *li* from the road. Opposite the second high mountain west of the temple’s rear, there is another great spring. It emerges from the earth, over four *zhang* in length and three *chi* in width, penetrating four *chi* into the ground. Its force scours the earth for over three hundred *bu* before diverging two *li* from the road. Near the temple’s rear flank, there is yet another great spring. It issues from the earth, over five *zhang* in length and four *zhang* in width, penetrating slightly over two *chi* into the ground. Its flow converges inward, one hundred fifty *bu* from the temple.

North of Jiang Mountain, there are three such erupting springs, their currents flowing northwest. These three entries record strange phenomena, yet as no eyewitness account exists, their veracity remains uncertain. It is also unknown when these eruptions occurred. To the south of the mountain, there are documented sites of such outflows, now blocked with piled stones and called "Jiang Hou’s Watering Place." No such traces are found behind the mountain—perhaps these mark the appointed time of a future kalpa.

At times, it resembles passing through city gates where documents are inspected—likely all occurring within the outer palaces atop this mountain. As with Humu Ban’s journey to the Lord of Mount Tai’s abode, one may unknowingly enter the grotto. Perhaps ghosts and spirits are illusory, preventing mortals from perceiving the truth.

Those among the living who know the names of the Six Heavenly Palace Gates need only recite them thrice while facing north before sleep, in a low voice, and the hundred ghosts will not dare to harm them. (Earlier, they were called palace names; now, gate names. The gates derive their names from the palaces. The palaces are but empty titles, while the gates bear inscribed placards visible to all ghosts—and now to mortals as well, which is why they submit in awe.)

The incantation goes:
*"I am a disciple of the Most High, governing the Six Heavens below. The Six Heavenly Palaces are under my command—not only under my command, but under the authority of the Most High. I know the names of the Six Heavenly Palaces, and thus I attain longevity. Should any dare to transgress, the Most High shall sever your form."*

(Here, "governing the Six Heavens below" means they are not governed by the Six Heavens. Not only do I command them myself, but the Most High has ordered me to oversee them, thus reinforcing my authority—much like officials in commanderies and counties who receive imperial appointments, not mere blank commissions.)

The first palace is named the *Zhoujue Yintian Palace*. Proceeding eastward in order, the second palace is named— (These two characters in Yang Jun’s manuscript appear at the bottom of the page, but the copyist, unfamiliar with them, rendered them as seven characters. All contemporary versions mistakenly list this as the seventh palace. This is an error, for there are only six palaces—how could there be seven? The incantation’s phrase "proceeding eastward in order" is meant to astonish the ghosts by demonstrating knowledge of their sequential positions.)

Continuing in this manner through the sixth palace, one then taps the teeth six times before lying down, to ward off the qi of malevolent ghosts. (After reciting the incantation once and tapping the teeth six times, the process is repeated twice more before sleep.)

(This method has already been transcribed in detail in the third chapter on cultivation practices.)

When a person first dies, they all proceed to the *Zhoujue Yintian Palace* to receive their fate. Some may first go to famous mountains, Mount Tai, or rivers, but they do not necessarily go directly to the first heaven. Only on the day of their judgment—when their sins are examined and their fortune determined—must they come to this first heavenly palace. (This palace is governed by the Northern Emperor, and all matters must ultimately pass through it—like prefectural and county prisons, which, though initially under local jurisdiction, must eventually be sent to the capital for final sentencing.)

The *Tailiang Shizong Tian Palace* and its attendant ghosts constitute the second heaven. Those who die suddenly or violently also pass through here.

Wang Xiu served as *Langzhong Ling* under Emperor Wu of Wei. At the age of seven, he lost his mother. She died on a *du* day, but her surname and family remain unknown.

In his youth, the prefecture office had three notable figures: Wang Shaodao, Fan Shusheng, and Li Boshan—all paragons of the prefecture in their time. Shaodao was fond of the Dao and was the same Wang Dun’er who had been *Taishou* of Shanyang during the Han. Fan Shusheng was a native of Beidi and later served as *Huangmen Lang* under Emperor Wen of Wei. Li Boshan was the father of Li Chong, who had been *Ling* of Baima during the Han and practiced hidden virtues. Some inherit the Dao across generations, their virtue accumulating through the ages—such was the case with these two prefectures’ transcendents, who advanced step by step to enter this rank.

Xiang Liangcheng composed the *Palace Chant*, which reads:
*"Zhou’s end severed the imperial dawn,
In truth, affairs entangled in layered deceit.
Flaming as smoke in the vault of heaven,
Bursting like radiant brilliance.
Wuyang girds the divine blade,
Serene and luminous, swallowing the Azure River.
The gates of Chang swing open to the cinnabar well,
Cloud gates rise in towering majesty.
Seven wrongs traverse the wondrous canopy,
Linked bends spread their enchantments.
Six heavens bar the northern path—
This is the domain of ghosts and spirits."*

When a person lies in bed, the head must be raised high.
If raised high, the earthly *qi* will not reach upward,
and the ghosts will not blow upon them.
The *qi* of ghosts invading humans
always ascends from the earth below.

Ghosts—being yin in nature—
often rely on objects to disperse their *qi*.
They may attach to humans or beasts,
cling to vessels or utensils,
or lodge in food and drink,
only then unleashing their malevolence.
Once, a sick man lying on the ground
saw a ghost at the foot of his bed,
using its hand as a pipe to blow upon him—
this is the act of ghostly blowing.

When lying in a chamber,
one must keep it clean and well-ordered.
If clean and well-ordered, it receives pure *qi*;
if not, it receives impure *qi*.
Impure *qi* disrupting a chamber
will cause undertakings to fail
and actions to collapse.
Even one’s own body—
must be washed and bathed in purity.
Otherwise, there is no hope.

For ghosts and spirits are dust and turbidity incarnate,
and these things follow human wickedness.
Since they are restless and lack mastery,
how could the Dao be discussed?

Do not speak of the Dao while studying it.
If one speaks of the Dao while studying it,
ghosts will assail them,
and their undertakings will fail,
causing illness—
for their essence is not yet true.

(*The True Instructments* often warn against this:
Every word and deed, if revealed, diminishes one’s *ling* [灵].
How much more so for sickness?
What is called "transcendent" is achieved through sincere practice—
why seek to speak of it?
Demons lurk, ever watchful,
like echoes and shadows.)

Shān Shìyěn, after receiving the teachings of Master Mèng,
would lie down in the evening,
first reciting the *Huángtíng Nèijǐng Jīng* once before sleeping,
so that his soul and spirit might refine themselves.
If one practices this Dao for twenty-one years, they will become transcendent—
this is the fulfillment of ten thousand offenses.
Even three or four recitations are beneficial.
Lady Jiāng of Běiyuè said:
Reading this scripture also keeps one free of illness—
this is the Dao of immortality.

(These four principles are all worthy of adoption.
Their details are separately transcribed in the Third Section.)
