He lived to the age of one hundred and twenty-seven.
Later, he encountered an extreme cold snap and fell into the River of Longevity, drowning.
The Northern Sovereign’s officials also dispatched ghosts and calamity-demons of the sun to seize him,
yet these demons never dared approach him.
The Ghostly Bureau inquired as to why.
The Celestial replied:
*"This man was skilled in many magical arts,
by which he constrained us.
He habitually struck his teeth,
mimicking the thunderous beat of heavenly drums,
to awaken the spirits within his body.
The spirits dared not scatter,
and the ghostly *qi* could not penetrate.
Thus, he had no fateful connection to be taken."*

By this reasoning, had Báozhù not crossed the icy river,
he might well have lived beyond a thousand years.
Instead, during the severe cold, he walked upon the ice,
his mouth closed and unable to strike his teeth again—
thus, the ghosts seized him while he drowned in the river.

Even those afflicted with *miànfēng* whose teeth chatter uncontrollably
still repel death and ward off ghosts—
how much more so for a Daoist adept who deliberately strikes his teeth,
sounds the heavenly drums,
and fully invigorates his bodily spirits!

(The Daoist alchemical text states:

shortens one’s lifespan."*

In the past, there was a man named Báozhù from Jìběi.
(His name is obscure; it does not appear in external records.)
He never studied the Dao.
Nor did he know magical techniques.
At the age of over forty,
he suddenly contracted *miànfēng* [a wind-related facial disorder].
His mouth and eyes became misaligned.
When he opened his mouth, his upper and lower teeth would repeatedly strike against each other,
producing a loud sound.
This condition persisted day and night without cessation.

chunks.translated_text:
Human life has no fixed limit—
all that exists is premature death.
If one cultivates the Dao with diligence,
like Báozhù striking his teeth,
why should one not attain eternal years?
The true peril lies in occasional slackness,
when one is then seized by ghosts—
perishing like one drowned in the river.

As for all ghosts, they lack true wisdom;
they rely on wind-illness as their craft—
how could they overcome such folly?

---
In the **Doushan** [都山] realm,
trees, waters, and marshes resemble those of the mortal world.
Yet its rice grains are no larger than millet,
tasting like water chestnuts.
The other four grains are not so.
Only rice is called *Chóngsī* [重思]—
a name of great significance.

Du Qióng composed the *Ode to Chóngsī* [重思赋]:
*"Spring’s soft mist unfurls—
lush and verdant, the sacred grain.
The divine canopy spreads,
timely blessings for the people’s feast.
The four seasons’ harvests rejoice,
offerings made to the gods of grain.
The holy ears rise in abundance,
their vast stalks bending my dark hall.
Here, auspicious signs appear—
the Emperor’s radiance shines forth.
This is what is spoken of."*

(Here, it further speaks of **Doushan’s** affairs,
yet again returning to *Chóngsī*.
It says that those who worship the *Zhuren* [祝人]
must not partake in sacrificial feasting—
for this is the very act of offering to the Daoist officials, as previously stated.
Moreover, when a ghost’s lifespan is fulfilled,
it receives the remaining years of its host,
and upon death, sacrificial rites are held in its honor.)

Du Qióng, styled **Bóyú** [伯瑜],
a scholar from Shu [蜀],
was well-versed in learning and possessed literary talent.
He annotated the *Book of Songs* and mastered divination.
He could recall the events of the Wei dynasty as if they were contemporary,
and served under Liu Bei’s regime as **Honglu [鸿胪]** and **Taichang [太常]**.
He died in the **Yanxi [延熙] era’s** thirteenth year,
having lived past eighty.

Eight attendants served the Emperor at dawn:
Xu Shu, **Guanglong [广龙]**, Yuán Yú, Li Guang,
Wang Jia, Hé Yàn, Jié Jié, and Yīn Hào—
all like the **Shizhong [侍中]** of the mortal world.

(Li Guang, the **Xiáqí General [骁骑将军]** under Emperor Wu,
was accused by officials during his campaign against the Xiongnu.)

Xīn Guì [心貴] sighed and slit his own throat to die.
Wang Jia, a man of Shu Commandery,
served as a **Lángzhōng [郎中]** under Emperor Píng.
By the time of Wang Máng [王莽],
he abandoned his post and returned to his homeland,
refusing to submit to Sun Shù [孙述].
He died, sword in hand.

Xu Shu, styled **Fúzhí [符直]**
of Yǐngchuān [颖川],
recommended Zhuge Liang to Liu Bei.
Later, when Wei Wu [魏武] captured his mother,
he surrendered to the Wei.
He rose to the rank of **Zhōngchéng [中丞]**.
In the **Dàhé [大和]** era of Emperor Ming,
he died of illness.

Guanglong [廣龍] Dé, styled **Lìngmíng [令明]**
of Nán’ān [南安],
followed Zhang Zhen [張鎮] in surrendering to Wei Wu.
He was appointed **Lìyì Jiāngjūn [立義将军]**
and stationed at Fánchéng [樊城],
but was slain by Guan Yu.
He was posthumously honored as **Dú Hóu [杜侯]**
and buried in **Yèyì [業邑]**
with his head and body intact, as if alive.

Yuán Yú, styled **Shìdū [世都]**
of Píyáng [濮陽],
was eloquent and skilled in arts and techniques.
He served under Jin Wu [晉武],
was summoned to the **Sītú [司徒]** Wei Shu’s [魏舒] household,
and reached the position of **Shìzhōng [侍中] Zhōngshū Shìng [中書令]**.
Jié Jié, styled **Zìlián [稚連]**
of Jǐnán [濟南],
was his younger brother.
He once served under Jin as **Huángmén Shìláng [黃門侍郎] Zhōngchéng [中丞] Jīngyù Zhōuzhìshǐ [荊豫州刺史] Shàngshū [尚書]**.
During the reign of Zhao Wang Lún [趙王倫],
he was killed by Sun Xiù [孙秀].

Hé and Yīn [何、殷], the two mentioned earlier,
were of the eight who served before—
only Dào [道] and Dé [德] remain.
Now I must ask further:
Who are these four who serve at dawn?

Among them are **Sìmíng Gōng [四明公]** and **Běidǒu Jūn [北斗君]**.
They are like the five who serve at dawn—
the eight from before were merely officials under the Northern Great Emperor.
Their selection and use were also the same.

(The title *sìdì chén* [侍帝晨] also applies to the *xiān guān* [仙官].
Both hold the rank of *shìzhōng* [侍中].
This passage states their selection and use were identical—
whether it means only their titles and positions,
or evaluating their talent and insight while also considering their merits and virtue,
is unclear.
These individuals’ talents and stations
were forever unlike one another.
Perhaps in the **Yōutú** [幽途] they are distinguished differently.)

There are also four **Zhōngláng Zhíshì [中郎直事]**, akin to the **Shàngshū [尚書]** of the mortal world:
Dài Yuān, Gōngsūn Dù [公孙度],
Liú Fēng, and Guō Jiā.
Now they are seen in office—
Liú Fēng was the adopted son of Xuán Dé [玄德].
(This office should be the **Tàidì Lǐngliáo [太帝領僚]**, now equivalent to the *sàncáo shàngshū* [散曹尚書].
Dài Yuān, styled **Ruòyú [若愚]**
of Guǎnglíng [廣陵],
served under Jin, advancing through the ranks to **Hùjūn Shàngshū [护军尚书]**, **Pūshè [仆射]**, and **Piáojì Jiāngjūn [骠骑将军]**.)

Guō Jiā.

With Zhou [Yè] together perished at the hands of Wang Dun.
He was posthumously honored as *Guānglù* [光禄], and his posthumous title was *Jiǎn Hóu* [简侯].

Public Sun Du, styled **Shūjì** [叔济], was of Liaodong.
He was the ancestor of Yuān.
Initially, he served as Governor of Liaodong.
During the *Jiàn’ān* era, he usurped the throne and proclaimed himself king,
establishing imperial insignia and passing the *zhuànguó* [传国] heir to his son, Kāng.
His grandson, Yuān, was captured by Sīmǎ Xuānwáng [司马宣王].

**Liú Fēng**, originally of the Kòu clan of Luóhóu [罗侯],
was the adopted son of Liu Bei when the latter had no heir.
By nature fierce and bold, he possessed strength, martial skill, and qi.
Later, he was granted a command and executed.
This was a case of an outsider inheriting the surname—
yet he still managed to assume the lineage.

**Guō Jiā**, styled **Fèngxiào** [奉孝],
was from Yǐngchuān Yǔ [颖川阳翟].
A strategist for Wéiwǔ, he served as *jūn móu jìjiào* [军谋祭酒].
He died of illness at thirty-eight.
His posthumous title was *Zhēn Hóu* [真侯].

**Xuán Dé** now holds the title *Běihé Hóu* [北河侯],
ruling alongside Hàn Suì.
He is now under the *Xiān Guān* [仙官].
(The *Xiān Guān* also includes the *Běihé Sīmìng Jìn Bǎo Hóu* [北河司命禁保侯],
who oversees matters of the Three Officials [Sān Guān],
belonging to the *Dōnghuá Guān* [东华官], led by the *Bǎomìng Jūn* [保命君].
This must mean the *Běihé Hóu* is subordinate to them.)

**Liú Bèi**, styled **Xuán Dé**, was of his native commandery.
He first raised an army in rebellion,
later seizing Shu and assuming imperial titles.
After three years, he died of illness at sixty-three.
His posthumous title was *Zhāoliè Huángdì* [昭烈皇帝].
At the time, he was one of the Three Sovereigns alongside Wéiwǔ Sūn Céng.
Though his rank was low, being under the *Xiān Guān*,
his merit may yet compare favorably.

**Hàn Suì**, styled **Wén Jiǎo** [文纣],
was from [omitted].
At the end of the Han, he led armies and sowed chaos in the western lands.
In the twenty-fifth year of *Jiàn’ān*, Wéiwǔ launched a campaign against him.
Suì fled to Jīnchéng, where he was killed by his own generals, including **Móu Yǎn** [麴演].
Though bold and fierce, he could not escape calamity—
yet he was granted the honor of serving alongside Liu Bei in the *Xiān Guān*,
further elevated in rank.

There are also two *Dà Jìn Chén* [大禁晨], equivalent to the *Shàngshū Lìng* [尚书令].
These were held by Hàn Guāngwǔ and Sūn Wéntái.
(Hàn Guāngwǔ, Liu Xiù, styled **Wénshū** [文叔],
was the eighth-generation descendant of the High Ancestor.
He raised armies to overthrow Wang Mang and the Chìmǐ,
pacifying the realm.)

Sūn Jiān, styled **Wén Tái** [文台], was a native of Wú Commandery. He was the father of Sūn Quán. Clǎn Shù recommended him as the *Pò Lǔ Jiāngjūn Yùzhōu Shìshǐ* [破虏将军豫州刺史], leading the campaign against Dòng Zhuō. Later, he attacked Liú Biǎo. In the second year of *Chūpíng*, he was killed by an archer under the command of Liú Biǎo’s general, Huáng Zǔ, at the age of thirty-seven. Though loyal and valiant, his station was humble, yet he now shares rank with the Son of Heaven—much like Hàn Suì’s parallel with Guāndì [玄德].

(Yán Huái, styled **Sī Jì**, was a man whose worth was yet to be fully realized. Yáng Biāo, styled **Wén Xiān**, hailed from Hóngnóng. He was the father of Yáng Xíu, the Han *Sīkōng* [司空]. During the chaos of Dòng Zhuō’s rebellion, he supported and protected the Emperor Xiàndì. The **Nánbā Hóu** (南巴侯, Marquis of Nanba) was **Hé Céng** (何曾), whose style name was *Yǐngkǎo* (颖考). A native of **Yángxià** (阳夏) in **Chénjùn** (陈郡), he was the son of **Hé Zǐ** (何子). By nature, he was extravagant yet well-versed in learning, and practiced filial piety and fraternal respect. Initially serving under the **Wèi** (魏), he later rose to the positions of **Shàngshū** (尚书), **Zhēngběi Jiāngjūn** (征北将军), and **Sì Tú** (司徒). He was ennobled as **Lánglíng Hóu** (朗陵侯). In the **Jìn** (晋) dynasty, he held the titles of **Tàishǐ** (太尉), **Tàibǎo** (太保), and **Tàizǎi** (太宰) as **Lánglíng Gōng** (朗陵公). He died in the **Tàishǐ Sìnián** (太始四年) era, at over eighty years of age, and was posthumously honored with the title **Yuángōng** (元公).

**Cáo Rén** (曹仁), whose style name was *Zǐxiào* (子孝), was **Wèi Wǔ** (魏武) Emperor **Cáo Cāo**’s (曹操) younger brother. Renowned for his valor and archery, he often accompanied campaigns with distinction. His rank eventually reached **Chēqí Jiāngjūn** (车骑将军) and **Dūdū Yángyǐng Yìzhōu Zhūjūn Shì Dà Jiāngjūn** (都督荆扬益州诸军事大将军). He was ennobled as **Chén Hóu** (陈侯). He died of illness in the **Huángchū Sìnián** (黄初四年) era, at fifty-six years of age, and was posthumously honored as **Zhōnghóu** (忠侯).

As for **Liú Táo** (刘陶) serving as **Dōngyuè Dà Jiāngjūn** (东越大将军), there were three such figures across the **Hàn** (汉), **Wèi** (魏), and **Jìn** (晋) dynasties. The **Hòuhàn** (后汉) one bore the style name *Zǐqí* (子奇) and was from **Yǐngchuān** (颖川). He served as **Língdì** (灵帝) Emperor’s **Shìzhōng** (侍中) and **Shàngshū Lìng** (尚书令). Later, he was imprisoned and died in confinement. The **Wèi** (魏) one bore the style name *Jìyǎo* (季冶) and was from **Huáinán** (淮南), the son of **Liú Yè** (刘晔). Though skilled in debate, he lacked moral conduct. **Cáo Shǎo** (曹爽) appointed him as **Xuǎnbù Láng** (选部郎), but he was later executed as **Píngyuán Tàishǒu** (平源太守) by **Jìngwáng** (景王). Xún **Zǐqí** (荀｛岂页｝) served as **Tàishān Jūn** (太山君).

(Xún **Zǐqí**, style name *Jǐngqiàn* (景倩), was the fourth son of **Xún Yú** (荀丕). He was well-versed in learning and possessed eloquence and logical reasoning. He assisted the **Jìn** (晋) dynasty’s establishment. Beginning from a lowly position, he became a **Huángmén Láng** (黄门郎), then successively held the offices of **Shàngshū Púshè** (尚书仆射), **Sìkōng** (司空), **Tàiyè** (太尉), and **Tàifù** (太傅). He passed away in the tenth year of the **Tàishǐ** (太始) era, at the age of seventy, and was posthumously honored as **Kāng Gōng** (康公). According to **Sū Yáo** (苏韶)'s *Transmission* (传云), **Liú Kǒngcái** (刘孔才) served as **Tàishān Gōng** (太山公) and plotted to rebel against the **Northern Dì** (北帝). He was later executed and eradicated. **Kǒngcái** (孔才) was none other than **Liú Shào** (刘邵).

Additionally, **Méi Yí** (梅颐) held the post of **Yùzhāng Tàishǒu** (豫章太守). In a dream, he was summoned to serve as **Tàishān Fǔjūn** (太山府君). Upon waking, he died shortly thereafter. It remains unclear whether these two positions were distinct from that of **Tàishān Jūn** (太山君).

It is also said that there existed a **Tàishān Lìng** (太山令), commanding a force of ten thousand soldiers to garrison a location—such garrisons numbered several hundred in total. Some commanded garrisons of several thousand soldiers, all subordinate to one another. Each had a **Chángshǐ** (长史) and **Sīmǎ** (司马).

**Wáng Wéndù** (王文度) was stationed in **Guǎnglíng** (广陵). Suddenly, he saw a soldier appear and summon him, saying, *"You are to be appointed as **Píngběi Jiāngjūn** (平北将军) and **Sìshǐ** (刺史) of **Xú** (徐) and **Dài** (兖) states."* **Wáng** (王) replied, *"I have already been appointed to this office."* The soldier said, *"This is a celestial appointment."* In a short while, the soldier vanished, and soon afterward, **Wáng** was led away and died.

The **Dao/Way** (天地间事理) of existence transcends human understanding and cannot be fathomed by mere conjecture. Even in the unseen and visible realms, there are three categories: **xiān** (仙, the celestial), **rén** (人, the human), and **guǐ** (鬼, the spectral). Those who cultivate virtue may ascend to become **xiān** (celestial beings). Those who are exiled from the celestial realm may reincarnate as humans. The wicked among humans may descend to become **guǐ** (spectral beings). The fortunate among **guǐ** may return to human form. **Guǐ** (spectral beings) emulate humans, while humans emulate **xiān** (celestial beings). This cyclical transformation follows patterns, with each category mirroring the others in kind. It is merely a subtle distinction between the hidden and the manifest.

The enlightened observe this **Dao/Way** (达者监之) and thus find no further cause for concern.

The Prefect of Kuàijì departed in the eleventh year of **Yǒnghé** (永和). He declared, *"My spirit shall not return to office."* Earlier, he had frequented **Xǔ Xiānshēng** (許先生, *Master Xu*), and though he had some admiration for the Dao, by the fifth year of **Shēngpíng** (升平), in the year **Xīnyǒu** (辛酉), he died at the age of fifty-nine.

In the year **Yǐchǒu** (乙丑), it was said that five years had passed since his death. Yet, he was still imprisoned—though no record of his offense could be found. It was feared that his imprisonment was due to lingering resentment in his heart, and that his spirit had been exiled.

Serving under the **Hàn** and **Wèi**, he rose to the position of **Tàiyè** (太尉, *Grand Tutor*). The **Morning Crown and Azure Sash**—
the rustling sleeves of feathered grace,
the chime of bells upon celestial steps,
the turning of jade halls—

Though the heart remains pure yet the sun sets,
I lament not yet ascending to join the **Mysterious True**,
to rank alongside **Yùkūn** and **Tǔyōng** in serene repose.
I hear the lingering strains of the **Divine Music**,
plucking **spirit-mushrooms** from the hidden peaks,
shaking my emerald robes in the Nine Heavens,
dancing the **Dark Feathers** of the Ten Directions.

Now I must govern the host of ghosts,
judge right from wrong,
dwelling amid the filth of mortals,
my voice mingling with the clamor of demons.
My deeds stray from **Dao and Virtue**,
my gaze falters before the True.
Yet I compare my stillness to the **Silent Void**,
soaring free in the **Primordial Beginning**.

For harmony unites like sounds,
and kindred things share their nature—
thus I am called to the **Upper Clarity**,
my name inscribed in the **Cinnabar Register** of the **Mysterious Seed**.
The **Qi of the Dao** merges with the **Virtue of the Spirit**,
my luminous form ascends in splendor—
that is why they come to follow.

Now I present three poems,
to express the depth of my esteem.

Zhou Bó-rén has recently been appointed as the **Central Protector of Ximing Gong [西明公中都护]**. The **Central Protector** is an office akin to that of the **Grand Tutor of the Realm [世太傅]**. He served under the Jin as **Master of the Imperial Heir’s Attendants [太子洗马]**, **Minister of Personnel [吏部郎]**, and **Governor of Hedong [河东太守]**. He was captured by **Shí Lè [石勒]** but later returned to the east, becoming **Governor of Wujun [吴郡太守]** and **Minister of Personnel [吏部尚书]**. He died of illness in the first year of **Xiánhé [咸和]**, aged forty-seven, and was posthumously honored as **Lord of Light [光禄]**. When **Yōu Bùpíng** returned from rebellion with the Hu, he abandoned his own son and brought only his younger brother’s child across the river. Thus, he had no descendants, leaving no heirs. **Xiè Àn [谢安]** sighed, *"Heaven’s ways are inscrutable—why did **Yōu Bódào [攸伯道]** have no son?"*

The above is what **Xīn Xuánzǐ [辛玄子]** spoke of—his accounts of the **Netherworld [冥中]** are numerous. Here, I have only roughly recorded the **fragmentary [鹿鹿鹿]** portions, without elaborating further. (Though this record is from **Xuánzǐ’s** teachings, it also includes words from **Yang Jun [杨君]**. Yang’s original text is lost, and only a copyist’s draft remains. The manuscript was later partially cut away, so the accounts may not be entirely complete.)

Those of **utter loyalty and filial piety**, upon death, receive the **Scripture [书]** to become **Netherworld Rulers [地下主]**. After **one hundred and forty years**, they are granted instruction in **Lower Dao [下仙之教]** and taught the **Great Way [大道]**. From then on, they gradually ascend, eventually **supplementing the ranks of the Immortals [补仙官]**. After another **one hundred and forty years**, they are permitted a **trial advancement [试进]**. (These **Netherworld Rulers** are the same as those recorded in the **Cavern Texts [洞中所记]**—such as **Lǐ [李] (East)**—not separate ghostly officials appointed anew. Each **one hundred and forty years** marks a promotion to the next rank, where they serve as **Immortal Envoys [仙人使]**, only then beginning to receive Daoist teachings.)

The **filially pious** can move **ghosts and spirits**, causing **birds and beasts of the mountains** to guard their tombs **[巡其坟土延]**. The **utterly loyal** act with **unwavering rectitude**, their **essence piercing the sun [精贯白日]**, or even **severing their own bodies** to inspire their rulers. **Bǐ Gān [比干]** now resides at **Róngshān [戎山]**, while **Lǐ Shàn [李善]** is at **Shàoshì [少室]**. Many have undergone such **transmutations [变鍊]**, but these two serve as examples. (Bǐ Gān’s **severed heart** exemplifies **utter loyalty**, while accounts of filial sons moving spirits are also numerous. Yet here, only **Lǐ Shàn** is mentioned—his case seems misplaced, as his deeds align more with **loyalty than filial piety**. Perhaps it is because he preserved **Lǐ Yuán’s [李元] lineage**, ensuring succession, thus fulfilling filial duty. The merits of such acts need not be debated further. Figures like **Chéng Yīng [程婴]** and **Qí Sūn Qiújiù [齐孙杵臼]** should also be counted among the **filially pious**.)

**Lǐ Shàn**, styled **Cìxùn [次逊]**, was originally a slave of **Lǐ Yuán [李元]** from **Yùyáng, Nanyang [南阳育阳]**. The slaves conspired to divide the estate among themselves, but **Shàn** secretly carried **Xùzǔ** away, fleeing to **Xiáqiūshān [瑕丘山]**, where he nursed and raised him. When **Xùzǔ** was over ten years old, **Shàn** revealed him to **County Magistrate Zhōnglíyì [锺离意]**, who then recommended him, taking all the slaves under his care and establishing **Xùzǔ** as the heir. 「All receive the **Three Officials’** scrolls as rulers of the underworld.
After a thousand years,
they are then assigned to supplement the **Five Emperors** of the **Three Officials**.
Some become the **Lords of the East, West, South, and North**,
to govern the spirits and deities.
After another thousand four hundred years,
they may attain the **Great Clarity** and roam freely,
becoming the **Middle Immortal** of the **Nine Palaces**.

*(In terms of years, even this **sagely virtue** falls short of loyalty and filial piety.
Calculating from death, a total of two thousand four hundred years
before one may enter the ranks of the **Immortal Stage**.
This makes it clear that the earlier passage must refer to **Xià Qǐ [夏启]**, not **Míng Gōng [召公明]**.
After **Jìzǐ’s** death, until the **Jìn** era of **Xīngníng [兴宁]**, it was only about eight hundred and eighty years—
far short of a thousand.
I wonder if he had already become a **Lord**?
*[The records from the capital mention none of the **Five Emperors** in this context.
Perhaps this follows the precedent of the **Northern Emperor**, who also has five.
Thus, later mentions of **Heroes** as the **Five Emperors’** supreme ministers,
while the **Northern Emperor** has **Qín Huáng [秦皇]**.
The **Sū Zhāo** transmission also states that **Yáng Xióng [扬雄]**, **Zhāng Hēng [张衡]**, and others are among the **Five Emperors**—
but **Yáng Xióng** and **Zhāng Hēng** are not **supreme sages**;
their ranks are humble,
and they should not be equated with **Yán Dì [炎帝]**.
There may also be lesser **Five Emperors** not listed here.
The accounts of **Yáng Xióng** and **Zhāng Hēng** may not be accurate either.)*

Those who possess **boundless magnanimity** and **unrivaled prospects**,
nurturing their **浩然** *Great Qi*,
yet do not seek honor and wealth,
upon death
receive the **Three Officials’** scrolls as the **spirit of benevolent clarity**.
After four hundred years,
they may attain the rank of **ruler of the underworld**.
From there, they advance in stages,
with three hundred years marking each **ascension to Immortal Officials**.

*(This refers to the rank of **recluse-sage** and **eremitic virtuous ones**.
From the **ruler of the underworld** onward,
this is entering the **Immortal Stage**,
no longer serving as a **spirit-official**.)*

Those with **uttermost integrity and utmost frugality**,
upon death
receive the scrolls as **pure spirits** of the **Three Officials**.
After two hundred and eighty years,
they may attain the rank of **ruler of the underworld**.
From there, they gradually ascend
to become **Immortal Officials**,
with two hundred and eighty years as one stage.

*(This rank is slightly inferior to that of the **recluse-sage**,
yet the years required are double those for loyalty and filial piety—
thus, it is clear that **loyalty, filial piety, integrity, and frugality** are the most esteemed virtues in practice.)*

As for the **utterly frugal**,
they do not eat food not earned by themselves,
nor wear silk or cloth not acquired by their own labor—
**Wáng Yáng [王阳]** was such a man.
*(This category should be measured against **Yí Qí [夷齐]** as the standard.
There are many examples among **recluse-sages**,
yet today only **Wáng Yáng** is cited—
his natural purity was innate,
not a deliberate act of pristine virtue.
**Wáng Yáng** was a person of the **Former Han** era.)*

As for the **utterly chaste**,
luxury and splendor cannot sway their uprightness,
nor can the might of a great kingdom shake their reputation and conduct.
For men, **Gù Guāng [务光]**’s deeds are similar.
For women, **Sòng Jīn Piāo’s** daughter is the example.
*(The **chaste** are not merely those who avoid licentiousness in deed—
they also resist the **inflamed heart** of coveting honor and profit.
**Gù Guāng** declined the **Tāng** dynasty’s offer of office,

The hidden dragon and serpent wage war in the **Xuán Quán**,
while **Fān Qiū** loses his horse in **Huái Yáng**.
The **Líng Zhōu** shifts the seas at the southern pole,
and the **Dōng Shān** gathers afar in the **Dì Xiāng**.
The **Mǎ Huá** and **Mǎ Liú** hold the reins against the giant tortoise,
while the **Jiāng Shǐ** is moved by dreams from the **Sòng King**.

Thus, though **Dòngtíng** be vast,
**Jì** cannot contain it with a blade.
Though **Lú Lóng** be steep,
**Yuè** cannot scale it in a morning.

The **Shān Mián** mountain hangs suspended,
its chasm a thousand *rèn* wide.
The **Shù Mǎ** and **Mián Zhú**—
then **Ānlè** returns to **Jìn**,
while the **Liáo Hǎi** stretches wide,
spanning the celestial channels.
**Gōngsūn** does not compete—
thus his downfall comes swift.

As for the flying **fēihú** and white horses,
the **Jímò** and **Tiānshān**,
the sources of the **Sān Jiāng** and **Jiǔ Hé**—
what words suffice to speak of them?

The heart and governance harmonize within the Great Unity—
only the Tang and Yu could fulfill this duty.
The spirit and transformation sway beyond all bounds—
only Fuxi could inherit this lineage.

Thus, the twenty-five-stringed instrument’s craft
requires Yajuan’s skill to wield its divine resonance.
The bow and arrow’s plain implements
require [Houyi’s] Yǔ [or] Fēngmeng’s mastery to perfect their art.

The Master’s chariot flies with four steeds harnessed,
its gaze sweeping through groves and thickets.
Yet only the treasures of mountain and river are heard—
why has the realm of Wei not yet been fully explored?

When Wu Qi spoke but once,
the heart of Lord Wu was stirred.

*(These two lines are from the expanded *Yǔ* section of the *Capital Ode*.
All four lines are from different hands.
The small script on green paper is ancient and crude,
yet since they connect with the true script,
they are recorded together and carried along.
—Yang Jun)*

The First Emperor of Qin built the Long Bridge across the Wei River,
six *zhàng* wide, three hundred eighty *bù* long—sixty-eight spans.
In the Han, a Water Commissioner was stationed north of the bridge,
with fifteen hundred laborers under his command,
administered by the Jingzhao prefecture.
Dong Zhuo destroyed it.
Emperor Wu of Wei rebuilt it,
three *zhàng* wide—this is the bridge of today.

*(The *zhōng* is an auspicious omen.
In the Jin Dynasty, there were six *zhōng*—
their appearance was certain.
The Five Hegemons of the Jin era surpassed them in virtue,
so the six *zhōng* were merely fortunate omens,
not a sign of decline for future generations.
Was there not a warning of lost territories?
This is a note of forty-eight characters added by Huang Min.)*

This was the twelfth year of Emperor Yi of Song.
The Ho Mountain collapsed, yielding six *zhōng*.
Thus, one sought to associate it with the Song ancestors,
and hastily composed this passage—
yet the events diverged so greatly as to invite ridicule.

The Qin built the Alang Palace,
twenty *lǐ* southwest of Chang’an.
The palace stretched a thousand *bù* east to west,
three hundred *bù* north to south.
Its upper halls seated ten thousand,
while its courtyard could accommodate a hundred thousand.
The Second Qin Emperor was slain by Zhao Gao in the Yìchūn Palace,
located three *lǐ* south of the city.
He was buried nearby—
as Sima Xiangru described:
*"The tomb lies overgrown and unkempt."*

The Qin confiscated weapons nationwide,
melting them to cast twelve bronze statues.
They were placed in the palaces—
*(these fourteen characters occupy a single line;
the preceding fish-rotten residue leaves ten missing;
now the order is completed as such)*
—and remained in Chang’an during the Han.
Dong Zhuo melted them down for coinage.
Two statues remained in the Eastern Palace before Qingmen.
Emperor Ming of Wei sought to relocate them to Luoyang,
but the effort failed at Ba City.
They now stand on Ba City’s main road to the south,
with an inscription on their chest:
*"In the twenty-sixth year of the Emperor,
he unified all the feudal lords under his rule,
establishing commanderies and counties,
rectifying the laws,
and standardizing measures and weights."*

The Great One came to take up residence beside the **Water Omen**.

His stature was five zhang in height.
His footprints measured six chi.
These were inscribed by Qin Chancellor Meng Tian and Li Si.
*(The Qin character is missing.)*

Four bronze bells hung in the temple.
All were in the Han High Ancestor’s Temple.
Emperor Ming of Wei relocated two to Luoyang.
Thus, the remaining two stand in the Southern Copper **Masheng** Lane—
the **Northern Zhu** bell.

In Han Zhao’s tomb at Pingling,
and in Han Xuan’s tomb at Duling,
two bronze bells stood in Chang’an.
General Xiahou Zhengxi sought to relocate them to Luoyang,
but their weight proved insurmountable.
Now they rest on the southern road of Qingmen.
The western one is the Pingling bell,
the eastern one the Duling bell.
*(Here follows the matter of the First Emperor’s tomb.)*

Hongmen lies ten-odd li north of the First Emperor’s tomb.
The *Han Book* records:
Zhang Liang there resolved his crisis.
As Qin King (should be **Chu King**; a mistake, calling him Qin King),
Xiang Yu appointed Stipe’s Duke as **Han King**,
establishing his capital at Hanzhong.
Yet he divided Guanzhong into three:
Qin Zhāng Hán as **Yong King**, capital at Daqiu—
now Huáilǐ is its site.
Sīmǎ Xīn as **Sài King**, capital at Lìyáng—
now Wànyuán County is its site.
Dǒng Yì as the **Yù King**,
capital at Gāonú.
Gāonú County lay northwest of Xianyang—
now it is **omitted** (or **abbreviated**).
The High Ancestor, emerging from Hanzhong to the north,
raided all three fronts and subdued them.
The *Han Book* records this.

Exploiting the opportunity to act,
he swept through the Three Qin—
this was his deed.
These three counties today still bear the sites of their ancient capitals.
*(Hereafter, fifteen or sixteen items are missing—
clearly lost or omitted.)*

**Du Ling**—the Mausoleum of Emperor Xuan.
Emperor Xuan, in his youth, took refuge with the Xu family in Du County.
He was buried in the Southern Mound,
and a temple was erected to him north of Qu Pool,
named the **Leyou Temple**—
taking its name from the nearby **Wanyuan** estate.
Forty-five noble clans from east of the Pass were relocated here
to accompany the Du Ling Mausoleum.

Sima Xiangru, in his elegy for the Second Emperor, spoke of
standing on the **Qujiang’s** [mistaken character] isle—
meaning Qu Pool itself.
*(This entry has been expanded and slightly altered.
It is unclear how it came to be thus.)*

The ten items preceding this
are all taken from Yang Jun’s transcription of Pan Anren’s *Record of Guanzhong*,
written in fine white paper with elegant cursive script.
It seems he merely copied these matters at random.

Within the Eastern Palace’s precincts,
there was a verse recited:
*"The small fish not yet cooked in the cauldron—*
*I weep beneath this rock."*
*(This is a song from the Donghua Palace.)*

*"The winds obey, the white road opens—*
*The River Spirit leads the way ahead."*
*(These two lines are from the *Huishen* poem.)*

*"The Wind Lord does not stir the branches—*
*The Divine Tiger holds them fast."*

On the twenty-fourth day of the eleventh month,
in the blink of an eye,
a voice was heard from the **Dongfang Chamber**:
*"Within the crimson canopy,*
*there sounds like a human voice,*
*reading aloud like this."*
*(This records the Three True Ones of the Dongfang Chamber,
along with the preceding entry—
all from Yang Jun’s own recollections and experiences.)*

Upon receiving the letter,
he knew his heart had been cleansed of guilt,
and the words expressed deep humility.
In reply, he came again,
Zhang Sheng bowed his head.
The note was signed: *"To Master Xu.*
*I recently learned of your northern journey.*
*I regret we could not meet in person.*
*Now I send a single thread of Huang Zhang’s longevity.*
*Will you truly not come again?"*
Zhang Sheng bowed his head.
The note was signed: *"To Master Yang.*
*I dreamed of a woman-like figure,*
*wearing a feathered robe,*
*who brought these two folded letters.*
*Upon opening and reading them,*
*I awoke—*
*I recall having heard these words before,*
*yet much remains forgotten.*
*Later, I dreamed of burning incense*
*and entering the inner chamber."*
*(All this records the dream of Zhang Tian Shi’s letter.
Zhang Sheng’s name is thus concealed—
now revealed to the Chancellor,
so it is not openly displayed.
It also appears in the *Systematic Commentary on the Laozi*,
where all refer to "this humble servant bowing in reverence."
Perhaps this too is from Master Xi’s letter.)*

On the twenty-seventh day of the fourth month, **Xingning** year,
Yang Jun dreamed of a man
wearing red robes and a peaked cap,
holding two tablets in his hands,
and carrying two more in his arms.
He summoned Xu Yufu,
who stepped forward and presented the tablets—
all inscribed in green characters.
Yang was then summoned to serve as **Chancellor**.
In a moment, Xu Yufu emerged.
Yang pointed and said, *"This is Master Xu."*
Xu Yufu spoke for himself:
*"I am to be appointed in the thirteenth year.
Now I am summoned early—
I do not yet know the proper etiquette to address others.*
*If you say so, I can act as a messenger."*
Xu Yufu then bowed in submission,
still uncertain of the proper rites.
He was studying the **Ten Thousand Words** [mistaken character],
and it would take thirteen years before he could properly serve.
He then bowed to Yang and departed.
*(This half-sheet is a transcription,
written down as Yang Jun recounted his dream.
Thus, it remains within the Yang records.
The Chancellor’s position—
the one who attends the Emperor at dawn—
the tablets inscribed in green—
these are the **green bamboo slips and white tablets**.)*

On the twenty-ninth day of the fourth month, at midnight,
he dreamed of sitting beside Xu Yufu,
though he knew not where they were.
After a long while...

I saw the **Nanyue** Lady and the **Ziyang** True Person Zhou Jun together arrive.
They sat upon a single bed.
Then I saw Xu Yufu.
He spoke to the True Person Zhou Jun, saying,
*"I have long heard of Master’s **Guard-One** method.
I beg to request its transmission."*

Zhou Jun replied,
*"My former teacher, Master Su, once said to me,
‘To seek the True through the Dao—is this not overly roundabout?
Let me raise this point with you now.’"*

Xu Yufu said,
*"My aspirations are shallow and limited.
I covet the **Dao** and **virtue**,
so I wish to beg for the **Guard-One** method."*

Before he finished speaking,
Zhou Jun again said,
*"What was once not transmitted through the **Dao**
was merely because of the **bounded exchanges** of mortal men.
*(Zhou was from Ruyin. A seventh-generation descendant of Han Grand Commandant Bo. Hence, he is called a **bounded man**.)*
You are a **True Person**—
and already possess great transmission.
Why would you seek to **Guard-One** further?"*

Having spoken, he suddenly awoke,
yet did not know where he was.
This dream was exceedingly clear,
so I recorded it.
**Fourth month, ninth day, on the night of the fourth watch,**
I dreamed of traveling north and ascending a high mountain.
Lost and disoriented, I did not awaken.
Only when the sun rose four or five *zhang* did I wake.
Upon waking, I recalled climbing the mountain for half a day,
reaching the summit, where there were thousands of palaces,
so vast they defied description.
The mountain’s four sides were encircled by great waters,
yet I did not know where I was.

I then looked upward,
and in the sky saw a white dragon,
its body tens of *zhang* long,
flying eastward through the heavens,
its radiance dazzling the sky.
Then I saw, to the east, a fair woman in white robes,
also moving through the air,
facing west toward the white dragon.
She entered its mouth,
emerged again,
and did so three times before stopping.
She then returned to my right,
facing me.
To my left stood an old man,
wearing embroidered robes and a lotus-crowned cap,
leaning on a nine-jointed red staff.
Both gazed at the white dragon.

I asked the old man,
*"What kind of woman enters the dragon’s mouth?"*
He replied,
*"This is the **Taisu** Jade Maiden, Xiao Zifu.
She takes the dragon to refine her form.
This person appears to be **Fangxiang**, an official."*

I asked again,
*"Who is this old man?
Why has he come to this place?"*
He answered,
*"I am the **Penglai** Celestial Lord Luo Guangxiu.
This is **Penglai Mountain**.
I govern its heights.
The **Fu Lord** came to visit,
and thus we were able to meet."*

I asked the old man again,
*"Can this dragon be ridden?"*
He replied,
*"This dragon awaits the **True Person** Zhang Youshi,
Shi Qing’an,
and Xu Yufu."*

I asked again,
*"Is it one dragon that the four are riding together?"*
The old man replied,
*"This is a dragon that serves the Morning Emperor.
It is like the world’s **Zhāochē** chariot drawn by the Vermilion Bird—
each day, one rides it to ascend directly.
In a moment, the old man called these four worthies.
Before they arrived, I spread out a mat with you, the old man, and this maiden,
and we sat together on the mountain, all facing north,
gazing at the sea and the white dragon.
There was also wine and food set before us.
The wine was like pomegranate seeds,
and we ate them together.
The **mùbàn** was also like the world’s **mùbàn**,
and within the **mùbàn** was salmon.
After a long while, the four arrived from the east,
riding a fresh **niúcē** chariot,
with green oxen and green oil—
a grand carriage that came before us.
They bowed to the old man and to me,
and spoke with us.
After their words concluded,
the old man said, ‘The four men I spoke of earlier—
these are they.’
I saw that Zhang Youshi was about fifty years old,
Shi Qing’an was very youthful, around thirteen or fourteen,
Xu Yufu was the same age as I saw him today,
and Ding **Yùwéi** Ning was about thirty-four or five.
All wore fine single robes,
with **jīnzé** hanging down and **bān** sandals.
Only Qing’an wore an empty **jīnzé**."*

chunks.translated_text:
I said, "Not so."
The old man replied, "Zhang Youshi is a man of Changshan.
He is my disciple.
Shi Qing’an is a man of Ji Province.
He is the disciple of the Lady Gouyi.
Their talents are equal, their virtue matched—
both are esteemed among men of letters.
The old man then addressed the four, saying,
‘You may each compose a poem
to display your skill before the Master.
I too wish to hear your refined words of literary beauty.’

At this, the old man gave each a sheet of green paper,
and a brush to each as well,
to present to the four.
The four took them and said,
‘We fear our haste may betray us.’

Then Shi Qing’an composed his poem first.
Its words were:
*"The Ling Mountain crafts the dawn’s radiance,
The upright cliffs pierce the celestial peaks.
Purple mists drift across the land of gods,
Riding the gale, harnessed to the white dragon.
Hand in hand, we four guests arrive,
To the eastern hall of the Master of Sanglin.
Though my years are few, my heart is vast—
What wisdom do I bring?
I have not yet descended to yield the path.
Only in mutual reverence do we meet."*

Next, Zhang Youshi composed his poem.
Its words were:
*"To the north, I wandered beyond the Great Desert,
To climb the gates of Penglai.
Purple clouds met the Ling Palace’s halls—
Fragrant mists, how thick they rise!
Ah, splendid is the Master’s virtue!
Long have I dwelt in his Dao’s embrace.
The True Ones gather in their ranks,
Together observing the white dragon’s stride.
When shall we four loosen our belts and part?
I have a friend in whom I take delight—
Joyful mornings we share in his company."*

Then Xu Yufu composed his poem.
Its words were:
*"I wander through mountains of marvelous height,
Rinsing in the clear currents of the Stygian Sea.
From afar, I gaze upon Penglai’s realm—
Towering peaks pierce the heavens’ depths.
Purple mushrooms cloak the vermilion cliffs,
Four steps planted with fragrant *linyu* [citrus].
Swirling mists of divine splendor drift,
Gleaming radiance fills the halls of gods.
Beyond the Seven Awakenings’ bounds,
I freely grasp the mysteries of Heaven’s birth.
Sufficient lies within my heart’s measure—
Why seek the white dragon’s glory?"*

Last, Ding Yùwéi Ning composed his poem.
Its words were:
*"The Black Mountain frames the Stygian waves,
The golden halls reflect the Ling Chamber’s light.
The Duke of Luo upholds his singular virtue—
Graceful ease in all he does.
His form rests in the northern cold,
Three divine ones dwell in the Nine Heavens.
Together we lodge, then journey forth,
Praising your years of highest attainment.
Though I was but youthful in my twenties,
I did not yet revere the worthy.
Mocking the Master of Penglai,
I called him ‘Broad Rest’ before.
Now, Master, what shall you do?
To dismiss this youth’s brushstrokes?
The four finished their poems,
and each presented his to the old man.
After reading them, he laughed and said,
‘Each poem reveals their unique talent and nature.
Shi Qing’an has an unconventional brilliance yet moves lightly.
Zhang Youshi’s verse is harmonious but hard to fathom.
Xu Yufu is cautious and full of doubt.
Ding Yùwéi Ning is naturally withdrawn but slow to express himself.
To move lightly is to lack depth.
To be hard to fathom is to not grasp the Dao.
To doubt excessively is to think without divine insight.
To express oneself slowly is to miss the soul’s brilliance—
These are the paths of difference.
If each could return from their confusion,
And awaken to what they truly know,
They would not fall short.
The Master’s disciples—when they request to discuss doubts,
Doubt is what blinds them from divine insight.’

After the poems concluded,
each took up their staff and descended the mountain.
As they descended...

chunks.translated_text:
The Master then saw this woman riding a white dragon depart to the north.
I and the others walked southward.
Upon reaching the mountain’s foot, each parted ways.
The Master said, *"In twenty years’ time,
we shall meet again at the Seven Arts Hall—
to wander this place once more."*
At these words, I suddenly awoke to understanding,
my brow beaded with sweat.
For the rest of the day, I could neither eat nor drink.

Halfway down the mountain,
I saw Xu the Clerk ascending.
We met between the cliffs.
The Master spoke to the Clerk, *"Why do you come so late?
I have set aside four pints of wine
at the place where I sat on the mountain.
Go drink it, then return to follow me."*
The Clerk immediately went up the mountain.
In a short while, he returned,
moving swiftly.
Before he reached the foot, the Master met him again.
The Master said, *"Did you not drink the fine wine?"*
The Clerk replied, *"I still regret its sourness."*
The Master said, *"This is wine from the House of Great Peace—
it soothes the human intestines."*
The Clerk exclaimed, *"If one seeks longevity,
why should they drink the House of Great Peace?
What sourness could there be?"*
Thus, he is but a rustic child.
Hold fast to your single resolve,
take no heed of trifles.
Later, I shall rely on you
to assist and shelter me.*

The Clerk and I then went east together.
The Master returned to the mountain.
The other three departed westward fifty paces.
The Master sent a messenger to inform me:
*"Xu the Clerk will serve as my toothpick."*
I replied, *"I have no objection."*

To the tenth night.
I first composed a memorial on this dream.
The Master reported it to the sages.
Upon receiving this strange dream,
they were as clear as if they had not slept.
They did not discern what wish it might convey.

Only **Zǐwēi** Lady replied:
*"Your true nature is inwardly stirred—
spirit seeks far and wide,
divinity descends from the Eight Mysteries,
your form soars with your soul.
This is indeed the omen of supreme attainment.
The matter reveals the hidden depths—
not a vain fabrication.
As the **Luó** Master spoke,
you may discreetly inform **Yùfǔzi** and the others.
Do not widely proclaim the sacred intent within.
This is no small matter.
Take great care.

The other sages laughed.
**Qīnglíng** said:
*"It is through the **míng** of the **míng** that you perceive this.
Your heart resonates with piercing clarity—
the power of **Nányuè** Lord."*

Someone appeared and told me,
*"This is the Great Cave of Mount Móng.
The chamber is square, with seats facing each other.
All are made of cypress beds with dragon-scaled mats.
The walls are inscribed with countless texts, yet they cannot be deciphered.

He sits facing west, his back to the east.

One of them declares:
‘I am the father of Zhào Shǔtái—

The appointed time of water and fire

*(Shèng is still the sound of Chéng.

There are those who study yet fail to grasp it—

Truly, this saying is true!

The Chángshǐ then wrote it upon green paper
and showed it to me.

Dēng Nán asked: ‘What is meant by *guō*?’
The Chángshǐ replied: ‘It is like a *guō* within the cave—
not the *guō* of a tomb.’

Again he asked: ‘Why *qián*?’
The reply came: ‘*Qián* is the beginning of reverence.
Below, there are characters—
the written form of reverence.’

Again he asked: ‘Why *shèng*?’
The answer was: ‘*Shèng* is the servant beneath the sun—
the sun completes, and the moon attains.’

The three men in brocade robes together exclaimed:
‘Fortunate! Fortunate!
Study cannot deceive the coming and going of the Dao’s appointed time.’

his radiance illuminated the spirit’s hall.

our entwined oaths,
transcended the crowd—
a lone awakener, forging his own path beyond.

Master was then thirty years old when Great Yang was thirty.
When Master first entered Dongshan, Yang was but sixteen.
When he vanished from the world, Yang was nineteen—
thus did Yang’s devotion to the Dao begin so young.

Since parting from the radiant dust of the world,
today I gaze eastward across the Milky Way,
tears falling before words.
I imagine the Mysterious Palace in harmonious fusion,
its auspicious governance now complete.
At this moment, riding the Eight Winds,
it sweeps away all dross and obscurity.
The Six Heavens exert their might,
dispelling demonic *qi*.
May the true and authentic faith
spread through the Three Epochs.
The boundless sentiment of the Void
transforms endlessly.

Before your departure, you often expressed concern,
thinking of dreams you had seen.
You entrusted me with your handwritten traces as proof.
Since then, I have felt the hidden communion—
after receiving the inscription,
time seemed to vanish in an instant,
as if a thousand years had passed,
yet I was able to obtain it.
How strange and inexplicable!
Truly, how subtle and wondrous!
Truly, how subtle and wondrous!

This is what I recently dreamed, as recorded in my sparse notes.
I now reveal it in secret.
*(This was written after Master was tested—
Yang sent it to him in reply.
On fine hemp paper, exquisitely preserved—
this is the original manuscript, hence its survival.)*

Xī respectfully bows, bows again.
In the cold darkness,
I humbly inform you:
Your body remains in harmony, bringing comfort.
I have yet to pay my respects in person.
Respectfully, I write no more.
Yang Xī respectfully bows, bows again.
Xī reports:
Your third daughter came yesterday to offer a *jìngsài* rite.
Today, she is slightly better,
though still not fully recovered.

Master Xù, in days past, concealed his brilliance and withdrew from the world,
his light hidden in the ninth heaven.
In the dark, he observed the divine—
his radiance illuminated the spirit’s hall.

Fortunate! Fortunate!
In days gone by, our intimate exchanges,
our entwined oaths,
transcended the crowd—
a lone awakener, forging his own path beyond.

chunks.translated_text:
The multitude’s mood is turbulent and restless.
Their movements and stillness alike bring news of distress.
The recent plague and pestilence are most dreadful,
Yet still they do not cease.
This only adds to my profound anxiety.

To the *Giving Officer* Xu, Lord of the Prefectural Household, *(these six characters written on the back of a folded paper)*
Xī respectfully reports:
The two minor official matters were recently settled due to the dismissal of the Chief Clerk, who was transferred to Zheng’s Western Chamber.
Zheng’s Western Chamber also happened to be where he was stationed.
But the affairs were not yet fully completed.
Once finished, they would be submitted to the superior.
I now consider this a matter of personal sentiment.
This passage was composed for the descendants of Chen Zouwang and Rong Yi—
Indeed, it was a well-crafted work.

Respectfully, *(this letter lost its upper sheet)*
Xī bows, bows again.
I humbly inform you:
Your body remains in harmony, bringing comfort.
Last night, a messenger from the Liu family departed.
Their concern seems like that of the bereaved in mourning.
Tomorrow morning, Xī will accompany the Chief Clerk to the tomb to pay respects.
Perhaps later I may visit again.
Yang Xī bows, bows again.

The other day, I also received a carriage inquiry.
I suspect it was not properly examined.
At least, it was sent with *heartfelt* urgency.
This is not the doing of one who delves into the Dao’s profound treasures,
But rather the natural course of things.
To the *Longshì* Xu, Lord of the Prefectural Household, *(these six characters written on the back of the paper as well)*

Xī respectfully reports:
I received silk fabric,
Which I will use to make summer clothing for my aged mother.
Truly, this is a gracious favor akin to the Western Marquis’s care for the elderly.
Yet Xī’s reception of kindness is excessive and beyond measure.
The honor flows far beyond what I deserve.
I can only bear the debt of gratitude,
With nothing to offer in return.
As for the gift of silk and cloth,
It is not what I should accept.
Even a modest offering of filial piety
Would suffice for my own needs.
Respectfully, I return it.
I hope you will deeply understand.

Xī respectfully reports.
Xī respectfully reports.
This place was once pure and serene,
Now free of dust and filth.
Moreover, the residence of the young clerk is fine.
But Xī will soon depart,
Unable to stay long and share company.

I will report again later.
Xī respectfully reports.
*(These two entries were written on the same sheet, and it seems the upper sheet was lost.)*

Xī bows, bows again.
In the cold hours of the night,
I humbly inform you:
Your body remains in harmony, bringing comfort.
This is my final report after returning from the visit.
Yang Xī bows, bows again.

The *Xīyì* letter was answered separately.
I paid respects on the 2nd day of the 2nd month.
Respectfully reported."

Xī bows, bows again.
Today’s report again fails to dispel the *wind-dryness*.
I humbly inform you:
Your body remains in harmony, bringing comfort.

I humbly submit a letter in response to your earnest inquiry.
I do not presume to elaborate further.
Yang Xī bows, bows again.
Xī respectfully reports.

The *Cloud Zhi* Dao is not to be entrusted with this letter to be delivered.
Xī will personally attend to it.
Respectfully reported.
To the Honorable Chief Administrator Xu, Sir.

*(Attendant reports: These nine characters are inscribed on the back of a folded sheet. The letter from the Master and Yang Xī: The upper sheet bears repeated bows, while the lower sheet includes the single petition and the respectful report. Moreover, the self-reference to "Your body" is used, which may be explained by the irregularity of the ritual. It is neither the intent of a subordinate nor the proper conduct of a teacher and disciple. This is simply the expression of deference to one's superiors in age or rank, and the attendant's title reflects their duty. It is not a fixed rule that one must always adhere to—it should be adapted according to circumstances and cannot be strictly taken as [standard] practice.)*

Xī bows, bows again.
On a fortunate day, my wishes are fulfilled.
Though I have not yet paid my respects, I am deeply moved.
I humbly inform you:
Your body remains in harmony, bringing comfort.
Xī has now finished burning incense.
You should temporarily return home to rest in stillness.
In the evening, I will personally open [the letter].
Respectfully reported, without further elaboration.
Yang Xī bows, bows again.
Xī respectfully reports.

There has been no recent inquiry about the wilderness.
Yet the new wife of Hua is indeed well.
I still hang my heart on the 2nd day of the 2nd month for paying respects.
Xī respectfully reports.

I am grateful for today’s gift of rice.
Yesterday, I already dispatched Chen [with provisions] for food and drink.
They will remain to guard and observe [the matter].
Respectfully reported.

Long History Master, Lord Xu:

*(These six characters inscribed on the folded paper’s reverse—
to be answered while in the mountain retreat. The fifth day of the tenth month.)*

Xī respectfully reports:
The official reply has been completed, yet I forgot to send it.
Just as I was about to dispatch a messenger,
I received word and now seal it for delivery.
A proper copy will also be transcribed and submitted separately.

I am uncertain whether the prescribed *chóngwán* (虫丸) remedy has been taken as directed.
If it remains unfinished, should the course begin anew upon the coming year?
As for what I previously obtained,
I divided and took it daily as usual—no irregularities were observed.
Only at the outset, for six or seven days,
I felt a warmth in the head and a surging heat in the abdomen.
Beyond that, nothing else.
Perhaps the effects are gradually taking hold.
Respectfully reported.

Xī respectfully reports:
The Chief Clerk, the virtuous scholar-official,
remains here under my care, though only slightly comforted.
The junior clerk, alone in that distant place,
must surely feel deep longing.
These past days, my thoughts have followed him,
my yearning beyond words.
The household affairs are, for now, manageable.
I humbly request your continued concern.

Xī respectfully reports:
Yesterday and today, there were replies to be answered,
yet I was in a distracted state.
Only now, having just received your handwritten letter
and heard the full account,
will I present it properly.
Upon opening it, I will make it known.

Xī respectfully reports.

Xī respectfully reports:
I humbly inform you of all recent developments,
ever awaiting your guidance.
Your labor has kept me restless in thought.
Xī respectfully reports.

The colored papers remain with the young scholar.
I dare not let them be lost.
Xī respectfully reports.
Xī respectfully reports.

Tomorrow I shall go to East Mountain.
The Chief Clerk says he will accompany me.
There is also a matter of the kitchen staff to resolve.
The young scholar also lacks a horse.
Xī will answer the Master today.
The Master instructs that tomorrow I should first think of arranging a carriage together to deliver the matter.
I do not know if Your Honor’s horse can be obtained to send me here.
The grass here is easier to manage than in the capital.
May he be fortunate and not need it.
I am now arranging the *Three Virtues* (三秀).
It is a matter of several days.
Xī respectfully reports.
*(The following five letters are all previous responses to the Prefect while in the county.
Some are single petitions, others may have lost the original letter.)*
Xī respectfully reports.

The Master’s household, Xī heard, yesterday and today hosted a visit from Master Xu.
The Master’s household was still modest in its arrangements.
He did not even realize how long I should have been departing.
Zhang Hong continued to arrive.
At that time, the day was still manageable.
Xī humbly informs:
Entering the gate to support the Master’s affairs,
this was indeed a rare and unusual matter.
Because Xī could not properly restrain myself in drink and food,
I failed to measure the appropriate time to send guests away.
I am deeply ashamed and fearful.
I hope Your Honor will again examine and pardon me.
Xī respectfully reports.
*(This matter was addressed in the capital to the Prefect,
while I was still in the Military Protectorate.)*
Xī respectfully reports.

I have now compiled and collected about fifty people.
I have also drafted the *True Record* (叙真).
This should be seen as a benefit.
The followers of *Mystic Depth* (味玄),
if they can encourage and exhort me,
I am truly moved.
Xī heard that this should be far more than what I have done.
In the evening, I will overturn my bundle to search for materials,
and send those I obtain.
Xī respectfully reports.

I have already prepared paper and writing implements.
When finished,
I will personally write one copy.
I wish to send it to Master Shi.
I wish it not to be seen by others.
*(This should be the case of the *Shi’s Rectification* (白石耳).
Or perhaps it is the *Five Officials’ Fat Law* (五公腴法).
From this letter onward, Master Yang’s records are all matters after the Clerk’s death.
I do not know who collected and preserved them—
perhaps it was Huang Min from his elder’s household.)*
Xī respectfully reports.

The *Han Records* (汉书) mention the *Chief of the Season* (季主事),
yet do not describe his difficulties.
The *Master of the Hills* (稽山公) composed the *Biographies of High Scholars* (高士传).
If they are as refined and modest,
I will copy the *Master of the Hills’* draft of the *Chief of the Season*’s biography
and present it as though it were separate.
Xī respectfully submits.
The *Scriptures of the Secluded Chamber* (洞房先进经) have already been written.
I will deliver them as Your Honor commands, requesting Master Wang Edict (王旷) to retrieve them.
*(Alternative: "I have already reported.")*
For fear of forgetting, Xī respectfully reports again.
*(The red paper and books I now possess are these.)*
Xī respectfully reports.

I received Your Honor’s letter yesterday during the rain,
and could not visit.
I thought tomorrow I would surely be able to comply.
If the weather clears, I will temporarily pay my respects before reporting.
Xī respectfully reports.

This letter of nine characters (written on folded paper, backside):
Xī respectfully reports.

Master Jì excels in profound learning,
and his Dao/Way is most sublime.
Thus, should he not be placed at the very beginning of the scroll?
The Honorable Lord of the Eastern Prefecture sighed greatly at Master Jì’s character,
and also admired his lofty and daring spirit.

The collection is now roughly complete.
It should soon be ready for viewing.
Though I have not yet seen the Honorable Lord’s letter,
I already rejoice and marvel at it.
I will humbly present it in one or two days.
Xī respectfully reports.

*(The text I wrote on the Eastern Prefecture’s praise of Master Jì’s deeds
was originally inscribed on separate green paper,
not included with this letter.
It is now found in the fourth section.)*
The collection should ideally be completed for seventy-two individuals.
I do not know how many have already been recorded.
If the number is few,
I should also consider invoking the unseen (冥中)
to seek their likenesses.
However, I have only drafted a portion.
I will proceed gradually.
It cannot yet be finalized.
I also wish to personally copy one complete draft
to present to the Honorable Lord.
The Honorable Lord has always cherished this endeavor,
hoping to fulfill it with sincere devotion.
Xī respectfully reports.
Xī respectfully reports.

Kǒng Ānguó compiled the seventy-two disciples of Confucius.
Liú Xiàng compiled the seventy-two immortals (列仙).
Huángfǔ Shì’ān compiled the seventy-two high-sage masters (高士宗).
Chén Chángwén compiled the seventy-two elders (耆旧).
*(These are the elders of Chénliú. This book is complete in form but lacks a title—likely sealed in an envelope.)*
Xī respectfully reports.

I recall another matter on separate paper—
it is most excellent.
It can be included in the transmitted records (传中).
I await the Honorable Lord’s command
to inquire and request the names and surnames.
I must also see the Honorable Lord of the Eastern Prefecture.
This month, I should complete it without fail.
Xī will report as circumstances allow.
*(This letter also lost its original paper.
The words were written in response to the initial sending of the *Godly Immortals’ Records*.
The Honorable Lord’s command must await his arrival.
Again, this seems written while in the county,
not in the capital.)*

The *Godly Immortals’ Records* still lack proper revision.
I must await the Honorable Lord of the Eastern Prefecture’s arrival
to present them respectfully.
Yesterday, I again humbly read them,
repeating them three times,
so I could name them properly.
I was moved by their grandeur.
The messenger awaits clear weather to deliver them.
Xī respectfully reports.
Xī respectfully reports.

The *Records* have not yet been inscribed to Master Wáng.
The reason for this is
that I wish to present them to the Honorable Lord of the Eastern Prefecture.
Since he has not yet arrived,
I cannot yet begin this.
I will present them upon his later visit.
Your Honor’s office already has a copy.
I do not know if this copy should be kept here.
I also wish to submit further records.
Once all are submitted,
I will humbly return them all together.
Xī respectfully reports.

*(This *Godly Immortals’ Records* by the Prefect’s attendant
were never revealed to the world.
I do not understand how this came to be.
Perhaps the Honorable Lord forbade me to disclose the true matter,
causing me to conceal and abandon it.)*

I do not know if the reclusive scholar (方隅山中幽人) in the distant hills
has already arranged a seat for me at the Easy Migration’s household (易迁户).
Xī humbly inquires.
*(The reclusive scholar refers to the county magistrate.
The Honorable Lord has set up a symbolic seat in his mother’s home.)*

The messenger still requires a cow.
Tomorrow, after the meal is finished, I will send him away.
*(This letter lost its original paper—likely sealed in an envelope.
It was written while in the county.)*
Xī respectfully bows.
Xī respectfully reports.

I have taken the Honorable Lord’s medicine for three days,
and my body feels at ease.
This is a great relief.
I wish Your Honor’s body to remain harmonious
and free from further strain.
Recently, I have been busy with both public and private affairs,
so I humbly presented this brief report.
Yang Xī respectfully bows, respectfully bows.

I have been troubled by an illness for two years.
Recently, I received the *Sutra of the Lion’s Roar*.
It does not mention any ailment.
This must be a minor affliction.
I will send a messenger to inquire about it on a clear day.
Xī respectfully reports.

I have accepted Master Shí’s visit.
Xī now recognizes him.
Recently, there have been many sudden deaths.
*(This letter also lacks a title—likely written in the capital.)*

Yang Yi respectfully bows, respectfully bows.
I humbly report.

I have seen the *Dream Commentary* and the full account of the memorial.
Upon careful reconsideration,
the dream is indeed a matter of *qi* disturbance,
and the memorial has also reached its conclusion.
I am deeply moved by this.

I suspect this is the work of malevolent spirits.
They will soon disperse and vanish.
Recently, I have been attending court.
Yang Yi respectfully bows, respectfully bows.

The separate memorial should not be shown to others.
The grievances you mentioned—
I have humbly reported a few in my memorial.
As for the *Dream Commentary*,
it should now be resolved.

However, fundamentally, this is a disturbance of *qi*.
I respectfully report.

Recently, I too dreamed of a minor official.
He spoke of something,
but it was nothing of consequence.
I also no longer trust dreams to enlighten me,
so I did not report it.

Your illness—though precious as jade—remains unresolved.
It is likely due to minor disturbances of *qi*.
The memorial’s foundation is complete,
and it should be sufficient to dispel this.

I respectfully report.
I report.

Earlier, I received fine white silk, blue paper, and fragrant beads from the minor official.
However, these are mere superstitions of leftist heresies.
Thus, I no longer speak of them.

The appointed time for this matter shall indeed be the *jiashen* year.

All the grievances—
My pen cannot fully express them.
I respectfully report.

*(Since the minor official departed,*
*Yang has often experienced supernatural communications.*
*The Longshi has always remembered him,*
*so Yang has repeatedly encountered him.*
*In this world, many do not believe in the hidden and manifest.*
*Thus, I did not wish to speak of it fully.*
*Since then, it has been the ninth year of Taiyuan and the twenty-first year of Yuanjia—*
*two jiashen years have already passed.*
*I do not know which jiashen year this refers to—*
*is it the jiashen year after four cycles of dinghai?)*

I humbly bow, bow again.
I respectfully inform you:

Your body remains unwell,
and my own ailments—precious as jade—
persist in their disturbances.
My concern burns intensely.
I suspect this is due to occasional harm.
You wish to submit a memorial to explain yourself,
which would also suffice to sever the harm of malevolent *qi*.

Dreams should not be blindly trusted—
one must only steady the mind to calm them.

Later, I recovered and returned to normal.
Yang humbly bows, bows again.

I received news that the *jiyezhe* has returned.
I rejoice.
You have already met with him.
I inquire about the details—
I respectfully report.

Since the minor official’s passing,
*(cough)*[omitted]—
not a month passes without dreams.
I have dreamed of him ten times.
Even in sleep,
his form appears with grievances.
His words and deeds
are as if he were still alive.
Yet, since I no longer believe,
near and far mock me.
I dare not speak of it again.

Now, I fully recount the dream,
merely to inform you again.
I hope you will not take offense.
If you believe this to be mere delusion,
I hope you will return it to me,
and I will immediately burn it.

*(This letter has no title.

The minor official would often come in person to record it with me,
using sleep and dreams as a pretext.

some heard that Yang could commune with spirits.

while skeptics ridiculed him.)*

On the nineteenth night of the third month, I dreamed that a junior clerk came and sat quietly here. The junior clerk further said, *"The grass on Fang Mountain is truly excellent—unusually fine. Its leaves are vast. I took much of it yesterday, but recently lost the cloth wrapping. Du Guangping likewise cut firewood to trade for grain. How much more so the scholars dwelling above the caves? Truly, they would not fail to know the practice of fasting to abstain from grains—it is simply that they ought not to do so.

The junior clerk further said, *"The burial site is now unauspicious. Cutting off the tomb’s *mai* brings many ill omens."* (This was dreamed on the nineteenth evening. This is the end of the letter to the *changshi* (Master of Records). What remains of the true handwritten text concludes here. (One line is missing before this, and the two preceding characters are also lost.)

My heartfelt sentiments cannot be fully expressed. Upon reflection, I received word and roughly agreed. I soon went to visit, and our reunion is near. Recently, I have been in a state of anxious anticipation—truly beyond words.

The *jishì* (Assistant Minister) An He (who is the *changshi*) will depart from Nanzhou on the nineteenth day and return on the twenty-second. The *gongcao* (Functionary) has already entered the capital. Yesterday, we met and comforted each other’s hearts. (The *gongcao* is the clerk’s elder brother, whose childhood name was Kui.)

At that moment, my mind was wandering—my return had not yet been completed. Shall I invoke the *yin* virtue of the zither strings? Let me offer a lighthearted smile instead. (The zither strings matter is from the *Peng Su Jing*—a text on the *fangzhong* arts.)

This is all for today. Tomorrow, the *gong* (my lord) will again depart for Nanzhou to bid farewell to the *dà sīmǎ* (Grand Marshal). The *dà sīmǎ* will set out on the twenty-sixth. The seventh seems unlikely to join the campaign. (The *gong* is Simwen, serving as *sītú* (Grand Tutor). 「Thus he sends me far away with the rice.
Is it to prepare for the *dòngzhāi* (Great Cavern Ritual)?
If the Master were to refine the *xiánjìng* (Mystic Mirror) in distant lands,
to purify the voice and ascend the lofty tones,
dwelling in the depths of the forest,
far from worldly affairs,
then this matter would never come to pass.
But now I hear it—truly, the *dharma* is complete.

（The *dòngzhāi* refers to the *Dà Dòngzhāi Fǎ*—the Great Cavern Ritual. The *xiánjìng* is likely a metaphor for the *Tàihé* or *Tàihé* Ritual texts, which the clerk now possesses in full as the *shàngpǐn qījuàn* (Seven Volumes of the Supreme Grade).）

I believe my writing is finished.
Let me polish it further.
By autumn and winter,
I shall again reveal the *sūtra*.
（Unknown which *sūtra* this refers to. Next year, the clerk will depart into seclusion.）

Hence, I do not take the *shíxùn* (Stone-and-Rice).
When spring grass grows,
this matter is easy to find.
I imagine often wandering at the *xiánshuǐ* (Mystic Waters).
This month, I must go.
Speak of our brief reunion.
（The *Nánzhú* [Southern Incense] is not carved in winter,
but its flavor and hue are finest in spring.
Since it is called *shíxùn*,
it must be the clerk’s method of combining stone and rice.
As recorded: “The next dose is a meal of rice,
with grains unobstructed—
just one prescription for a thousand years of life.
The method differs, that’s all.”
Thus, I still don’t know where the *xiánshuǐ* is.）

I also do not trouble the *Lǐ* (Lee) family.
The *Lǐ* are ill and cannot attend to matters.
I’ve already burdened *Yì* (Yi) with labor.
The *shàngshū* (Secretary) has ordered me—
if it’s like this, there will surely be an autumnal gathering.
This is truly trifling—
not worth your slightest concern.
But the *Gěishì* (Palace Attendant) says:
Upon returning to *Nánzhōu* (Southern Prefecture),
I must also hasten.
By mid-April,
I wish to reach *Dōngshān* (Eastern Mountain).
I hope there will be no mistake.

（The clerk later notes:
*"Chá yī bù"* (Tea, one scroll)—
though the meaning isn’t clear, it’s likely a gift for the clerk.
*Chá* here refers to *míngchá* (green tea),
which the clerk needs for his *dàn yǐn* (dietary regimen of abstinence),
and also to aid in light sleep.）

A day without seeing you,
I constantly fear my vulgar and stingy heart has already arisen.
Could you still emerge from the dust of *fēngchén* (worldly affairs)
with such carefree ease?

（The following eight entries are from *Yángshū* (Yang’s Records),
all concerning the Master’s return to the mountains and the clerk’s affairs.
The original paper is lost—
these are letters between teacher and disciple,
clearly framed as Master and servant,
written in ancient style.）

I follow the *Gěishì*’s manner and spirit as before,
yet he is still so deferential.
In my haste to leave the *shìchéng* (Palace Secretariat),
I tremble with anxiety.
Burning incense and entering stillness,
I compose a nocturnal petition to lay bare my concerns,
so that the full *dànkǔ* (Elixir of Great Bitterness) may be revealed—
its principles distinct in motion and repose.
I await further inquiry.
（This is a brief note,
likely written from the county.
It concerns the illness of the *Hǔyǎ Dàoshì* (Tiger’s Claw Commandant).）

The *Gěishì*’s letters before and after,
I present to the *Shénmǔ* (Divine Mother).
Through them, I address the *xiǎoyuàn* (Junior Clerk).
I also submit my replies to the *Shénmǔ* before and after.
The *xiǎoyuàn* intercepted the *Gěishì*’s letters,
leaving only this one to be returned.
（This also pertains to the *Hǔyǎ*—
events after the clerk’s departure.
The *Shénmǔ* is likely *Nánzhēn Fùrén* (Southern True Lady).
The following are Yang’s external letters and his own recorded dreams,
along with his replies to the Commandant and other clerks,
as well as preserved notes.
There are also separate records of exchanges with the *Zhēnrén* (True Person),
already mentioned in earlier volumes.）

The *Dàoshì*’s letter states:
*"In the year of *Yǒu* (the Ox), I studied.
In the year of *Xū* (the Dog), I shall return.
In the year of *Xū*, the Dao will traverse the world.
It says that from the year of *Xū*, I shall receive the law."*
（This entry is from the clerk’s later records.
He notes that in the year *gēngwǔ* (Regnal Year *Gēngwǔ*),
he departed—
this *Xū* (Dog) refers to the years *guǐyǒu* (Year of the Ox) and *jiǎxū* (Year of the Dog),
when he received the *fǎ* (law)—
that is, the *Dàoshì*’s teachings on the *sūtra*’s two *bèn* (leaps/phases),
and his attainment of *Zhēn* (Perfection) in the eleventh year.
Thus, the records say:
*"After sixteen years, I shall see you at *Dōnghuá* (Eastern Flower)."*）

The *sūtra* says:
*"The Master of all *guān* (passages) begins with the *jìng* (Mirror) of clarity."*

（This is from the *Huángtíng Jīng*—the Yellow Court Classic.）

The dates are as follows:
September 17th—190 days passed.
October 21st—200 days passed.
October 26th, November 1st, 8th, 11th, 15th, 17th, 20th, 23rd, 30th.
November 2nd, 6th.
（This should be November 26th.）
November 13th, 20th, 21st.

and smoothed meticulously.
This method suits **remote mountains, great marshes, or uninhabited wilds**,
unfitting for human dwellings.

Upon entering the chamber,
**each of the four seasons has its own method**.
Yet this is but **inherited from the Dao/Way’s tradition**—
a single affair of the **Daoist school**,
nothing extraordinary.

**Essentially, it is known thus:**
*"This, and so forth—*
*(The Daoist **static chamber method (jìngshìfǎ)** differs.

yet without careful verification.
Now, when visualizing entry into the chamber,
one may follow it as well.

On the **fifteenth day of the first month**,
while **on duty in the Secretariat (Shàngshūshěng)**,
I prayed for dreams of extraordinary **numen (língxiān zhēnxìang)**—
many revealed blessings for my descendants.
On the **second day of the intercalary month at dusk**,
I again dreamed of **celestial assemblies (xiānlíng gònghuì)**,
and begged for auspicious responses.
I also saw **(a missing character) of extraordinary splendor**.
At the **midpoint of the month**,
suddenly, I encountered **Nine Elders (Jiǔlǎo xiānsheng)**,
who summoned me in **chariots (chēzhào)** and led me along.
We met with joy, and they said:
*"We have been in Xuānchéng for forty days and shall return."*
They inquired after my affairs and said:
*"We shall reach Wúhú by the twenty-third day,
then return to visit you.
We shall be delighted to see you again."*
*(This was when I was **Magistrate of Yùyáo**,
later serving as **Secretary of the Secretariat**.)*

On the **fourth day of the intercalary month at dusk**,
I dreamed of **colorful banners (cǎiwù)** in the shape of **flags (yángxíng)**,
all spread out upon the mats—
some like **paintings (huà)**, some like **embroidered brocade (jǐnxiù)**,

The more they unfolded, the more wondrous they became.
They said it was **Yang’s household treasures (Yángshè wùwù)**.
Yet I did not see **Master Yang** at the time.
They urged me to **record them**,
saying: *"Only one skilled in **ordering figures (zhěngdùn)**—
something I have never seen—
should undertake this.
There will be about ten such banners."*

Again, I dreamed of being in the same place,
where a **hanging mountain chest** released itself,
falling from a **precarious peak**.
From afar, I saw **Liú Shēng** conversing with someone.
From that point, I was to **return home**—
but the **road back was perilous**.
I obtained a **fine knot** and threaded it through a **handkerchief**.
I saw my **native city** offering support,
and thus I was able to **turn and retreat**.
*(The above six entries are all recorded by the Prefect himself from his dreams.)*

the **five officials of the kitchen** were ordered to **hunt in the southern mountains**.
*(This is also recorded by the Prefect himself—
